headline: New Envoy for Prison Transfers
abstract: The Obama administration on Tuesday named Lee Wolosky as the State Department’s envoy for negotiating transfers of detainees from the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Tuesday named Lee Wolosky as the State Department’s envoy for negotiating transfers of detainees from the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Mr. Wolosky fills a position that had been vacant since Clifford Sloan, the previous envoy, stepped down in December. The only transfers approved since then involved a resettlement of six Yemenis in Oman in June, a deal that was struck last year. President Obama wants to close the prison, but many Republicans want to block any more transfers, and the State Department and Pentagon often disagree over the risk of releasing certain prisoners. Of the 116 detainees remaining, 52 are approved for release if security conditions can be met. Mr. Wolosky worked on illicit transnational financing at the National Security Council in the late Clinton and early Bush administrations. He is a partner at Boies, Schiller & Flexner.

headline: King of All Media: Larry King’s Internet Afterlife
abstract: In February 2012, CNN severed its relationship with the host; now, at 81, he’s as comfortable with the brave new wired world as any millennial.
lead_paragraph: Larry King has looked like a retiree for at least three decades — like the snappiest dresser at a Boca Raton assisted-living facility — but he only stopped working in 2012, and not by choice. First, in 2010, King was eased out of his post at “Larry King Live,” the nightly talk show he had hosted on CNN since 1985. Then, in February 2012, CNN severed the relationship entirely, announcing that King would no longer appear even in occasional specials on the network. King was 78 years old, but he was worse at being retired than Brett Favre or Jay Z. Exactly a month later came the news that King would be returning to talk show hosting, though not, strictly speaking, to the airwaves. He co-founded a new production company, Ora TV, with the Mexican tycoon Carlos Slim Helú (who also has an ownership stake in The New York Times), and signed a multiyear deal for a new web series, “Larry King Now,” with the streaming site Hulu.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Encore) A RIVER RUNS THROUGH IT (1992) Craig Sheffer portrays the writer Norman Maclean as a quiet young man, and Brad Pitt (above right, with Mr. Sheffer) is Paul, his wilder, more magnetic brother in this adaptation of Mr. Maclean’s 1976 autobiographical story about the sons of a Presbyterian minister coming of age in Montana between Prohibition and the Great Depression — and finding expression for their emotions through fly-fishing. “These are men for whom the physical is inseparably entwined with the spiritual, men for whom both aspects of life are best appreciated knee-deep in a rushing river on a glorious day,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about this visually stunning film, for which Philippe Rousselot won an Oscar for best cinematography. “Between the novella’s well-known first sentence (‘In our family, there was no clear line between religion and fly-fishing’) and its elegiac last line (‘I am haunted by waters’), ‘A River Runs Through It’ circled gracefully among the landmarks of Mr. Maclean’s early years without violating the distant perfection of those memories.” It is easy “to recognize Robert Redford’s reverent film version of this beautifully spare novella as a labor of love,” she added. “The same thoughts embraced by Mr. Maclean — of family and history, of the unbridgeable distances between men, of a wild natural landscape as a pathway to spiritual grace — are ably reflected on the screen.”

Either join our alliance, pay ruinous dues and cede your national sovereignty, or you will be destroyed. Unwilling to allow the delegation to present its case to their fellow citizens, the country’s political elite tries to buy time. But appeals to reason, pragmatism and common decency fail to budge the visitors. When the elite finally replies that it is not prepared to surrender its nation’s freedom, the delegation withdraws and, true to its threat, crushes the rebellious country.

One gets the impression that he happily socialized in an ocean of Scotch and martinis with just about everyone of his “vintage,” as he often puts it, as well as with slightly older and younger authors he admired: Robert Penn Warren, James Baldwin, Truman Capote, James Jones, Terry Southern, Arthur Miller, James Dickey, Ralph Ellison, Philip Roth, J.D. On a blue May day, three other naïve Americans and I invited him, along with Gennaro, the chauffeur; Giulio, who ran the fish market; Nino, who staked the peas; and an assortment of others to lunch in the white stucco villa we were borrowing.

headline: What Happens When a State Is Run by Movie Stars?
abstract: The frenzied, fanatical politics of Tamil Nadu, India.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of May 8, I stood in the offering hall of a Hindu temple in Chennai, the capital of the South Indian state of Tamil Nadu, amid a phalanx of anxious politicians dressed in their customary white shirts and dhotis. ‘‘Lord Perumal, we pray that justice will prevail,’’ a priest intoned. ‘‘Tamil Nadu was on the verge of prosperity, but evil powers have left it stagnant. Let Amma resume her work. Let her opponents be punished. Let the evil that has imprisoned her be banished into hell.’’ While we waited for the ceremony to begin, the politicians showed me their tattoos. The minister of higher education had a woman’s plump face inscribed on his forearm. A district secretary had the words ‘‘Long Live Amma.’’

headline: Do Another Woman’s Marriage Vows Bind Me?
abstract: The Ethicists consider whether ‘the other woman' is required to honor a couple’s marriage.
lead_paragraph: A single woman, I moved to a new town and became friendly with a married man who then told me that he was romantically interested in me. He said that while he wasn’t in an open marriage, his wife knew how he felt, and they were negotiating some arrangement that might allow him to pursue his feelings if they were shared. I was attracted to him but made it clear that I wouldn’t have an affair in secret and that I had no desire to cause a rift between him and his wife (whom I didn’t know as well but liked). At one point we saw a movie together, and we continued talking at work; we’re adjunct professors at the same university. It quickly became clear that his wife took a far more traditional view of their marriage, and although I thought I was being fairly responsible, I was pilloried by his wife, by her friends and by a close friend of mine for encouraging his attraction. I was told that I had no girl code, that I was antifeminist, that you just don’t do that to other women. Is a woman who has chosen not to marry really responsible for acting as a custodian of another woman’s marriage? My behavior may have been self-serving, thoughtless or any number of things, but I don’t believe it was ethically objectionable, at least not on the grounds that were presented. NAME WITHHELD

headline: A Jump to Honor a Fallen Marine

abstract: Among Air Force pararescuemen and combat rescue officers, it’s standard practice to name drop zones for fallen brothers.
lead_paragraph: We step off the C-130 ramp from 13,000 feet above the Florida Keys and into a radiant, cool blue sky, cloudless yet hazy on the horizon. Arms interlocked, Dan, Paul and I skydive in a three-man formation while a fourth chases us with his helmet-cam. There is nothing inherently unique about the act of falling at 149 miles per hour, not after you’ve done it enough. But this jump has a sacramental feel even at terminal velocity, and I know it’s due to the name of the drop zone beneath us.

headline: The Economy’s Missing Metrics
abstract: Statistics guide policy and move markets — which is why they should measure what really matters.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every day, a few hundred federal workers, carefully spread around the United States by a rigorous statistical model, carry out a peculiar task on a special, secure tablet computer. Throughout the day, they are directed to visit specific stores in search of specific items — say, organic romaine lettuce hearts; or a 2015 Hyundai Sonata Sport with the premium package; or a men’s long-sleeve button-down shirt, blue, size XL and made of 80 percent cotton and 20 percent polyester. Over the course of the month, 80,000 prices are entered into tablets throughout the country, and the data flow to Washington for processing. Parsed and analyzed by economists, that information determines the official United States government inflation rate: arguably the most influential bit of data in the world, determining whether new factories are built, new employees hired.

headline: Poppy Delevingne’s Secrets for Staying, and Looking, Cool This Summer
abstract: The model and actress, who was recently named Jo Malone’s first-ever brand ambassador, shares her seasonal beauty tips.
lead_paragraph: For the English model and actress Poppy Delevingne, smelling good is every bit as important as looking good. “All my life, I’ve always been very into scent; I’m very sensitive to it,” she said earlier this month from London, where she was busy packing for the Glastonbury Festival. “I can literally meet someone in a pub and be like, ‘You smell like my best friend,’ and know exactly what the scent is.” Delevingne is especially fond of the aromas of popcorn and jasmine, which she says evoke memories of her childhood. But when it comes to her own signature scent, she has long been loyal to the British perfume house Jo Malone, whose Red Roses has been her everyday perfume since her early 20s. And the house recently named Delevingne its first-ever brand ambassador. “I’ve gotten into layering the scents, kind of like being a chemist,” she says. “I’ve been wearing a lot of the Peony & Blush Suede; at night I add Tuberose Angelica to make it a little muskier, a little sexier. And lately I’m really into Wood Sage & Sea Salt. It reminds you literally of the sea, so I’ve been wearing that for the summer.”

After she died when I was 12, cooking was a way to feel connected with her, and it still is. My daughters will never know their Grandma Janie, but they will know her recipes for Danish Puff, Brown-Edged Cookies and French Bread, and that is something. I suppose it makes sense then that I’ve included my older daughter in the kitchen since she was a baby, first in a sling, then on my hip, then standing on a chair next to me while I cracked eggs into a bowl or sifted flour for a batch of chocolate chip cookies. headline: 36 Hours in Chengdu, China
abstract: Despite being a center of high-tech industry, the old way of life persists in the city, with graceful teahouses, serene parks and a lively Tibetan quarter.
lead_paragraph: Chengdu might look like a typically gray Chinese metropolis of skyscrapers and chaotic traffic, but beneath the concrete exterior is one of China’s most inviting, charming cities. Life moves just a little more slowly here. The teahouses fill up quickly on weekends with locals practicing calligraphy and cracking sunflower seeds, and at the Chengdu panda research center, the city’s most famous residents seem content lazing about in trees most of the time. Recently, though, this unpretentious city has seen its economy boom as one of China’s new high-tech hubs, luring young entrepreneurs to found creative start-ups and innovative architects to transform the skyline. There’s definitely a buzz about the place, though it’s hard to notice over the clacking of tiles during a rousing game of mah-jongg in the park.

headline: ‘The Rise of Sneaker Culture’ Tracks Coolness at the Brooklyn Museum
abstract: The exhibit will include rare examples of highly prized shoes and more than a century’s worth of footwear.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t ever be caught out there with a pair of grips that everybody and their mother has,” Bobbito Garcia, high priest of sneaker culture, counseled in an influential essay for The Source magazine in 1991. What Mr. Garcia meant, translated, was: The harder a pair is to find, the cooler it is. Judging by that metric, the Brooklyn Museum should be the coolest place on the planet for sneakerheads with “The Rise of Sneaker Culture,” which opens July 10 and runs through Oct. 4. The show will include not only rare examples of prized shoes, like the original Nike Air Force 1 (a pristine 1983 pair can command $1,500), but also more than a century’s worth of footwear that united the casual, the athletic and the artful in a way that has become ubiquitous worldwide. One of the oldest existing running shoes, from the 1860s, will be featured, along with 1920s Keds. But the show’s main attraction will be examples of the shoes that meshed with hip-hop, the graffiti scene and basketball subculture beginning in the 1970s to lay what Mr. Garcia calls “the foundation for all the madness.” (718-638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org.)

headline: The Photographer Who Introduces Celebrities to Themselves

headline: Classical Playlist: David Lang, ‘Fiamma del Belcanto’ and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: DAVID LANG: ‘The Difficulty of Crossing a Field’ Beverly O’Regan Thiele, Laquita Mitchell, Jay O. Sanders, soloists; Douglas Kinney Frost, conductor; Harlem String Quartet(Cantaloupe Music)Mysticism and entertainment make strange bedfellows. But Mr. Lang’s chamber opera, based on a one-page story by Ambrose Pierce about a slave owner who vanishes into thin air while crossing a field in pre-Civil War Alabama, manages to combine pathos, satire and meditation to strangely addictive effect. Together with the librettist Mac Wellman, Mr. Lang mines the story for all its weird urgency and wonder. The music, performed by a fine roster of singers and actors against a now sparse, now seething instrumental accompaniment shows this composer at his most inventive. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)‘FIAMMA DEL BELCANTO’Diana Damrau, soprano; Gianandrea Noseda, conductor; Orchestra Teatro Regio Torino(Erato)Ms. Damrau has made her mark in a range of Italian repertory, and has been impressive at the Metropolitan Opera in recent years in works including “La Traviata” and “La Sonnambula.” On this disc she has assembled some of her favorite Italian roles from the bel canto, verismo and Verdi repertory. The selections include roles that have become her trademarks, including Violetta from “Traviata,” as well as parts she has yet to perform on stage, like Nedda in “Pagliacci.” In all the arias, Ms. Damrau’s impeccable technique and emotional commitment yield alluring results. (Vivien Schweitzer)BIRTWISTLE: ‘Angel Fighter'; ‘In Broken Images'; ‘Virelai’ Andrew Watts, countertenor; Jeffrey Lloyd-Roberts, tenor; David Atherton, conductor; BBC Singers; London Sinfonietta(NMC)Harrison Birtwistle might have turned 80, but he shows no sign of slowing down. His recent work has been of stunning quality, and the ones included on this new recording are no exception: “Angel Fighter,” a fearsome dramatic cantata on the fight between Jacob and the Angel; “In Broken Images,” an homage to Gabrieli for groups of instruments imagined as choirs; and “Virelai,” a rethinking of a piece from the Middle Ages by Johannes Ciconia. Spare a thought, too, for the London Sinfonietta and NMC — their work for Birtwistle has been crucial. (David Allen)

headline: Tanning Bed Use Falls
abstract: Use of tanning beds declined to 4.2 percent of American adults in 2013, down from 5.5 percent in 2010, according to new data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
lead_paragraph: Use of tanning beds declined to 4.2 percent of American adults in 2013, down from 5.5 percent in 2010, according to new data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The findings, published in a report in JAMA Dermatology, showed broad declines in the practice of indoor tanning by young people. Just 8.6 percent of Americans ages 18 to 29 tanned indoors in 2013, down from 11.3 percent in 2010. The report’s authors attributed the change to more awareness of the risks posed by indoor tanning, a shift that was aided by new laws to limit use of tanning beds by minors.

headline: How to Sell the Most Cookies
abstract: Sing like a Girl Scout. Build up your support crew.
lead_paragraph: Smile. ‘‘No one wants to buy from a person who is frowning,’’ says Katie Francis, 13, who sold 22,200 boxes of Girl Scout cookies this year, breaking the world record she set last year. Look and act like a professional, even if you’re just a child. When making the rounds in Oklahoma City, Francis wears her troop uniform and passes out business cards. Don’t waste time trying to convince naysayers; instead, ‘‘move on and find the yesses.’’ On school days, Francis works past dark, and she logs 12- to 13-hour days on the weekends.

headline: ‘The Word That Is a Prayer’
abstract: Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: What I like best about poems, beyond their sheer aesthetic pleasures, is the way that the intimacy of a single voice speaking across time and space can become a call to empathy. In this poem, the close and particular focus invites a kind of mindfulness — a way to recognize ourselves in others, linked by our common need.

headline: Divided Sky
abstract: Watching Syria burn from across the border.
lead_paragraph: Had I known I would spend so much time thinking about the southern Syrian city of Dara’a, I would have paid more attention when I drove through it in 2009. I was a young teacher then, living in Jordan and en route to Damascus for a short holiday. I’m certain I didn’t even bother to remember the name at the time, much less notice any of the details. But two years later, Dara’a was where the crisis in Syria would begin, with the bloody suppression of a protest against Bashar al-Assad. Today, opposition and regime forces are still battling to control the symbolic city; more than half its population has been displaced, and many of its buildings have been destroyed.

headline: Restaurant Report: Edwins Leadership & Restaurant Institute in Cleveland

headline: Letter of Recommendation: The Oxford English Dictionary
abstract: To own these books is to dwell alongside your own personal Eighth Wonder of the World.
lead_paragraph: Until the appearance of the Oxford English Dictionary in 1928, Samuel Johnson’s 1755 Dictionary of the English Language was the pre-­eminent authority on spelling and usage. Titanic an achievement as it was — Johnson wrote it largely on his own, with the help of a few assistants — it contained only those words the great lexicographer thought worth knowing. Richard Chenevix Trench, dean of Westminster and an early champion of the project that would result in the O.E.D., opposed the very idea of curation, as he explained to the Philological Society in London in November 1857.

headline: Dinesh D’Souza Isn’t the Real Criminal
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The writer and filmmaker on becoming an amateur jailhouse anthropologist.
lead_paragraph: After your conviction for violating campaign-finance law, you served an eight-month sentence, spending nights in a confinement center. Irving Kristol once said that a neoconservative is a liberal who has been ‘‘mugged by reality.’’ So what’s a conservative whose reality is being surrounded by muggers? Unlike white-collar prisons, the confinement center has the full gamut of criminals — armed robbers, rapists, murderers. I thought of myself as an anthropologist with a rare opportunity to, you might say, study the natives.

As we head into the holiday, the campaign trail is crowded in Iowa, and Hillary Rodham Clinton released a large fund-raising figure as her emails while secretary of state continue to be parsed. headline: Understanding the Incomprehensible With Music
abstract: The only way I could get through to my nephew, suddenly a quadriplegic, was with the dark, dirgy music.
lead_paragraph: I arrived home from the Shepherd Center in Atlanta — a “catastrophic care hospital” — debilitated by grief. I had many questions stemming from our family’s new reality, but only one that I would work to answer: What should I include on a soundtrack for recovery for my formerly active and able-bodied 23-year-old nephew who had just become a quadriplegic? I sifted through my iTunes and the pile of neglected CDs shoved to the back of my closet with a clarity of purpose and swollen eyes. There wasn’t much else I could do.

lead_paragraph: MIXED MESSAGES AND PARALYSIS IN GREEK CRISIS | In a day of twists and turns, Greeks could be forgiven for wondering who was in charge,  Andrew Higgins writes in The New York Times. On Wednesday, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece said he would be willing to accept many of the bailout terms set by Greece’s creditors, only to go on television in the afternoon to urge Greeks to vote no on Sunday’s referendum on the bailout,  Suzanne Daley and Kiki Kitsantonis write in The New York Times. For a new short film project directed by the photographer Marissa Kaiser, with creative direction by the hair colorist Aura Friedman, Smith plays five distinct characters, intercut reading the same monologue — it’s a meditation on identity and style that is also, thanks to her natural charisma, quite funny. The full video will premiere on Nowness tomorrow; in the meantime, here’s a patriotic teaser that finds Smith’s five very different women brought together by America’s founding document. headline: A Movie Scene About Abortion, With a Message for Mother and Daughter
abstract: I don’t want my daughters to have abortions. I do want them to know they can come to me, like the character in “Obvious Child” goes to her mother.
lead_paragraph: My daughter and I are snuggled up in the big bed watching a movie. Perched side-by-side, my laptop propped against our knees, we are as cozy as we once were a dozen years ago in this very same bed, when we would take naps together. After a romp at the playground, we’d come home to a little mac and cheese, an episode of The Wiggles, and then we’d settle down for a snooze. She’d stick her chilly bare feet between my knees (“cozy toes,” we called this maneuver) and her eyelids would flutter a little as her breathing grew deep, nearly as close to me as a baby in the womb.

headline: ‘The Truth and Other Lies,’ by Sascha Arango

lead_paragraph: “You can always count on a murderer for a fancy prose style,” says Humbert Humbert in “Lolita.” Humbert is a pedophile and a murderer. Henry Hayden (another H.H.), the protagonist of “The Truth and Other Lies,” by Sascha Arango, is merely a murderer, though, like Humbert, a man of discernment. He’s a world-­famous, best-selling novelist, with millions of copies sold around the world, a winner of awards and a recipient of honorary degrees. He drives a Maserati, wears expensive suits and lives in splendor in a coastal town in, apparently, Germany.

headline: ‘Book of Numbers,’ by Joshua Cohen
abstract: A failed novelist is tasked with producing a tech mogul’s memoirs.
lead_paragraph: “For last year’s words belong to last year’s language,” T.S. Eliot wrote, “and next year’s words await another voice.” It would be hard to find a more apt description of Joshua Cohen and his brilliantly exhausting fourth novel, “Book of Numbers.” On its surface, the book is about a struggling New York novelist hired as an Internet billionaire’s ghostwriter — but its breadth, the ambition of its ideas and devices, confounds standard book review responses. Trying to approach this ­demanding, overstuffed novel is a bit like hyperlinking one’s way around the Internet: It’s bigger, wilder and fuller than you imagined, and there’s always more where that came from.

headline: ‘Joan of Arc: A History,’ by Helen Castor

lead_paragraph: Fame is like a parasite. It feeds off its host — infecting, extracting, consuming its victim until there’s nothing left but an empty husk. For the lucky (or unlucky, depending on your point of view), with the emptiness comes the possibility of a long afterlife as one of the blowup dolls of history.

headline: ‘Valley Fever,’ by Katherine Taylor
abstract: A young woman reluctantly returns to her parents’ California farm to nurse a case of heartache.
lead_paragraph: Romantic breakups are never fun, but the Devil is in the details. It is better, for example, not to be caught completely off guard. Ideally, one should also not hear the phrase “I think I only love you when I’m drunk.” No such luck for Ingrid Palamede, the heroine of Katherine Taylor’s second novel, “Valley Fever.” After uprooting her life in New York to live with her boyfriend in Los Angeles, she discovers, nearly a year in, that he doesn’t love her. Ingrid is becoming a connoisseur of sudden, devastating breakups in exotic locales, but this one leaves her homeless and unmoored. The book begins with her crying in an airport, calling her big sister to pick her up.

headline: ‘Life #6,’ by Diana Wagman
abstract: Facing cancer, this novel’s heroine considers life, death and a long-ago nearly fatal voyage.
lead_paragraph: If every stage of growth proceeds from a sort of metaphorical death, how many times in life does one person die? We cycle through our grand repertory of possible selves, striving in adolescence and adulthood for reinvention, yet our most enduring feature never recedes: We are always dying.

headline: Nathaniel Popper’s ‘Digital Gold’ Looks at Bitcoin
abstract: A journalist profiles the developers and devotees who have aided the rise of cybercurrency.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to create an entirely new world, like that in “Star Wars,” or in Neal Stephenson’s “Cryptonomicon,” you would certainly need an entirely new form of money. As Nathaniel Popper points out in his new book, “Digital Gold,” which tracks the roller-coaster ride of the digital currency called Bitcoin, it’s not surprising that part of its appeal to its devotees is that it could enable the creation of that new world, a libertarian utopia. Bitcoins — which are created, or mined, via complex computer algorithms, and are stored in digital wallets — offer privacy: Although every transaction is recorded, the users are identified only by wallet IDs, which are difficult, if not impossible, to track back to their owners. Theoretically, Bitcoins also allow users to avoid any fees or meddling by a middleman like a bank, because buyers and sellers can deal directly with one another. At its grandest, Bitcoin promises freedom from the clunkiness of cash, from the dominance of central banks and from technology that allows us to be tracked, even by our own governments. On a more prosaic level, why shouldn’t money be as vulnerable to technological disruption as, say, music?

headline: ‘A Lady of Good Family,’ by Jeanne Mackin
abstract: A novel follows the Grand Tour of a landscape-design pioneer.
lead_paragraph: Toward the beginning of “The ­Beautiful American,” Jeanne Mackin’s absorbing 2014 novel of American expats in France from the 1920s through World War II, her heroine asks, “Do they matter, simple facts?” She could be summing up the dilemma of the historical novelist: How closely must fiction inspired by real people and events — as Mackin’s novels have been — hew to the bones of the ­historical record? How much can the writer invent without betraying the reader’s trust? And, conversely, how much must the writer invent in order to transform history, in all its messiness, into fiction with a satisfying narrative arc and fully developed characters?

headline: ‘The Body Where I Was Born,’ by Guadalupe Nettel
abstract: A woman’s harrowing girlhood, as told to her analyst.
lead_paragraph: The girl at the heart of Guadalupe Nettel’s novel has a peculiar problem. She is a cockroach. At least her mother refers to her this way, as when she castigates her posture: “Cucaracha!” she yells. “Stand up straight!” Adding insult to insecthood, a birthmark on the child’s right cornea limits her vision. In order to strengthen the extraocular muscles, she must wear a flesh-hued cloth over her good eye. She resists putting it on each morning, but once it is secured, she submits to being “a patched child” until 5 o’clock, when she is allowed to remove it.

headline: Joseph Luzzi’s ‘In a Dark Wood’
abstract: Joseph Luzzi turned to Dante to come to terms with grief after his wife’s death.
lead_paragraph: Beatrice Portinari died at age 24 on June 8, 1290, and dozens of other figures in the “Commedia” were dead by the week in 1300 when Dante, poet and protagonist, crossed over to the other side. “The Divine Comedy” is a long poem about a lot of dead people, and Dante, no halfway believer in the hereafter, used his gifts — for speech, for the strong image, for extravagant simile — to bring them to life in words.

headline: Etgar Keret’s ‘The Seven Good Years: A Memoir’
abstract: An Israeli writer describes a parent’s daily life in a combat zone.
lead_paragraph: Etgar Keret’s story collections are like good punk rock records: fast, fun and cultishly admired. And yet despite the inclusion of a few foundation-rattling standouts, even the best punk records ultimately leave the listener under the spell of undiminishing sameness. The same goes for Keret’s collections. Not that Keret is completely to blame; his genre is the parable, and if it weren’t for the demands of the market, these stories would be individually packaged rather than bound in books. The best of Keret’s stories, “Surprise Egg,” say, from his 2006 collection “The Nimrod Flipout,” explode with distortion. In the case of that particular story, there’s also an actual explosion — a suicide bomb — and the story’s power lies in the immediacy of its ending: a bomb-­widowed husband dreams of the foot of his dead wife slowly stroking his face. Keret forgoes easy moralizing and refuses to politicize the personal or to offer an obvious message. When Keret, who is Israeli and writes in Hebrew, first appeared in English, he was hailed as a savior of short stories from the dour realism of Raymond Carver, and a liberator of Israeli fiction from the big-picture density of writers like David Grossman. His stories were unapologetically absurd and libidinous, and if they weren’t all winners, then at least there was something refreshing in Keret’s imaginative conceits.

headline: ‘Irrepressible: The Jazz Age Life of Henrietta Bingham,’ by Emily Bingham

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: HOW TO TELL TOLEDO FROM THE NIGHT SKY, by Lydia Netzer. (St. Martin’s Griffin, $15.99.) headline: Inside the List
abstract: Holly Madison, the former Playboy Playmate whose tell-all memoir is No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list, has said, “I don’t want negative, toxic people in my life anymore.”
lead_paragraph: Here Bunny, Bunny: Holly Madison, the former Playboy Playmate and star of the E! reality show “The Girls Next Door,” about life at the Playboy Mansion, hits the hardcover nonfiction list this week with a tell-all memoir, “Down the Rabbit Hole,” new at No. 2. The book paints a fairly tawdry picture of Madison’s years as Hugh Hefner’s girlfriend — or, more accurately, as the “No. 1 girlfriend” in a volatile harem rife with infighting, sexual competition and petty jealousies over money and favors. (I told you it was tawdry.) Hef has accused Madison of “rewriting history,” a claim she shrugged off in a recent interview with The Associated Press: “He doesn’t have any mental or emotional power over me anymore,” she said. “He’s somebody that I look back on as somebody who treated me really poorly, who I tried to convince myself was a great person but I don’t think is. And I don’t want negative, toxic people in my life anymore.” All of this is a good excuse, if you needed one, to dig up a copy of Gloria Steinem’s 1963 exposé of the Playboy Club in New York City, where she briefly assumed a false name and went undercover in the standard satin costume, complete with ears and a rabbit tail. “A middle-­aged man in a private guard’s uniform grinned and beckoned,” Steinem wrote. “ ‘Here bunny, bunny, bunny,’ he said, and jerked his thumb toward the glass door on the left. ‘Interviews downstairs in the Playmate Bar.’ ” Madison might recognize the world Steinem was writing about, even if it had less silicone than she’s used to; evidently, the bunnies of Steinem’s era padded their bosoms with plastic dry-cleaning bags.

headline: A Former Wedding Photographer Finds His Focus as a Crooner
abstract: The 24-year-old R&B singer Vicktor Taiwo premieres the video for his song “Curse.”
lead_paragraph: “Music is a very visual thing for me,” says the Nigerian-born singer-songwriter Vicktor Taiwo. “I don’t mean I see green or something when I make music, but when I start making a song, it looks like a real, physical thing to me.” That the 24-year-old Londoner views music as a multisensory enterprise is little surprise. As a teenager, Taiwo fell deeply in love with photography after playing with the aperture on his mother’s camera. “I realized it could be pitch-black, and I could change a knob and it would be bright,” he says. “It blew my mind.” By 15, he was a working photographer, toting his own DSLR to weddings and parties around Britain. He was paid for his work, but the high-pressure gigs overwhelmed him. “I hated photography after that,” he says.

But his 7th Regiment Punch, made from brandy, wine and raspberries, is particularly opulent: It’s served in a scalloped black-and-white teacup reminiscent of “Alice in Wonderland” and comes over hand-cracked ice. The drink has quite a pedigree: It’s mentioned by the legendary bartender Jerry Thomas in his 1862 handbook “The Bon Vivant’s Companion,” and was originally created by the sons of the Vanderbilts, Van Rensselaers and Livingstons who made up the ranks of New York’s “Silk Stocking” regiment.

headline: National Ballet of China Conveys Its History at Lincoln Center Festival
abstract: Two works, dating from 1964 and 2008, show how the company has evolved from its revolutionary roots.
lead_paragraph: “Our aim in the cultural sphere is to build a new Chinese national culture,” Mao wrote in 1940, more than two decades before the start of the Cultural Revolution. Since then, China has undergone a series of profound cultural shifts, many of which Mao could never have predicted. Change has come to every sphere, including ballet, a relatively recent import that has nonetheless played a role in the country’s re-evaluation of its performance traditions and aesthetic ideals. New Yorkers will have the chance to view part of that trajectory next week when the National Ballet of China comes to the Koch Theater as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. Later the company will travel to Wolf Trap in Vienna, Va., and Saratoga, N.Y.

abstract: The Dominican Republic hasn’t yet acted on its plans to expel hundreds of thousands of people of Haitian descent. But the worst may be yet to come.
lead_paragraph: In early 2006, my first long-term overseas posting as a journalist took me to the Dominican Republic. From my new home in Santo Domingo, I planned to write about tourism, baseball, corruption and drug trafficking, while working on my Spanish. If things went well, I figured, I might even get to cross the island of Hispaniola’s international border, into Haiti, whose chronic crises — including a recent coup d’état that had overthrown the president — drew more international interest.

headline: Review: Ruth Root, Minimal and Opulent, at Andrew Kreps Gallery
abstract: The artist’s new work unleashes a firestorm of patterns.
lead_paragraph: In a gesture of extraordinary generosity and transparency, the artist Ruth Root once made a news release with dozens of thumbnail images of phenomena that had inspired her work: everything from paintings by Peter Feeley, Mary Heilmann, Ellsworth Kelly and Josef Albers to shaped bathmats, ghosts and multicolored ski socks. From the looks of her current show, Ms. Root has stayed close to these origins — yet also strayed very far away.

headline: Review: Susan Cianciolo Lets Others Pick Through Fragments of Her Life
abstract: This show at Bridget Donahue is part archive, part reliquary and part toolbox.
lead_paragraph: The kind of visual and tactile magic that makes you remember why you loved art in the first place — way back, as a kid — is hard to find. But it’s there in Susan Cianciolo’s enchanting solo exhibition, her first New York gallery show in over a decade.

headline: Review: Zoe Leonard’s ‘Analogue’ Shows the Human Toll of Globalization
abstract: This vast suite of photographs installed in the Museum of Modern Art’s atrium has no images of people but still evokes a sense of human struggle.
lead_paragraph: Zoe Leonard’s “Analogue,” a vast suite of photographs installed across three walls of the Museum of Modern Art’s atrium, is an affectingly plangent update of Social Realist photography. Produced between 1998 and 2009, its 412 images — 342 color, 70 black and white — show examples of low-end commerce from New York to Africa, indirectly but evocatively representing the human toll of corporate globalization.

headline: Forget Fireworks: A Couch Potato’s TV Lineup

headline: An Artist on the Margins Is Rescued From Obscurity
abstract: An artist’s work ended up in a relative’s attic after she was institutionalized, and an HBO documentary is now bringing her story to light.
lead_paragraph: A career sidelined by greed inspired the HBO documentary “Packed in a Trunk: The Lost Art of Edith Lake Wilkinson,” which will be shown on July 20. The film resulted from decades of legwork by the writer and director Jane Anderson, Wilkinson’s great-niece. Her family inherited about 120 artworks and related documents from Wilkinson, a West Virginia native who had trained at the Art Students League of New York in the 1880s and befriended modernist painters, including Blanche Lazzell.

lead_paragraph: During Abstract Expressionism’s heyday in the 1950s, three artists in San Francisco turned away from abstraction and back to representational painting, founding a movement that came to be known as Bay Area Figuration. They were David Park, Richard Diebenkorn and the subject of this stirring exhibition at the George Adams Gallery, Elmer Bischoff (1916-1991).

headline: Review: Sargent’s Intimate Portraits of Friends at the Metropolitan Museum
abstract: This high-society portrait painter put something extra into the work when his sitters were his companions and peers.
lead_paragraph: Despite a career as a society portraitist, John Singer Sargent was, by many accounts, a shy man, given to halting speech or silence except among people he knew well and liked. He was not ever, though, a shy painter. Few artists in any era have had as extroverted a hand as his, and as keen an instinct for visual theater. And when his sitters were people he cared for, something extra came into the work, a relaxed recklessness of a kind that scintillates and sluices through the 90 paintings and drawings in “Sargent: Portraits of Artists and Friends” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Review: In ‘Cartel Land’ Documentary, Vigilantes Wage Drug Wars
abstract: Matthew Heineman’s on-the-ground film profiles leaders of two vigilante groups fighting drug gangs, one in Arizona and the other in Michoacán, Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The director Matthew Heineman has a terrific eye. And, to judge from “Cartel Land,” his immersive documentary about American and Mexican vigilante groups, he also has guts and nerves of steel. Serving as the primary cinematographer, he employs a run-and-gun style for much of the movie, using a lightweight digital camera that at times lurches so dramatically that you can visualize the body attached to it. Considering that Mr. Heineman landed in a few shootouts while making this documentary, both his camera moves and its pictorial quality are striking.

headline: ‘Ernest Hemingway: Between Two Wars’ Arriving at Morgan Library
abstract: On display are letters, photographs, dog tags and first editions that reflect the celebrated author’s creative process.
lead_paragraph: Ernest Hemingway was a maker of lists and a collector of his life’s ephemera. For the first time, some of the objects that this American writer gathered during his long career — bullfighting stubs from Pamplona in Spain, boastful fishing logs from expeditions off the Cuban coast, coy letters to a mistress, penciled drafts of stories — will be on display in an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum from Sept. 25 through Jan. 31.

headline: Drought Pushes Nevada Ranchers to Take On Washington
abstract: After one ranching family in the drought-stricken northern desert let its cattle graze on federally owned land, it and other families struck deals with the government to do the same.
lead_paragraph: BATTLE MOUNTAIN, Nev. — Around here they call it “going Bundy”: allowing cattle to graze illegally on federally owned land. For months, ranching families in this tiny community have itched to do it — both because of the relentless drought, which has left their own land dry and their animals hungry, and because of the anti-Washington streak that runs deep in this part of the rural West, where people fervently believe that the government owns too much land.

Mr. Hall, whose nickname gives the film its title, is a Vietnam veteran, a biker, the manager of a trailer park in southern Missouri, the patriarch of a multicultural family and much more. He’s a complicated American, and Ms. Granik honors that complexity.

headline: Review: ‘Jimmy’s Hall’ Pits the Church Against a Populist Gathering Place
abstract: Ken Loach’s film, set in Ireland in the 1930s, centers on a man of the people who turns an abandoned community center into a place to dance and dream.
lead_paragraph: One of the pleasures of “Jimmy’s Hall,” a likable period piece directed by the social-realist British filmmaker Ken Loach, is its unswerving belief in old-fashioned populist heroes. Such a hero is Jimmy Gralton (Barry Ward), a real-life Irish firebrand portrayed as an articulate, courageous natural leader without a shred of grandiosity. Jimmy is a man of the people whose defiance of the powers that be eventually lands him in deep trouble.

headline: Spare Times for July 3-9
abstract: A listing of holiday events, discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s Fourth of July Fireworks (Saturday) This corporate-sponsored display of patriotism sparkles above the East River for a second year since its return from the Hudson. It begins around 9:20 p.m., with fireworks barges set up at the Brooklyn Bridge and between 23rd and 34th Streets in Manhattan.

headline: Spare Times for Children for July 3-9
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: Bug Week

headline: Review: ‘Closer to God’ Offers a Modern-Day Frankenstein Tale
abstract: Billy Senese’s new film explores the consequences of a doctor’s experiments in human cloning.
lead_paragraph: Billy Senese’s suspense movie “Closer to God” would like you to know the weightiness of its “Frankenstein”-like themes of scientific irresponsibility. So it hammers them home again and again: in staged TV news reports, in scenes of public protest, in conversations between its main character, Dr. Victor Reed (Jeremy Childs), and his wife, Claire (Shannon Hoppe). Victor has produced what he says is the first human clone, an infant named Elizabeth, and taken her home for observation. But Elizabeth isn’t as problematic as Ethan, a previous child experiment raised secretly in a separate house on Victor’s estate. Ethan tends to be manic and homicidal.

headline: Liberia Reports New Cases of Ebola
abstract: Three cases have emerged in the country since it was declared free of the virus on May 9, highlighting the continuing threat of viral outbreaks in West Africa.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Three new cases of Ebola have emerged in Liberia since the country was declared free of the virus on May 9, highlighting the continuing threat of viral outbreaks in West Africa. The Liberian government said it was tracing scores of people who had recent contact with the three patients.

headline: Prison Escapee Was Killed After He Aimed Gun at Agent, Officials Say
abstract: United States Customs and Border Protection now indicates that Richard W. Matt tried to make a last stand when he was tracked down.
lead_paragraph: Cornered in the woods three weeks after his extraordinary escape from prison, Richard W. Matt aimed his 20-gauge shotgun at an armed federal agent late last week but was shot and killed before he could pull the trigger, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Review: In ‘Zarafa,’ a Giraffe Journeys in a Hot-Air Balloon
abstract: This story of a friendship between a boy and a wild creature takes them across the Mediterranean.
lead_paragraph: Pro-giraffe and antislavery, the animated feature “Zarafa” follows an African boy, Maki, on his trek across deserts, oceans and the city of Paris to save a friend. Set in the early 1820s, when the pasha of Egypt famously gave a giraffe to King Charles X of France, this hand-drawn French adventure is a children’s story in the routine template of many friends-and-villains quests, but with a fresh historical setting and a serenely subdued look.

headline: Bidens to Lead U.S. World Cup Delegation
abstract: The White House named a delegation to the championship soccer game in Vancouver, to be led by Dr. Jill Biden and her husband, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: The United States women’s soccer team will have some high-profile fans in the stands on Sunday as it faces Japan in the World Cup final.

headline: A Mission to Catalog Hidden Life in Central Park
abstract: The Flora Project has documented 200 species of plants in the park, discovering some that were previously not known to grow there.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Atha put on his waders and ventured slowly into the Pool, near West 103rd Street, one of several bodies of water in Central Park. He was after a broad-leaved yellow pond lily and an iris of indeterminate species.

headline: Review: ‘Stung’ Stars Giant Wasps That Attack the Rich
abstract: In Benni Diez’s horror comedy, a millionaire’s al fresco dinner turns ugly because her growth-hormone-infused plant fertilizer has created a swarm of monsters.
lead_paragraph: For sheer gustatory delight, you can’t beat outdoor summer dining: barbecue, lemonade, cold beer on a humid evening. But watch out for wasps, especially any that have been feeding on growth-hormone-infused plant fertilizer. Even industrial DEET is no match for the seven-foot-tall winged predators that make the lives of the caterers Julia (Jessica Cook) and Paul (Matt O’Leary) so stressful in Benni Diez’s comic gorefest, “Stung.”

headline: Danny Elfman Brings Music From Tim Burton’s Films to Lincoln Center
abstract: Mr. Elfman, who has scored nearly 100 movies, has reorchestrated 15 suites from the ones he made with Mr. Burton.
lead_paragraph: “I’M a mole,” Danny Elfman said, putting on a pair of shaded glasses as he sat in a bright restaurant at Lincoln Center recently. Mr. Elfman, the versatile composer who has scored nearly 100 movies, ranging from “Good Will Hunting” to “Avengers: Age of Ultron,” as well as writing the enduring theme to “The Simpsons,” was talking about his proclivity for the nighttime. “I lived at the beach for five years, and they called me Nosferatu on the Beach,” he said. “As soon as the sun got big and red and was going down, I would come out.” He works nocturnally, too, moving among three studios he owns around Los Angeles, soundtracking into the wee hours.

headline: Val Doonican, Top-Selling Irish Singer and TV Host, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Doonican hosted a variety show for two decades, but was also known for knocking the Beatles out of the top spot on the British album charts.
lead_paragraph: Val Doonican, an Irish crooner whose gentle, humorous way with a song and a story on television made him so popular in Britain in the 1960s and ’70s that he once dislodged the Beatles from the top of the album charts there, died on Wednesday in Buckinghamshire, England. He was 88.

headline: Sprawling Estate With an Unknown Future
abstract: An eight-acre complex is at the center of a disagreement between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles and a group of nuns over who should be able to buy the estate.
lead_paragraph: An eight-acre complex is at the center of a disagreement between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles and a group of nuns over who should be able to buy the estate.

headline: Led by Pirates, Iceland Legalizes Blasphemy
abstract: Surging in the polls, Iceland’s Pirate Party scores its first legislative victory, the decriminalization of blasphemy.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week after Iceland’s prime minister contended that his nation’s fundamental values would be at risk should the insurgent Pirate Party ever come to power, the group celebrated its first legislative success on Thursday, the decriminalization of blasphemy.

headline: Review: Shania Twain in Concert Recalls Glory Days
abstract: Ms. Twain’s set at Nassau Coliseum featured her many country hits, with nods to other genres.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Everything shone brightly when Shania Twain performed at Nassau Coliseum here on Wednesday night. After a long residency in Las Vegas, she is back on the road for her first tour in over a decade — one that she has said will be her last. She brought Las Vegas with her. She had blond hair, sequined minidresses, thigh-high boots, banks of lasers, tall video screens and bursts of fireworks. For “Up!,” the title song of her blockbuster 2002 album, she was literally back in the saddle, one that was mounted on a cherry picker to lift her up and closer to the audience.

headline: For Two Final Weeks, Playing in, and Cheering On, the Band
abstract: In the last two weeks, the Grateful Dead played five final “Fare Thee Well” shows in Santa Clara, Calif., and Chicago to celebrate the band’s 50th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: In the last two weeks, the Grateful Dead played five final “Fare Thee Well” shows in Santa Clara, Calif., and Chicago to celebrate the band’s 50th anniversary.

headline: As Grateful Dead Exit, a Debate Will Not Fade Away
abstract: As the band prepares for its last of its 50th anniversary “Fare Thee Well” concerts, some Deadheads, among the most ardent of music fans, contend that attendance is not necessary.
lead_paragraph: ALAN MANDE calls his first experience with the Grateful Dead, in 1969, “a portal to a spiritual awakening.” Since then, he’s attended more than 400 shows and traded bootlegs with untold Deadheads, all while philosophizing on the nature of such devoted fandom.

headline: ‘The Hunger Games: The Exhibition’ Allows Kids to Express Their Inner Katniss
abstract: This exhibition at Discovery Times Square, packed with movie costumes, props and activities, puts Peeta Mellark squarely in the friend zone.
lead_paragraph: REBELLION? Awesome. Romance? Not so much.

headline: Review: ‘Multitudinous Heart,’ Newly Translated Poetry by Carlos Drummond de Andrade
abstract: The book, with translations by Richard Zenith, includes samples from every phase of the revered Brazilian poet’s career.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Drummond de Andrade (1902-1987) is widely considered the greatest poet in the history of Brazil, a country where poets are taken seriously. One of his poems, “Canção Amiga” (“Friendly Song”), was once printed on the 50 cruzados bill.

headline: ‘Ada/Ava’ and ‘Preludes’ Are Shows to See in a Relatively Empty City
abstract: The holiday weekend often means smaller crowds and shorter lines for some of the city’s top attractions, like its museums and theater.
lead_paragraph: Stuck in the city this holiday weekend? As your neighbors load their cars, stuff themselves onto trains and push their way to the bridges and tunnels, the Miser suggests you wave goodbye with a smile — your piece of the Big Apple just got that much bigger.

headline: Sheldon Richardson of Jets Is Among Four Suspended for Drugs
abstract: Richardson, a stalwart defensive lineman, apologized to teammates and fans after he was barred for four games for violating league’s substance abuse policy and program.
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Richardson, a stalwart of the Jets’ defensive line, will miss the first four games of the season for violating the N.F.L.’s substance-abuse policy and program.

headline: Remembering the Phonograph
abstract: With the advent of yet another way to stream music, Friday File looks back to the beginning of recorded sound — Thomas Edison’s phonograph.
lead_paragraph: 127 YEARS AGO

headline: A Ford Recall for Engines That Might Not Turn Off
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Ford is recalling about 433,000 of its newest cars and sport utilities because drivers may not be able to shut off the engine, even after pressing the “stop engine” button.
lead_paragraph: Ford is recalling about 433,000 of its newest cars and sport utilities — including almost 375,000 in the United States — because drivers may not be able to shut off the engine, even after pressing the “stop engine” button, the automaker said on Thursday. The problem with the 2015 Focus, C-MAX and Escape models is a computer malfunction. “When I tried to shut the engine, it didn’t,” the owner of a 2015 Escape wrote to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in May. “The motor was still running when it was being towed.” Ford said it was not aware of any accidents or injuries.

headline: Boko Haram Militants Suspected in Attacks at Mosques in Nigeria
abstract: Up to 150 people were gunned down in three locations, according to witnesses, in attacks by gunmen thought to be members of Boko Haram.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Gunmen thought to be members of the Islamist sect Boko Haram rounded up scores of men in mosques in northeast Nigeria on Wednesday evening and began shooting indiscriminately, witnesses said.

headline: Nascar Asks Fans to Put Away Confederate Flags
keywords: ['Automobile Racing', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series']
abstract: Although Nascar has stopped short of an outright ban, officials at every racetrack that hosts an event in the top three national series asked fans to no longer display the flags at their tracks.
lead_paragraph: Confederate battle flags have been common at Nascar racetracks for decades, with fans often flying them above their motor homes along with American flags and banners of their favorite drivers. Nascar, with its predominantly white Southern fan base, has always tolerated the presence of the flag at its races even after banning it from official use.

headline: Opening-Round 66 Leaves Tiger Woods Buoyed
abstract: After missing the cut at the United States Open, Woods equaled his lowest score relative to par this year and trailed the Greenbrier Classic’s first-day leader, Scott Langley, by four strokes.
lead_paragraph: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va. — The only other time Tiger Woods appeared in the Greenbrier Classic, he was coming off his third victory of the 2012 season and had not posted a score higher than 75 all year. He carded a 71 and a 69 on the par-70 Old White TPC course and did not make the cut.

headline: Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas May Face Securities-Fraud Indictment
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Attorneys General', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: A special prosecutor said he would present evidence against Mr. Paxton that was uncovered by the Texas Rangers.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Evidence that Ken Paxton, the attorney general of Texas, committed securities fraud before he became the state’s top lawyer will soon be presented to a grand jury, a special prosecutor said this week.

headline: Miss USA Pageant Finds a Televised Venue
abstract: Reelz, a cable network, has stepped up to carry the Miss USA Pageant on July 12. Univision and NBC had backed out after Donald Trump’s comments on immigrants.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — The symbolism wasn’t lost on the organizers and contestants of the 2015 Miss USA pageant Wednesday evening as thunderstorms drenched the public sports park where their first official media event was scheduled to take place.

headline: Bratton Tells Police Academy Graduates They Face a Time of Change
abstract: The mood at the graduation of 822 police academy recruits on Thursday contrasted sharply with the atmosphere at the December graduation.
lead_paragraph: It was nine days after two police officers were killed in December when a class of recruits last graduated from the New York Police Academy.

headline: Cardinals Fire Rising Front-Office Star Amid Hacking Investigation
abstract: Chris Correa, the Cardinals’ scouting director, was fired, according to an official with direct knowledge of the decision. Correa once worked for Astros General Manager Jeff Luhnow.
lead_paragraph: As the F.B.I. continues its investigation into a breach of the Houston Astros’ database, the St. Louis Cardinals have fired their scouting director, Chris Correa, who once worked under Jeff Luhnow before Luhnow left the Cardinals to be Houston’s general manager.

headline: Fiat Chrysler Accused of Neglect in 23 Recalls
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In a rare public hearing, the N.H.T.S.A. condemned the automaker for not promptly notifying owners of problematic vehicles, delaying repairs and failing to alert regulators.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators on Thursday accused Fiat Chrysler Automobiles of putting lives at risk by repeatedly failing to perform timely vehicle recalls and inform consumers of dangerous defects.

headline: Aetna Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Humana for $34 Billion
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A push for mergers among large insurers has gained momentum since the Supreme Court upheld a key part of the Obama administration’s health care law.
lead_paragraph: Aetna is near an agreement to buy its smaller rival Humana for about $34 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday, in what could be the first in a series of mergers among the country’s big health insurers.

headline: Jihadist From Tunisia Died in Strike in Libya, U.S. Official Says
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Seifallah Ben Hassine, one of Osama bin Laden’s top lieutenants and Tunisia’s most wanted jihadist, was killed in an American airstrike in Libya last month, a senior United States official said.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisia’s most wanted jihadist, who masterminded a campaign of assassinations and terrorist attacks, including one against the United States Embassy in Tunis, was killed in an American airstrike in Libya in mid-June that had targeted another Al Qaeda leader, a senior United States official said on Thursday.

headline: Air Passengers Applaud a Justice Dept. Collusion Case
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Peeved passengers are cheering on government investigators looking into possible collusion among the major domestic airlines.
lead_paragraph: As the manager of her husband’s rock band, Jill Meniketti has booked many flights over the past 12 years.

headline: Business Ties Made by Jeb Bush as Florida Governor Turned Lucrative When He Left Office
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: The former Florida governor is finding a steady source of income in speeches for corporations, industry trade groups and other organizations.
lead_paragraph: In his final year as governor, Jeb Bush led a campaign to persuade an Italian military contractor and its partners to build a plant in Florida, meeting with the company’s chief executive, offering financial incentives and appearing at an event celebrating the project.

headline: Dustin Brown, Ranked 102nd, Seems to Have Rafael Nadal’s Number
abstract: Brown, 30, who grew up in Germany and Jamaica, defeated Nadal, the 10th seed at Wimbledon, for the second time in two opportunities on grass.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Dustin Brown stands 6 feet 5 inches, with dreadlocks about half that long, and is listed at a lithe 172 pounds. He has a large tattoo of his father over his left rib cage, has rings in his ears and speaks English with a German-Caribbean accent.

headline: Yemen Expects a Pause in Fighting for Aid Deliveries
abstract: If a pause is agreed to, it will be a victory in efforts to push Saudi Arabia to let up the airstrikes long enough for food and fuel to be delivered.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Under mounting pressure from United Nations officials who warn of the risk of an imminent famine, the Saudi-backed Yemeni government said it expected a pause in the fighting to be declared to allow for the delivery of humanitarian aid, a government minister said Thursday.

headline: Hopeful Start to Greek Debt Negotiations Quickly Soured
abstract: Why Alexis Tsipras took the extreme step of a referendum remains puzzling. But a look at the events reveals missed chances between Greece and its creditors that led him to think a deal was impossible.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Last Friday morning, the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, gathered his closest advisers in a Brussels hotel room for a meeting that was meant to be secret. All the participants had to leave their phones outside the door to prevent leaks.

headline: Republican Governors Signal Their Intent to Thwart Obama’s Climate Rules
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Governors (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'States (US)', 'Air Pollution', 'Clean Air Act', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: As President Obama prepares to complete sweeping climate regulations, at least five Republican governors say they may refuse to carry out the rules in their states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama prepares to complete sweeping regulations aimed at tackling climate change, at least five Republican governors, including two presidential hopefuls, say they may refuse to carry out the rules in their states.

headline: From Bats to Trades, All Is Quiet for the Mets
abstract: The Mets have scored one run in their last three games, and almost all their hitters are slumping or injured. But the front office isn’t showing much urgency.
lead_paragraph: Baseball is so crazy that the Mets, who have scored one run in their last three games, will probably blitz Clayton Kershaw in Los Angeles on Friday night, and then do the same to Zack Greinke on Saturday. Perhaps the Mets have the Dodgers’ aces right where they want them.

headline: Glenn Ford, Death Row Prisoner Freed After 29 Years, Dies at 65
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Mr. Ford spent three decades on death row in Louisiana for a murder he almost certainly did not commit. He died less than 16 months after his conviction was vacated.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Ford, who spent nearly 30 years on death row in Louisiana for a murder he almost certainly did not commit, died on Monday in New Orleans, less than 16 months after his conviction and death sentence were vacated and he was released. He was 65.

headline: Letter Accompanying Sin
abstract: Brandon Hensley will not share his 15 Across.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — A very fresh and snappy puzzle by Brandon “I Make My Own Ice Cream From Scratch” Hensley. Mr. Hensley, who has yet to offer me any of his delicious RUM RAISIN ice cream, or even his lavender honeycomb flavor (which sounds fabulous), wondered if I was going to begin my post about his puzzle with the word “Ew,” like I did with his debut puzzle. I was actually responding to the grotesque rural legend that his theme described, and not his construction, because it’s impossible for me to think about what that legend described and not respond with an “Ew.”

headline: South Sudan: 2 Sanctioned by U.S.
abstract: Two commanders leading the opposing sides in the civil war convulsing South Sudan were sanctioned by the Treasury Department on Thursday for fomenting the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Two commanders leading the opposing sides in the civil war convulsing South Sudan were sanctioned by the Treasury Department on Thursday for fomenting the conflict. The action against the two, Gabriel Jok Riak and Simon Gatwech Dual, freezes any assets they have under American jurisdiction and bars them from transactions with Americans. The Treasury said the two were responsible for “perpetrating violence and breaching cease-fire agreements.” The United Nations Security Council has imposed sanctions on them and four others.

headline: Signs of a Compromise Over Inspections in Iran Nuclear Talks
abstract: An Iranian official signaled a willingness to accept Western demands for inspections of any nuclear-related facility, despite a previous rejection of such actions by the supreme leader.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — An Iranian official signaled Thursday that Tehran was trying to bridge the gap between Western demands for inspections of any suspected nuclear-related facility and a declaration by Iran’s supreme leader that foreigners could not enter military sites or interview Iranian scientists.

headline: Charles Harbutt, Photojournalist With an Eye for Art, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Harbutt infused his work with evocative imagery and as an art photographer he transformed conventional scenes into surreal metaphors.
lead_paragraph: Charles Harbutt, a photojournalist who infused his work with evocative imagery and an art photographer who transformed conventional scenes into surreal metaphors, died late Monday or early Tuesday in Monteagle, Tenn., near Chattanooga, where he was teaching. He was 79.

headline: Alexis Tsipras’s Enemies in Europe See Their Chance in Vote on Greece’s Bailout Terms
abstract: Opponents of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras are backing a “yes” vote in a referendum on a deal with Greece’s creditors, hoping that outcome will force his ouster.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras says the referendum in Greece on Sunday is simply about whether to agree to what he sees as a bad deal from the country’s creditors. Many of his opponents say it is actually about whether Greece wants to stay with the euro.

headline: Man Accused in Killing Is Indicted on Terrorism Charges, a First for New Jersey
abstract: Ali Muhammad Brown, 30, is accused of killing Brendan Tevlin, 19, as an act of “revenge” for United States military action overseas.
lead_paragraph: A Seattle man accused of killing a New Jersey man as an act of “revenge” for United States military action overseas was indicted on terrorism charges on Thursday, the first time in New Jersey that a defendant has faced a state-level terror charge in a murder case.

headline: Unlikely Journey of Martin St. Louis, Spanning 391 Goals and a Stanley Cup, Comes to Its End
abstract: The Rangers’ St. Louis, an undersized right winger who went from being undrafted to being named most valuable player in 2004, announced his retirement on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Martin St. Louis, an undersized right winger who went from being an undrafted free agent to having an N.H.L. career that will likely put him in the Hall of Fame, announced his retirement Thursday.

headline: Near Citi Field, Plans for Willets West Are Ruled Illegal
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Land Use Policies', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: A state court said that land near the Mets’ ballpark can be used only for a stadium.
lead_paragraph: A state court ruled Thursday that a development group that includes the owners of the Mets cannot build a mall and movie theater on acreage next to Citi Field because it is parkland legally designated only for use as a stadium. The proposed construction of Willets West — on the parking lot where Shea Stadium once stood — is part of a long-planned project to redevelop the larger Willets Point area.

headline: William Anderson Said to Be Leaving Goldman Sachs for Evercore
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The addition of Mr. Anderson would prove a big coup for Evercore, as banks rush to set up their activism advisory teams.
lead_paragraph: One of the most prominent advisers to companies besieged by activist investors is preparing to leave his perch at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Mayor de Blasio and Governor Cuomo Point Fingers, but There’s Enough Blame for Both
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is not known for kindness in the political arena, but Mayor Bill de Blasio is not doing himself any favors either.
lead_paragraph: Just before the shooting war between the mayor and the governor broke into the open this week, a series of guerrilla strikes promised the first signs of life in Albany for months. Other than the two most powerful legislators’ being arrested, nothing much had happened since January, although all kinds of laws needed to be fixed or extended.

headline: When a Chic Italian Interiors Magazine Curates a Pop-Up Bazaar
abstract: This month, Cabana brings its eclectic sensibility to 1stdibs and the MiArt fair at Salone del Mobile.
lead_paragraph: The year-old Italian interiors magazine Cabana is dedicated to the principle of gemütlich, a German term referring to an intimate, comfortable feeling. “That word summons this vision,” says Cabana’s editor in chief, Martina Mondadori. “Not only big and grand rooms, but that corner, that detail, that object that makes a room feel unique and yet personal.” Next week, fans of the publication will have the chance to bring its eclectic sensibility home when the magazine debuts its first-ever pop-up store at the entrance of the MiArt fair taking place in Milan during Salone del Mobile, and an online companion sale at 1stdibs.com. Mondadori hand-selected each of the antique and contemporary objects on offer, including gilded decorative panels by Tennant and Tennant (Stella Tennant’s design project with her sister Isabel); antique decanters similar to a set found at Marella Agnelli’s house in Marrakesh; and ikat cushions by Rifat Ozbek. The assortment is “somewhere between a Middle Eastern bazaar and a cabinet of curiosities,” Mondadori says. “These are ultimately the elements that can make a house truly unique and inspiring.”

headline: Pete Rose Declines to Respond to ESPN Report on Betting
abstract: Rose said that he would wait until a pending reinstatement hearing before baseball’s commissioner to address accusations by ESPN’s “Outside the Lines” that he bet on games as a player.
lead_paragraph: In an appearance on Fox Sports 1 on Thursday, Pete Rose declined to respond to a report on ESPN last month that he bet on baseball while playing for the Cincinnati Reds in 1986.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY (2014) A motley crew of baddies, led by the armed professional scavenger Peter Quill (Chris Pratt, above), joins forces to stop a crazed warrior from taking over the universe in James Gunn’s interstellar western, based on the Marvel Comics characters. The cast includes Zoe Saldana as Gamora, a green, mean killing machine; Dave Bautista as the brute Drax; Glenn Close as a space-age Hillary Rodham Clinton; Bradley Cooper as the voice of the raccoon Rocket; and Vin Diesel as a gorgeous tree called Groot, who nibbles his own tender sprouts. Oh, yes — and a blue orb that has incited the mayhem in the first place. “That there’s a palpable directorial sensibility in ‘Guardians of the Galaxy,’ along with other signs of genuine life, helps separate this latest Marvel cash grab from a lot of off-the-rack movie cartoons,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Here, a pulse, wit, beauty and a real sensibility have been slipped into the fray, alongside the clockwork guffaws, kabooms and splats.” She added: “The story may be confusing and generic by turns, but if you shake off the bonds of narrative coherency it’s liberating letting the weird words — Yondu, Necrocraft, Sakkaran — just slide right past you, much like the zigzagging, exploding 3-D spaceships. What sticks are the fantastical landscapes, the beautiful creature designs and the actors delivering lively performances, even with strata of makeup and digital wizardry.”

headline: A Plan to Resettle Hong Kongers in Northern Ireland? Surely You Jest
abstract: A proposal discussed by British officials in the early 1980s may have been a joke, but it highlighted concerns in Hong Kong about the impending handover and in Northern Ireland about ongoing sectarian unrest.

headline: How Bobbi Brown Spends Her Sundays

Four years later, her company was acquired by Estée Lauder Companies. Ms. Brown, 58, spends her Sundays walking, shopping and socializing with family in Manhattan. She lives with her husband of 27 years, Steven Plofker, also 58, “in the 20s near the High Line,” with a view of the Hudson River and of New Jersey, “where I came from.”

headline: A Photographer Finds Abundant Life in and Around the Gowanus Canal
abstract: Wandering the neighborhood at night, the photographer Miska Draskoczy found life abounding: green plants pushing up through broken pavement, vines reclaiming graffiti-marked walls, trees throwing bucolic shade over drive-by garbage heaps.
lead_paragraph: A tree grows in Brooklyn, a rose grows in Spanish Harlem, a developer follows with seven-figure condos — are there any forces in New York more eternally indestructible than nature and gentrification? The photographer Miska Draskoczy became fascinated with this cycle of destruction and rebirth after moving near the Gowanus Canal in 2008, two years before the canal was named a Superfund site, requiring $506 million to clean up. Wandering the neighborhood at night, when the streets emptied of people, he found life abounding: green plants pushing up through broken pavement, vines reclaiming graffiti-marked walls, trees throwing bucolic shade over drive-by garbage heaps. One night, pushing through dense foliage at the dead end of Huntington Street, he spied a snowy egret perched on a branch, staring out over a motionless canal.

headline: Greece’s Sorry Reckoning
abstract: A lot more is at stake than the only stable currency the nation has had in a history punctuated by bankruptcies.
lead_paragraph: FALIRON BAY, Greece — THE sea, as I look from my office window, is calm. Little white sailboats glide over silver waters in the Saronic Gulf. A picture of peace, but the scene of countless battles. In these waters, at Salamis, an alliance of free Greek states under Athens’s leadership defeated the Persian navy in 480 B.C., giving democracy room to develop. In 1941, as German forces swept into the country, a handful of allied airmen tried to stop black waves of enemy planes, with many pilots plunging to their deaths in the bay one April day.

headline: 1915: Sinking Provokes Italians
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The sinking of an Italian ship gave rise to anti-German sentiment.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The news of the sinking of the Italian barque Sardomene by a German submarine, off the south-east coast of Ireland, near Bantry Bay, has aroused deep indignation among all classes throughout Italy. Everyone is asking whether this is intended as a means of provoking the declaration of war that Germany refuses to make, while all the time she is transferring Bavarian troops to the Italian frontier and keeping the Swiss frontiers closed, in order to conceal these movements. If destruction of the Sardomene is really meant to goad Italy into declaring war, Germany could not have chosen anything better calculated to move Italian public opinion. Among the harrowing details of the sinking of this ship without notice, is the fact that two seamen were shot by the crew of the submarine as they were attempting to swim ashore. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 4, 1915

headline: 1965: Algerian Leader to Form Government
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The leader of a coup in Algeria promised to form a government.
lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — Algerian strongman Col. Houari Boumedienne today [July 4] reluctantly agreed to take over the task of forming a new government. He did so after apparently giving up his attempt to get another prominent figure to take over the job of president, which has been vacant since the Boumedienne-led coup ousted President Ahmed Ben Bella two weeks ago. An Information Ministry announcement said Col. Boumedienne would make an ‘‘important address’’ to the nation tomorrow — his first since the military coup. Tomorrow is the third anniversary of Algeria’s independence of France. It has been widely reported that he was engaged in talks with two of Mr. Ben Bella’s political opponents, Ferhat Abbas and Rabah Bitat, to serve in the presidency to a figurehead capacity, leaving him free to run the government from his old post as defense minister. These talks apparently collapsed. Meanwhile the council banned all independence anniversary parades and mass meetings tomorrow, apparently to guard against any possible demonstrations in favor of Mr. Ben Bella. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 4, 1965
