headline: Heroines Triumph at Box Office, but Has Anything Changed in Hollywood?
abstract: A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis on Hollywood’s recent spate of female-driven movies, from “Spy” to “Pitch Perfect 2” to “Inside Out.”
lead_paragraph: Has feminism conquered Hollywood? Has Hollywood co-opted feminism? Some recent female-driven hits and some vocal critics suggest that the entertainment industry’s status quo is under attack, at least in some quarters. While the Sony hacking scandal last year revealed what certain power players really think about women, more and more women and men in the industry — from Kathryn Bigelow to Mark Ruffalo and Margaret Cho — are speaking out against discrimination. Whether emboldened by the hacking, by exasperated fans, media attention, legal threats or just one another, these critics — and the box office — may signal that real change is upon us, even during that seasonal playground for boys and men called summer.

headline: The Art of Thinking Inside the Box
abstract: On the eve of a major survey of Joseph Cornell’s work, a look at three contemporary artists who turn little objects into whimsical tableaux.
lead_paragraph: In his mind’s eye, the American artist Joseph Cornell traveled the European continent without ever leaving his Queens apartment. “He was an armchair voyager,” says Sarah Lea, the curator of a major survey of his work, “Joseph Cornell: Wanderlust,” opening at the Royal Academy in London tomorrow. “Europe was not just a source of inspiration for him, it was a long-distance love affair that sparked a wanderlust of the mind.” The former textile salesman’s imaginary travels began in Manhattan junk stores, where he amassed the vintage maps, travel guides, toys and ephemera that were the building blocks of his surrealist assemblages. Cornell’s found-object aesthetic — which pays tribute to his many interests, from vaudeville to Renaissance art to his beloved prima ballerinas — remains influential. Here, we round up three contemporary box artists whose work, like Cornell’s, is the product of a life of collecting.

lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — When Universal Studios opened its back lot to tourists in 1964, it was one of Hollywood’s biggest wows. For the first time, swarms of everyday people, riding in candy-striped GlamorTrams, could come face to face with filmmaking.

headline: Obama’s Eulogy, Which Found Its Place in History
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: The president’s speech at the funeral of the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney was not just eloquent but remarkable in how it fit a mass shooting into a discussion of race and justice.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama’s eulogy for the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney of the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., was remarkable not only because the president sang the opening refrain of “Amazing Grace” on live television, and not only because of his eloquence in memorializing the pastor and eight other parishioners killed by a white gunman. It was also remarkable because the eulogy drew on all of Mr. Obama’s gifts of language and empathy and searching intellect — first glimpsed in “Dreams From My Father,” his deeply felt 1995 memoir about identity and family. And because it used those gifts to talk about the complexities of race and justice, situating them within an echoing continuum in time that reflected both Mr. Obama’s own long view of history, and the panoramic vision of America, shared by Abraham Lincoln and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., as a country in the process of perfecting itself.

headline: ‘Collecting Paradise’ at the Rubin: A Curious Case of Divergence
abstract: An exhibition on Buddhist art in Kashmir that traveled from one museum to another raises the issue of omissions.
lead_paragraph: When art exhibitions travel from one museum to another, as they often do, their main themes usually don’t change very much. A show might be tweaked by different institutions, but the core set of objects and ideas put together by the originating curators ordinarily remains the same. “Collecting Paradise: Buddhist Art of Kashmir and Its Legacies,” a show at the Rubin Museum of Art in Manhattan, is a curious case of divergence from that custom, and it’s one that hinges on some currently momentous issues for museums and their holdings.

headline: Mindful of Greece, Ukraine Is in a Rush to Line Up Debt Relief
abstract: In a bid to avoid continuous negotiations with creditors, the Ukrainian government (with the I.M.F.’s support) is deep in debt talks, pressing investors to accept a bailout deal — but investors are resistant.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Nobody knows how the endless dispute will play out between Athens and the European leaders who hold its purse strings. But in Kiev, another European capital in the grip of debt talks, one thing is certain: The Ukrainian government does not want to end up like Greece, squabbling with creditors for years.

headline: Calls to Oust Ecuador’s President Flare Before Visit by the Pope
abstract: Ecuador’s government and opposition have both been using Francis’ imminent arrival to get their messages across, spurring complaints that a historic event is being politicized.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — Protesters calling for the ouster of President Rafael Correa have filled the streets of Ecuador’s largest cities in recent weeks in some of the largest antigovernment demonstrations here in years, creating tensions on the eve of a visit by Pope Francis.

headline: Liberia: 200 Reportedly Had Contact With Ebola Victim
abstract: The World Health Organization reported Friday that nearly 200 people had been in contact with a 17-year-old in Liberia who was confirmed to have died of Ebola.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization reported Friday that nearly 200 people had been in contact with a 17-year-old in Liberia who was confirmed to have died of Ebola on June 28, the country’s first Ebola case since May 9, when it had been officially declared free of the highly contagious disease. In an assessment posted on its website, the W.H.O. said that all of the contacts of the teenager were being closely monitored and that two of them had already tested positive for the virus, confirming what the Liberian health authorities had reported this week. The organization also said it was dispatching epidemiologists and other specialists to ensure that the victim’s hometown “is fully involved in identifying contacts and preventing any further disease spread.”

headline: An American Tip to German Spies Points to a More Complex Relationship

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In the summer of 2011, American intelligence agencies spied on a senior German official who they concluded had been the likely source of classified information being leaked to the news media.

lead_paragraph: John R. Whitman, an investment banker and the husband of former Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey, died on Thursday in Morristown, N.J. He was 71.

headline: Medical Mysteries of the Heart
abstract: Further study could help patients with coronary heart disease and their doctors overcome ingrained resistance to new medical approaches.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have made enormous gains in reducing deaths from coronary heart disease, the leading cause of heart attacks, but it is astonishing how much they still don’t know. That leaves patients and their doctors uncertain about the best way to fight a disease that is still the leading cause of death for both men and women in the United States.

Bush’s chief economist and was an architect of the big tax cuts in 2001, which favored the wealthy. He can be expected to weigh in on wage stagnation and income inequality, campaign issues that all the candidates, including Mr. Bush, have said they will address.

headline: Lawrence Herkimer, Grandfather of Modern Cheerleading, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Herkimer elevated cheerleading into an aspirational goal for generations of youths and a highly successful business for himself.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence R. Herkimer, who elevated cheerleading into an aspirational goal for generations of youths and a highly successful business for himself, organizing camps for would-be cheerleaders and selling the clothing and gear they would need, died on Wednesday in Dallas. He was 89.

headline: Survivor of ’05 London Subway Attack Is on Antiterror Mission
abstract: Gill Hicks, who lost her legs in a bombing and now runs a counterextremism group, says people must learn empathy with terrorists to learn how to defeat them.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For a moment, after a suicide bomb ripped off both her legs, Gill Hicks thought she had died. It took an hour for emergency medical workers to make it to the deepest tunnel of the London subway, and she drifted in and out of consciousness. But she remembers vividly finding a label on her wrist in the hospital: “One unknown, estimated female.”

headline: Billionaires to the Barricades
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Minimum Wage', 'Philanthropy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Some of the world’s wealthiest are publicly addressing the gap between the working class and the 1 percent.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this month, when the billionaire merchandising mogul Johann Rupert gave a speech at The Financial Times’s “luxury summit” in Monaco, he sounded more like a Marxist theoretician than someone who made his fortune selling Cartier diamonds and Montblanc pens. Appearing before a crowd of executives from Fendi and Ferrari, Mr. Rupert argued that it wasn’t right — or even good business — for “the 0.1 percent of the 0.1 percent” to raid the world’s spoils. “It’s unfair and it is not sustainable,” he said.

headline: Facing a Selfie Election, Presidential Hopefuls Grin and Bear It

lead_paragraph: I FOLLOW a lovely blog called “There Is a River,” written by a young Christian evangelical named Christie Purifoy, whom I knew when we both lived in Chicago. She lives now in an old brick farmhouse in southeastern Pennsylvania. She writes about the changes in the seasons: the sudden spring flowering of her big magnolia, the last of the tomatoes. What I find moving about her words is how hard she works to adapt to the imperfections of the world, and the way she interprets disappointment as compost: “Some beginnings are brown. There is nothing fresh or new about them.” This insistent recasting of the negative as positive, of suffering as love, marks the writing, to my mind, as Christian.

And by dive bar I do not mean a New York “dive bar,” which is more like a dive-themed bar with sexy barmaids and a video hunting game and $5 Pabst Blue Ribbon drafts — I mean an actual dive bar, with skanky patrons and pop country on the jukebox and cases of Miller High Life takeout at last call, a place where you might, on occasion, get punched in the face for no reason at all.

headline: The Supreme Court and the Politics of Fear

abstract: A backlash led by the G.O.P. would be a mistake. What’s to fear? A married same-sex couple with affordable insurance?
lead_paragraph: WHEN he ran for president the second time almost half a century ago, Richard M. Nixon made Earl Warren’s Supreme Court a target of his campaign. It was a brilliant move. His accusation that the court had tilted “too far in weakening the peace forces against the criminal forces,” as he put it in a widely noticed 1967 Reader’s Digest article, resonated with a public that had seen the crime rate double since 1960. It was no longer acceptable, at least in polite circles outside the South, to denounce the Supreme Court explicitly on race, so Nixon’s dark warnings about a breakdown in public order (the article was entitled “What Has Happened to America?”) served double duty. Fear was in the air, fear that Nixon and his henchmen (Patrick J. Buchanan was the article’s ghost writer) knew how to exploit.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (TMC) BABEL (2006) The director Alejandro González Iñárritu and the screenwriter Guillermo Arriaga weave together four stories, set in Morocco, Tokyo, Mexico and the United States and told in several languages, to create a tapestry of misunderstandings. The cast of this Oscar nominee for best picture includes Brad Pitt, above, and Cate Blanchett as an American couple trying to move beyond the death of their infant son; Adriana Barraza as their housekeeper; Gael García Bernal as a reckless nephew; and Rinko Kikuchi as a deaf teenage girl. “On paper, very little of it makes sense, but what is on screen has an almost physical impact,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “In the end ‘Babel,’ like that tower in the Book of Genesis, is a grand wreck, an incomplete monument to its own limitless ambition. But it is there, on the landscape, a startling and imposing reality. It’s a folly, and also, perversely, a wonder.”

headline: 1915: Swiss Neutrality Rules
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: New regulations were announced in Berne to preserve Swiss neutrality in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Swiss Government’s new regulations for the preservation of neutrality come into force on July 15. According to a Berne message, they provide that anyone who, by written or spoken words or pictorial illustration, slanders or publicly belittles a foreign nation, its ruler, or government, is liable to imprisonment not exceeding six months, or a fine not exceeding forty pounds, or both together. The Federal Council will decide when a prosecution is necessary, and the trial will be conducted before the Federal Court and not a military tribunal. The new regulations will have the effect of removing the censorship, except for military news, from the hands of the military authorities. The press censorship in future will be entrusted to a special Censorship Committee, some members of which are journalists. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 6, 1915

headline: Meanwhile In China
abstract: Bubble bursting in the Middle Kingdom?
lead_paragraph: I am, of course, anxiously awaiting the results of Greferendum, although the next few days in Greece will be terrible whoever wins. Some of us have been worrying quite a lot about China — an economy that at market exchange rates is 40 times the size of Greece, and is severely unbalanced. And in the past month, mainly in the past few days, the Shanghai stock index has fallen almost 30 percent. This doesn’t necessarily mean that the feared crisis has come, but it’s definitely not a good sign.

lead_paragraph: Until this summer, the Argentine ballerina Marianela Nuñez has scarcely been known in New York whereas for more than 10 years she’s been one of the Royal Ballet’s most beloved ballerinas. Suddenly, however, New York has seen her in three dissimilar roles. In the Royal’s weeklong season at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center (it ended on June 28), she danced the heroine of Kenneth MacMillan’s “Song of the Earth” and the pas de deux of Christopher Wheeldon’s “Aeternum” (created for her in 2013). Those roles are serious and heroic, but on Thursday, when she made her debut with American Ballet Theater in the title role of Frederick Ashton’s “Cinderella” — the Metropolitan Opera House was packed — her qualities of humanity and radiance were abundantly apparent.

Competitive croquet also does not include the tactical spitefulness of stepping on one ball while sending an opponent’s ball flying into backyard shrubbery, as in the 1988 dark comedy “Heathers.”

And they knew that any Soviet citizen caught spying faced certain execution. Still, there were rules.

abstract: Approved for noncommercial recording by the Grateful Dead, tapers are a now-fading subculture within a subculture, recording shows and sharing with an evangelical following.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Between his first Grateful Dead show in 1988, at the age of 15, and the death of Jerry Garcia in 1995, William Walker saw the band about 130 times, a modest number in the Deadhead universe. But Mr. Walker has experienced many, many more of the band’s concerts through his passion for live audience taping, collecting thousands of cassettes and terabytes-worth of digital audio, while also contributing his own recordings to the seemingly endless archive.

headline: Meek Mill Is Loudly Reflective on His Second Album, ‘Dreams Worth More Than Money’
abstract: On much of his latest album, Meek Mill, the shoutiest rapper since Ludacris, sounds as if he urgently needs to tell you something.
lead_paragraph: The first 90 seconds of Meek Mill’s 2012 debut album, “Dreams and Nightmares,” are placid — no drums, just piano and strings. He’s rapping crisply atop them, contemplative but not preachy. The build begins. The beat drops. He goes from speaking to shouting. The effect is that of a missile strike on a rural pond. It’s one of the great triumphant moments in recent pop, and it suggested that for every time Meek Mill was wielding his words like a billy club, there was a meditation just underneath.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:55 A.M. (FXM) THREE CAME HOME (1950) Claudette Colbert stars as Agnes Newton Keith, an American writer living with her British husband (Patric Knowles) and 4-year-old son (Mark Keuning) in colonial comfort in 1942 North Borneo, in this adaptation of Ms. Keith’s memoir. Then Japanese soldiers attack Pearl Harbor, and Agnes and her child are taken to a prisoner-of-war camp. Sessue Hayakawa, the silent-film actor, plays the Japanese officer who, despite his cruel treatment of other captives, befriends Ms. Keith out of admiration for her literary talents — even while failing to save her from torture. “Played against realistic settings, which vividly convey the meanness of the jungle prisons, and directed by Jean Negulesco for physical and emotional credibility, ‘Three Came Home’ is a comprehensive film,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times. “It will shock you, disturb you, tear your heart out. But it will fill you fully with a great respect for a heroic soul.”

The deal will make available for purchase English-language versions of more than 150 French series and graphic novels. (In France, comics are called bandes dessinées — “drawn strips.”) Three monthly series will have their premiere on Monday: “Proméethée,” a science fiction tale about strange phenomena that occurs daily for 13 days at 1:13 p.m.; “Spin Angels,” about a special-ops group with ties to the Roman Catholic Church; and “The Curse of the Wendigo,” about opposing soldiers during World War I who must temporarily unite against an evil creature. Prices for the Delcourt Group titles begin at $2.99 for stand-alone issues.

They were the first large group of thousands of English children who will be brought to Canada and the United States for the duration of the war. The children in this group were not refugees in the grimmer sense of the word. headline: Michael B. Oren’s ‘Ally: My Journey Across the American-Israeli Divide’
abstract: “Ally” is a remarkably frank new memoir by the former Israeli ambassador to the United States and current Knesset member Michael B. Oren.
lead_paragraph: When Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited Washington in July 2010, he met with representatives of the National Jewish Democratic Council and the Republican Jewish Coalition at Blair House. After the two delegations quietly entered the dimly lit brocaded dining room, they sat down at a large elliptical table, the Democrats to Netanyahu’s left and the Republicans to his right. But the calm was shattered as the Democrats and Republicans began shouting at each other and pounding the table until they were told to cool it. “The chastised representatives fell silent and finally acknowledged Netanyahu’s presence, but their near brawl demonstrated that Washington’s political schizophrenia also split American Jews” — or so the former Israeli ambassador to the United States and current Knesset member Michael B. Oren reports in his remarkably frank new memoir, “Ally.”

headline: ‘KL: A History of the Nazi Concentration Camps,’ by Nikolaus Wachsmann
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps']
abstract: A historian depicts the concentration camps where many of the Holocaust’s millions died.
lead_paragraph: Of an estimated 2.3 million prisoners who entered the hell of the Nazi concentration camps, over 1.7 million were killed, whether gassed or worked to their skeletal ends. Many went straight to their deaths, including about 870,000 Jews murdered on arrival and without registration at Auschwitz; others endured a slower annihilation, reduced to what Hannah Arendt called “ghastly marionettes with human faces.” Millions more were killed in other ways, but there were also survivors, and at the end of “KL: A History of the Nazi Concentration Camps,” his monumental study of the SS camps, Nikolaus Wachsmann focuses on one. His name is Moritz Choinowski, a Polish-born Jew detained by the Gestapo in 1939 in the German town of Magdeburg. By the time of his liberation on April 29, 1945, Choinow­ski has survived Buchenwald, Auschwitz, a slowly growing German camp called Gross-Rosen and finally Dachau, as well as the nightmarish forms of transportation between them. “Is this possible?” he sobs in the Dachau infirmary. headline: ‘Among the Ten Thousand Things,’ by Julia Pierpont
abstract: A husband’s affair, cruelly revealed, leaves his family’s future uncertain.
lead_paragraph: In some cases, the key to the success of a longstanding marriage may not be in its well-kept secrets but in its tacit agreements. Many a promiscuous spouse has been allowed room to roam as long as his or her dalliances aren’t flaunted. I remember reading an interview with Magic Johnson’s wife, Cookie, in this very newspaper in May 1996, five years after he was told he had been infected with H.I.V. When she came to Los Angeles to visit, “he always respected me,” she said. “It’s not that I thought he was a saint. But I didn’t know what was happening, and I preferred it that way.” If a marriage is sufficiently loving (as the Johnsons’ apparently still is) or satisfying or economically advantageous, maybe it isn’t worth blowing up if the person being betrayed is given the opportunity to turn a blind eye.

headline: What Are the Limits of ‘Religious Liberty’?
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'English Language', 'Discrimination', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The law has always made room for the needs of believers, but lately doctrine is being invoked to justify intolerance.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘I can’t. It’s against my religion.’’ Americans tend to handle religious objections with care, personally and politically. When a guest says, for example, that he can’t eat the food being served because it’s not kosher or halal, the host usually hastens to find an alternative. And when people resist following a law on the basis of faith, the government and the courts may try to accommodate them. It’s an American legacy that dates back to before the founding, when some of the original colonies were set up as havens for religious dissenters. Under the banner of belief, Quakers and Mennonites in the 18th century won the right not to join state militias. The first conscientious objectors were religious objectors, and from there, the category expanded to include moral opponents of war. The same pattern holds for home-schoolers. It was an Amish father, not a hippie mother, who first got the Supreme Court’s permission to take his children out of school in 1972, based on his religious commitment to ‘‘life aloof from the world,’’ as the justices respectfully put it.

headline: Unstarched Shirt
abstract: The polo used to be part of a preppy uniform. But as it shed its Ivy League lineage, its meaning became elastic.
lead_paragraph: In 1925, when René Lacoste won both the French Championships and Wimbledon, he wore a starched white shirt with buttons extending all the way down the front and sleeves reaching to the wrists. In 1926, he won the United States National Championship wearing the same shirt but with its sleeves cut short: a daring evolutionary step toward an archetype of sportswear. In 1933, Lacoste went into business with a knitwear manufacturer to mass-produce la chemise Lacoste, a short-sleeved pullover with a turndown collar, three buttons on its placket and a breathable piqué-cotton body. Ads extolled its suitability not just for le tennis and le golf but also for la plage (the beach): not just for athletic exertion but for general leisure. The shirt was not rigid, but there was a rectitude to it. It promoted physical comfort while adhering to social strictures. The line from there to casual Friday runs fairly straight.

headline: 1890: Husband Poisoners Convicted
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Hungarian women who poisoned their husbands are convicted in 1890.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The Assize Court of Mitrowitz, in Hungary, yesterday [July 6] concluded its trial of ten peasant women arraigned for poisoning their husbands. Four of the prisoners were sentenced to death, one to penal servitude for life, three to fifteen years’ penal servitude, and two were acquitted. The evidence disclosed that the murderesses acted with the most cold-blooded premeditation; nor were their crimes extenuated in any way by ill treatment received at their husbands’ hands. On the contrary, the husbands seem to have been good fellows, and it does not appear that their wives cherished any strong animosity against them. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 8, 1890

lead_paragraph: We’ve seen everything from a supermarket to a brasserie; and today, Karl Lagerfeld upped the ante by turning Chanel’s fall 2015 couture show into a giant, bustling casino. As guests entered Paris’s Grand Palais, they were greeted by the sight of Chanel-branded slot machines and roulette tables. When the show began, celebrities — including Julianne Moore, Kristen Stewart, Rita Ora, Lara Stone, Lily-Rose Depp and Vanessa Paradis — walked out in their best Chanel eveningwear, took a seat at the tables in the center of the room, and began to play roulette. And no one under the age of 15 is allowed to stay at the former 19th-century military fortress that in 2010 was converted to a privately owned 28-room hotel. (Given the catwalks over dry moats, private terraces perched on fortified ramparts, and steep roads descending to the rocky edge of the Mediterranean Sea, the rule is not entirely unwarranted.) Meticulously refurbished by the Spanish architect Antonio Obrador, what were once surveillance points are now three luxury suites called the Sentinels — private enclaves carved into the rocks, complete with their own plunge pools, which opened in June. The military drills have been replaced with a burgeoning breakfast of fresh bread, fruit and eggs, delivered to each room in large wicker baskets. headline: Classical Playlist: Lewis Spratlan, Beethoven and Brahms
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: LEWIS SPRATLAN: ‘Hesperus Is Phosphorus’ The Crossing; Network for New Music; Donald Nally, conductor(Innova)Born in 1940, Lewis Spratlan came to international attention in 2000 when a concert performance of Act II of his 1970s opera “Life Is a Dream” won the Pulitzer Prize for Music before the full work had ever been staged. That complex and compelling opera was finally given its premiere in Santa Fe in 2010. This recording offers his 2012 vespers cantata, “Hesperus Is Phosphorus,” performed by the Philadelphia forces that commissioned it: the Crossing, the superb contemporary-music vocal ensemble, and Network for New Music. The title plays on the belief of the early Greeks that Phosphorus was the morning star, and Hesperus the evening one, before they realized that the two were one celestial body, Venus. The inventive text draws together writings by David Eagleman, Wallace Stevens, Richard Feynman, Wallace Shawn and others. Mr. Spratlan’s pungently modern language comes through continually in this intricate 65-minute score. Still, he sets words for clarity, often in long stretches of spiky block chords. A beautiful recording of a sensual and mysterious work. (ANTHONY TOMMASINI)

headline: Argentina: Top Court Rules for Family of Patient in a Right-to-Die Case
keywords: ['Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Argentina’s Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that Marcelo Diez, who has required life support for two decades, can be allowed to die.
lead_paragraph: In a landmark decision, Argentina’s Supreme Court ruled  Tuesday that a patient who has required life support for two decades can be allowed to die, renewing debate here over a so-called death with dignity law. In their ruling, the justices  fended off resistance against  a measure approved in 2012 by lawmakers that allows patients, or their relatives, to refuse life support.  The patient, Marcelo Diez, who is reported to be around 50, has been in a vegetative state since a motorcycle crash in 1994. Mr. Diez’s sisters asked that life support be removed, but officials in Neuquén Province objected and used his case to challenge the 2012 measure. In a television interview, Lucas Pica, their lawyer, criticized figures in the Catholic Church who he said had resisted their moves in the courts.

headline: Spike Nation
abstract: Cheap, unpredictable and hard to regulate, synthetic marijuana has emergency responders scrambling to save lives.
lead_paragraph: One evening in April, Ethan Darbee, a 24-year-old paramedic in Syracuse, responded to a call on the city’s south side: unknown man down. Rolling up to the scene, he saw a figure lying motionless on the sidewalk. Darbee raked his knuckles across the man’s sternum to assess his level of consciousness. His eyelids fluttered. Inside the ambulance, Darbee hooked him up to a heart monitor, and he jerked involuntarily. The odd reaction puzzled Darbee. Why would the guy recoil from an electrode sticker but not a sternal rub? The driver started for the hospital. Darbee sat in the captain’s chair in the back of the rig, typing on a laptop. Then he heard a sound no paramedic ever wants to hear: the click of a patient’s shoulder harness unlatching. Swiveling around, he found himself eyeball to eyeball with his patient, who was now crouched on all fours on top of the stretcher, growling.

headline: Should I Respond to My Mechanic’s Racist Poster?
abstract: The Ethicists consider when and how to call out another person’s prejudice.

It proclaims to picture the most useful cellphone to have with you — a handgun that has a cellphone keypad in its handle. It then names the cities where this might be useful, naming cities that are primarily African-American. The owner is a nice guy and not a virulent racist; he probably does not realize that the poster is offensive, or why it is overtly racist. How should I respond? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Buly 1803, the Best of Old-World Beauty

It’s a nod to the brand’s history, which the couple — who have also been behind the success of Cire Trudon candles — invokes with their new line of exquisite all-natural beauty products. Nail polishes, for instance, are colored with chemical-free resins, while luxurious shaving cream is accompanied by a pamphlet from the 1800s on the art of grooming. headline: Berbers and Arabs Clash in Algeria, Leaving at Least 18 Dead
abstract: The unrest stems from longstanding disputes between the native Berbers and Arab settlers over land and housing.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — At least 18 people have been killed in clashes between Berbers and Arabs in several desert towns in Algeria this week, the Algerian news media reported on Wednesday. Several buildings were burned and one police officer was wounded in clashes on Monday and Tuesday. Longstanding disputes between the native Berbers and Arab settlers over land and housing in the eastern province of Ghardaia turned violent two years ago, and the government has struggled to contain the continuing unrest. The latest casualties occurred even after the arrival of police reinforcements and a visit by Interior Minister Nourreddine Bedoui to the town of Ghardaia a week ago.

headline: 36 Hours in Vilnius, Lithuania
abstract: Much of Vilnius still retains its bleak Soviet-era sprawl, but it’s a city in transition that is often heralded as one of the cheapest in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the historic districts of its Baltic siblings Tallinn and Riga, which often seem solely the dominion of tourists and kitschy souvenir stands, the Baroque Old Town of Lithuania’s capital seems to attract as many — if not more — locals as visitors to its sinuous lanes. With streets lined with Burberry and Max Mara outposts as well as boutiques by Lithuanian designers, the charming 13th-century historic center labyrinth flows seamlessly into the newer boulevards, and remains a deeply integrated part of the local fabric. Much of Vilnius retains its bleak Soviet-era sprawl, which you’ll pass on the 10-minute drive from the airport, but it’s a city in transition — and with Lithuania’s adoption of the euro this year, expect the city that’s often heralded as one of the cheapest in Europe to become even more accessible to travelers. If you’re in town from Sept. 4 to 6, join the locals to celebrate the end of summer with Sostines Dienos, the Vilnius City Fiesta — when open-air concerts pop up across the city, and the Gedimino Prospektas boulevard transforms into a street market.

Mr. Lecesne is both a virtuoso performer and a bighearted writer (he adapted the play from his young-adult novel); bravo to the producers who’ve brought back this emotionally stirring production, which had a brief engagement at Dixon Place earlier this year, for a longer run. headline: Painted Hair Pops Up at Haute Couture

lead_paragraph: Barely touched ponytails on runways may, finally, be a thing of the past: The Haute Couture shows in Paris this week have featured painted hairstyles of every color and stripe. At Schiaparelli’s show on Monday — which marked Bertrand Guyon’s debut as creative director — the hair master Odile Gilbert painted gold flecks in models’ hair, which she then twisted into updos. For his outing, Giambattista Valli — who also celebrated his 10-year collaboration with MAC Cosmetics this week— opted for a distinctly punky vibe: Models wore their hair in low, orange ponytails, which looked like they had been spray-painted minutes before the show. Finally, at Maison Margiela, each model came down the runway with a distinct hair look: Molly Bair, who opened the show, wore a chalky white handprint on the side of her head, while another model came out wearing a hand-painted vine that snaked from collarbone to updo.

Increasingly, something similar seems to be happening with technical failures: If an important computer system goes down somewhere, many people suspect that it was the result of a hacking attack that originated in China, Russia or North Korea.

headline: Guy Yanai’s Thoroughly Modern Ancient Paintings
abstract: The artist’s highly pixelated depictions of everyday life simultaneously evoke the digital era and needlepoint.
lead_paragraph: The young Israeli artist Guy Yanai is obsessed with borders — the way the paint touches the edge of a canvas; the liminal spaces between people and between people and places. “The show is really about edges between many things,” he says of his solo exhibition “Ancienne Rive,” which opens tomorrow at the Chelsea gallery Ameringer McEnery Yohe. Like much of his previous work, the 15 new paintings Yanai created for this show convey the everyday: sailboats, the sea, plants, a quiet lawn and a horseback rider are meticulously painted in vibrant horizontal stripes. “It’s not really clear where they are, or what space they are,” says Yanai. “They’re nowhere, and in that sense it’s really a very synthetic kind of work.”

headline: Why Is the Federal Government Afraid of Fat?
keywords: ['Oils and Fats', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Obesity', 'Carbohydrates', 'Food', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Research']
abstract: Despite a growing body of evidence in favor of fat in our diets, government policy continues to press against it.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — SINCE the publication of the federal government’s 1980 Dietary Guidelines, dietary policy has focused on reducing total fat in the American diet — specifically, to no more than 30 percent of a person’s daily calories. This fear of fat has had far-reaching impacts, from consumer preferences to the billions of dollars spent by the military, government-run hospitals and school districts on food. As we argue in a recently published article in The Journal of the American Medical Association, 35 years after that policy shift, it’s long past time for us to exonerate dietary fat.

headline: Joshua Oppenheimer Won’t Go Back to Indonesia
keywords: ['Movies', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The filmmaker on the risks he took to confront the perpetrators of genocide.
lead_paragraph: Your first film, ‘‘The Act of Killing,’’ was a portrait of the perpetrators of the 1965 Indonesian genocide, in which perhaps a million people suspected of being Communists were killed. In your new film, ‘‘The Look of Silence,’’ you focus on the murder of a single victim, Ramli Rukun. What made his killing stand out? Ramli’s murder had witnesses. Tens of thousands of others in that region were taken to rivers and killed, their bodies left to drift out to sea. Ramli’s body was dumped on an oil-palm plantation. For survivors, talking about Ramli was a way of insisting that the genocide had actually happened.

headline: 1915: Germans Capitulate in Africa
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Germany fails in South-West Africa in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An official telegram received from Pretoria to-day [July 9] announces that General Botha has accepted the capitulation of the whole of the German forces in German South-West Africa. This triumphal end of General Botha’s masterly campaign against the German forces had been expected for some days, owing to the rapid progress of General Botha’s troops in Damaraland. A despatch received from Cape Town yesterday stated that the capture of 750 Germans and their guns represented only the first results of General Botha’s masterly enveloping movement, which is paralyzing the Germans and has entirely frustrated any attempt at scattered guerrilla warfare. The end is believed to be near. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 10, 1915

headline: Sonya Tayeh Strides Into New York’s Dance World With ‘The Wild Party’
abstract: The choreographer, who is a fan favorite on “So You Think You Can Dance,” is bringing her combative style to New York theater and concert dance.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Sonya Tayeh had been working in Los Angeles for six months, when she presented her agent with a career wish list. It said: “I want to do a musical like ‘Spring Awakening.’ I want a career like Bill T. Jones” — that show’s Tony Award-winning choreographer and a pillar of the modern dance scene. And the list ended: “I want to be on ‘So You Think You Can Dance.’ ” Her agent, she recalled recently, was “looking at me like I was crazy.” Choreographers pursuing a career in Hollywood might also have Broadway aspirations, but few dream of making a mark in concert dance, too, with its different aesthetics and audiences, not to mention its smaller paychecks.

headline: Review: Missing Sneaker Culture at the Brooklyn Museum

You might be amused to find examples of some you have actually owned in “The Rise of Sneaker Culture” at the Brooklyn Museum, a nostalgically affecting but intellectually lightweight show. As a kid in the early ’60s, I wore PF Flyers like the ones in the exhibition. The distinctively blue and yellow Nike Waffle Trainers with wafflelike treads introduced in 1974? I had a pair of those, too.

lead_paragraph: A look at films where characters end up in bodies different from their original ones.

headline: Taliban Were Authorized to Talk, Afghan Envoys Say
abstract: The comments by members of the Afghan delegation added to speculation that there was a widening rift among the Taliban’s leadership over the peace process.
lead_paragraph: Rejecting claims that they had met with an unauthorized Taliban delegation, Afghan government envoys said on Thursday that the insurgents they held initial talks with in Pakistan this week had the blessing of the Taliban’s deputy leader, Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour.

headline: Crash Forces Leader, Tony Martin, Out of Tour de France
abstract: For the second time in this year’s race, the holder of the leader’s yellow jersey was forced to abandon the race after being seriously injured in a crash.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For the second time in this year’s Tour de France, and after less than a week of racing, the holder of the leader’s yellow jersey was forced to abandon the race after being seriously injured in a crash.

headline: Joint Chiefs Nominee Warns of Threat of Russian Aggression
abstract: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., at his Senate confirmation hearing, pointed to the Russian government’s aggressive behavior and its nuclear arsenal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia’s aggressive behavior and its nuclear arsenal make it the single greatest national security threat faced by the United States, Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr. said Thursday at a Senate hearing on his nomination as the next chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

headline: Invoking Charleston Victims in Confederate Flag Debate
abstract: Representative Wendell G. Gilliard on Wednesday invoked the victims of the Charleston, S.C., shooting as he made a plea for the removal of the confederate battle flag from the State House grounds.
lead_paragraph: Representative Wendell G. Gilliard on Wednesday invoked the victims of the Charleston, S.C., shooting as he made a plea for the removal of the confederate battle flag from the State House grounds.

headline: Kerry Says He Will Not Rush Iran Talks
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said on Thursday that he was not willing to rush nuclear talks with Iran, but that they could not go on forever without an agreement.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry said on Thursday that he was not willing to rush nuclear talks with Iran, but that they could not go on forever without an agreement.

headline: Russia’s Denial of Srebrenica Genocide
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: The veto of a United Nations resolution condemning the 1995 massacre of 8,000 Muslims as genocide is a cruel blow for victims’ families and the truth.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years after the massacre of more than 8,000 Muslim men and boys in the Bosnian town of Srebrenica, Russia has shamefully refused to call it what it is — genocide — adding to the pain of the victims’ families.

headline: Weighing the Fallout of a Greek Exit From the Euro
abstract: Economists are considering what will happen if Greece cannot reach a deal with its creditors and is forced to introduce some new form of money.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Bare store shelves and empty gas tanks. Hyperinflation. Riots in the streets.

headline: Uber Files Motion Opposing Driver Class-Action Suit
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The ride-hailing service asserts that the handful of drivers who filed the lawsuit on work status shouldn’t represent all the drivers.
lead_paragraph: In a counteroffensive filled with driver testimonials, expert witnesses and a highly produced video, Uber on Thursday filed a motion in a California court to oppose the certification of a class-action lawsuit that spotlights the work status of drivers for the ride-hailing service.

headline: When Algorithms Discriminate
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Online Advertising', 'Search Engines']
abstract: Recent research has shown how some websites can produce results that perpetuate bias.
lead_paragraph: The online world is shaped by forces beyond our control, determining the stories we read on Facebook, the people we meet on OkCupid and the search results we see on Google. Big data is used to make decisions about health care, employment, housing, education and policing.

headline: Women’s Pro League Seeks a Bump From U.S. World Cup Success
abstract: Most of the U.S. women’s soccer team players also play in the three-year-old National Women’s Soccer League, which hopes to benefit from their popularity.
lead_paragraph: The United States women’s soccer team won the World Cup on Sunday before 53,000 fans in Vancouver, British Columbia, and a domestic television audience of 26.7 million people. On Friday, the players will be celebrated in a ticker-tape parade down the Canyon of Heroes in Lower Manhattan, as the Yankees, the Mets and John Glenn were before them. And next month the team will begin a 10-game victory tour with an exhibition against Costa Rica at Heinz Field in Pittsburgh, home to the N.F.L.’s Steelers.

headline: Aaron Tveit To Star in TV Production of ‘Grease’
abstract: Mr. Tveit will play Danny Zuko opposite Julianne Hough as Sandy in the musical.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Tveit is the one that they want.

headline: Austrian Rieslings Set a High, Dry Standard
abstract: The country’s rieslings can be a good deal richer than dry German rieslings, while often steelier and more finely cut than those from Alsace.
lead_paragraph: Riesling nowadays comes from all corners of the wine-producing earth. And happily, unlike grapes that have achieved international popularity, like sauvignon blanc, chardonnay and cabernet sauvignon, riesling has rarely been criticized for generic homogeneity.

headline: In an Indifferent Toronto, the Pan-Am Games Land With a Thud
abstract: Most in Toronto seem to be greeting the event with a shrug, and Mayor John Tory is so exasperated that he has begun lecturing them about their attitude.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The new mayor is excited about his city’s big moment in the spotlight, but hardly anyone else seems to be.

headline: Calling Off the Credit-Card Debt Collectors
abstract: JP Morgan Chase is facing millions in penalties for illegal collection practices that damaged customers’ lives.
lead_paragraph: For years, consumer advocates have warned of abuse, deception and unfairness in credit-card debt collections by banks and third-party debt collectors.

headline: Review: In ‘Between the World and Me,’ Ta-Nehisi Coates Delivers a Searing Dispatch to His Son
abstract: A father tells his teenage son what it means to be black in America.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by James Baldwin’s 1963 classic “The Fire Next Time,” Ta-Nehisi Coates’s new book, “Between the World and Me,” is a searing meditation on what it means to be black in America today. It takes the form of a letter from Mr. Coates to his 14-year-old son, Samori, and speaks of the perils of living in a country where unarmed black men and boys — Michael Brown, Tamir Rice, Eric Garner, Walter L. Scott, Freddie Gray — are dying at the hands of police officers, an America where just last month nine black worshipers were shot and killed in a Charleston, S.C., church by a young white man with apparent links to white supremacist groups online.

headline: China Institute Moving to Larger Home in Lower Manhattan
abstract: The institute plans to open in a new home at 100 Washington Street next year, designed by Pei Partnership Architects.
lead_paragraph: The China Institute — which calls itself the nation’s oldest educational institution devoted solely to Chinese culture — is moving to Lower Manhattan from the Upper East Side.

headline: China’s Stock Crash Raises New Fears
abstract: The government should be trying to strengthen the foundations of its economy and financial system.
lead_paragraph: The stock market crash in China is  a test of President Xi Jinping’s stated goal of reducing the government’s dominant role in the economy. So far, his government has reverted to its traditional command-and-control approach to financial matters.

headline: Presidential Fine China, With Patterns Reflecting America
abstract: White House china makes appearances in an upcoming lecture, private collections and a forthcoming auction.
lead_paragraph: American presidents have had such varied tastes in dinnerware that many have discarded their predecessors’ china in favor of their own commissions. Historians and collectors are painstakingly reuniting sets and unearthing provenance and design paperwork.

headline: House Democrats Debate Flag Bill
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: On Thursday, Democrats in the House of Representatives debated an amendment to a bill that would have allowed the Confederate battle flag in certain cemeteries. The vote was then cancelled.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Democrats in the House of Representatives debated an amendment to a bill that would have allowed the Confederate battle flag in certain cemeteries. The vote was then cancelled.

headline: Hacking of Government Computers Exposed 21.5 Million People
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Every person given a government background check for the last 15 years was probably affected, the Office of Personnel Management said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday revealed that 21.5 million people were swept up in a colossal breach of government computer systems that was far more damaging than initially thought, resulting in the theft of a vast trove of personal information, including Social Security numbers and some fingerprints.

headline: Review: In Tribute to Eva Cassidy, Rebekah Lowin Gives New Personality to Standards
abstract: Ms. Lowin’s show, “I Know You By Heart: the Songs of Eva Cassidy,” projected a similar aura as Ms. Cassidy while infusing a wistful authority into her lyrics.
lead_paragraph: A sad, preternatural wisdom emanated from the singer Eva Cassidy, who was only 33 when she died in 1996 from complications of melanoma. And on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Room, the 23-year-old Rebekah Lowin, who paid Cassidy tribute in her show “I Know You By Heart: the Songs of Eva Cassidy,” projected a similar aura of bittersweet, farsighted resignation.

headline: With CarPlay, Apple Looks to Upend Tradition
abstract: Apple’s proposal that automakers write apps for technology company software raises concerns about security and safety.
lead_paragraph: APPLE’S widely anticipated CarPlay software is making its mainstream debut this summer in models from Hyundai and Chevrolet, but Apple is already looking ahead to leverage its potential in a way that could turn the automotive industry’s current approach to connected cars on its head.

headline: Behind a Watch’s Elegant Face, Some Valuable Mechanisms
abstract: A watch’s movement, the elegant heart that keeps the hands rotating, can have a serious impact on the timepiece’s value.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, a new IWC Portuguese Chronograph in stainless steel retailed for $7,990. A year later, a very similar looking Portugieser Chronograph Classic was $12,700.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: Tennis, anyone? The cricket-obsessed English weren’t so sure at first, but they came around, as coverage of Wimbledon shows.
lead_paragraph: 133 YEARS AGO

headline: The Best Days of Our Lives
abstract: We danced at midnight in Venice, motored through Tuscany and made memories. Just as newlyweds should.
lead_paragraph: We danced at midnight in Venice, motored through Tuscany and made memories. Just as newlyweds should.

headline: Review: Paris Is Reborn in ‘Gustave Caillebotte: The Painter’s Eye’
abstract: This show at the National Gallery of Art features realistic paintings of 19th-century Paris being reconstructed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Flash on French Impressionism and you’re likely to see gauzy noon landscapes, or a steam-choked Gare Saint-Lazare, or just clouds of flickering paint strokes like molecules flying apart. Yet if you visited the Impressionist show in Paris in 1877, you would have found a few things that countered such expectations: realistic paintings of a new Paris of luxury high-rises as blank as mausoleums and of ruler-straight boulevards running back into infinite space.

headline: Celebrate Bastille Day: Take to the Streets Like It’s 1789
abstract: Mimes, cancan dancers, macarons and pétanque evoke France’s independence this weekend at various New York celebrations.
lead_paragraph: One summer day in 1789 nearly a thousand Parisians stormed a fortress and sparked a messy revolution that eventually brought us modern France — and Bastille Day.

headline: Ignoring Protests, Thailand Deports About 100 Uighurs Back to China
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Deportation', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Muslims and Islam', 'International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The country acted despite international warnings that the Uighurs could face harsh treatment in China and pleas that they be allowed to resettle elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Thailand has sent about 100 ethnic Uighurs back to China, the country they fled, a Thai government spokesman said on Thursday. Thailand acted despite international warnings that the Uighurs could face harsh treatment in China and pleas that they be allowed to resettle elsewhere.

headline: Janis and Gueorgui Pastujov: Togetherness Is a Balancing Act
abstract: The couple follow their hockey-playing sons.
lead_paragraph: When they were married on April 8, 1994, Janis Tardy and Gueorgui Pastujov (who appeared in a Vows column) were members of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus and living in a 6-foot by 6-foot compartment on the mile-long circus train. Their bed doubled as the dining room table and every other piece of furniture, too.

headline: Increasingly Visible, Cuba’s Elián González Champions Island’s Government
abstract: The government may be grooming Mr. González, who returned to Cuba from Florida in 2000, for a formal role.
lead_paragraph: His rescue by fishermen off the coast of Fort Lauderdale nearly 16 years ago touched off a custody battle that ensnarled the Clinton White House in the intense acrimony between Cuban exiles and the island’s Communist leaders.

headline: Yankees’ Brett Gardner Plays Like an All-Star, Then Learns He Is One
abstract: Gardner hit his 10th home run in the first inning and finished with two additional hits, as the Yankees won their final home game before the All-Star break.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees had scored two runs in the fourth inning to pull ahead of the Oakland Athletics, 4-2, on Thursday, and now the sun was starting to burst through the clouds in the top of the fifth, illuminating the grass at Yankee Stadium on which left fielder Brett Gardner stood, and hinting at more good news to come.

headline: Chinese Employee of German Weekly Is Freed After 9-Month Detention
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Zhang Miao was detained in Beijing last year after helping to report on pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. She was released Thursday without conditions, her lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Chinese news assistant for the influential German weekly Die Zeit was freed on Thursday, her lawyer said, nine months after the police in Beijing detained her after she had returned from helping to report on pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong.

headline: Perella Weinberg Hires a Senior Goldman Sachs Executive
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Bruce Mendelsohn, the head of restructuring for the Americas at Goldman Sachs, will join the boutique bank’s corporate bankruptcy advisory practice.
lead_paragraph: As Perella Weinberg Partners restocks its corporate bankruptcy advisory practice, the boutique investment bank has poached a senior executive from one of its larger rivals.

headline: Age Bias? Tell Us About It
keywords: ['Age, Chronological', 'Working Hours', 'Discrimination', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The Workologist invites readers to advise a person who suspects that age discrimination could be part of why a company never followed up after an interview.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: In a Theater, or Under a Tent
abstract: The evangelical movement in New York is driven, in large part, by immigrant-led churches that have proliferated outside Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The evangelical movement in New York is driven, in large part, by immigrant-led churches that have proliferated outside Manhattan.

headline: An Evangelical Revival in the Heart of New York
abstract: About 1,700 churches are part of a gathering on Central Park’s Great Lawn hosted by Luis Palau, a minister who has built a reputation as the Hispanic Billy Graham.
lead_paragraph: The sky-blue walls of the former Vaudeville theater thundered with faith on Sunday morning in Corona, Queens. Some 600 worshipers rose to join the Latino band in song, shaking their tambourines, heads and hands in electric rapture.

headline: South Carolina Governor Signs Flag Bill
abstract: Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina signed a bill into law on Thursday that orders the removal of the Confederate battle flag from the Capitol grounds.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina signed a bill into law on Thursday that orders the removal of the Confederate battle flag from the Capitol grounds.

headline: Carnegie Museum to Open a Survey of the Designer Peter Muller-Munk
abstract: The show, opening in November, will be the first survey of the designer, who died in 1967.
lead_paragraph: His “Normandie” pitcher is one of the prime examples of Art Deco streamlining, sleek as a funnel on that great steamliner and elegant as one of its staterooms. And yet Peter Muller-Munk himself, who designed it in 1935, has passed largely from view.

headline: Art That’s Made Not to Last
abstract: Several galleries are mounting exhibitions touching on impermanent art.
lead_paragraph: In an era when art is toppling gold and joining high-end real estate as a preferred instrument for storing wealth, ephemeral works tend to flummox the system. A piece that burns bright for a few weeks or months and then exists only in memory, or photographs?

headline: New Museum Names Triennial Curators
abstract: Gary Carrion-Murayari and Alex Gartenfeld will share responsibility for the 2018 show.
lead_paragraph: The New Museum’s triennial, which began in 2009 and wrapped up its third iteration in May, has established itself as a kind of energetically internationalist, youth-oriented answer to the Whitney Biennial — the triennial’s first show was made up of artists 33 or younger. For its next installation, the museum has chosen two curators (one of whom is over that age) who have become well known in the art world for covering a lot of ground in a short time. Gary Carrion-Murayari, 34, who has been a curator at the New Museum since 2010 and was co-curator of the Whitney Biennial that same year, will join Alex Gartenfeld, 28, the founding deputy director and chief curator at the Institute for Contemporary Art in Miami, to curate the show, which will open in 2018.

headline: Hold the Phone, It’s Patti LuPone
abstract: Ms. LuPone talks about taking away the cellphone of a texting audience member during a performance of “Shows for Days.”
lead_paragraph: For Patti LuPone, it was “the day from hell, all day.”

headline: Thompson Family Foundation to Give Park Avenue Armory $65 Million
abstract: Wade Thompson, who died in 2009, began devoting a sizable amount of his fortune in the 1990s to reviving the armory.
lead_paragraph: The New York City cultural landscape is mapped by the surnames of great patronage: Guggenheim, Whitney, Morgan, Frick, Cooper Hewitt and, more recently, Geffen, Koch and Bloomberg. Now the name of another donor seems likely to enter the lexicon: Wade Thompson. Mr. Thompson, who died in 2009, made his money by reviving the Airstream brand of shiny aluminum trailers, and in the 1990s, he began devoting a sizable amount of his fortune to reviving the grand but crumbling Park Avenue Armory, at 66th Street, which has transformed itself into a hangar-size stage for art, music and performance.

headline: Superheroes, Just for Each Other
abstract: I aspired to always be my wife’s rescuer until, in our darkest moment, she rescued me.
lead_paragraph: The first time I lifted her up and carried her away, I was acting on a whim, seeking an exit from a stupid but dangerous argument. Though we lived in the glittering center of Shanghai, we couldn’t agree on where to go for dinner.

headline: Why China’s Stock Market Bailout Just Might Work
abstract: Unlike Japan in the 1990s, China has the motivation and the resources that may make government intervention in the markets succeed.
lead_paragraph: Outside of China, the consensus among economists is overwhelming: The country’s efforts to prop up its plunging stock markets are doomed, the financial equivalent of King Canute trying to halt the incoming tide. But this being China, the conventional wisdom may turn out to be wrong.

headline: British Tourists Should Leave Tunisia, London Says
abstract: The government said on Thursday that a terrorist attack there in the country was “highly likely.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — All British travelers should leave Tunisia, the British government said Thursday, because a terrorist attack there is “highly likely.”

headline: When a Son Says ‘I Do,’ and the Parents Say They Don’t
abstract: Plus: an untimely golf invitation; aging gracefully; and a subtle food fight.
lead_paragraph: Our son started dating a college classmate three years ago. They are graduating in December and told us they will marry in May. Neither has a job, and we pay all of our son’s tuition and living expenses. We told him that we are happy he found that special person, but that they should be more practical: find jobs, save money, then get married. My husband reached out to the woman’s parents, who were horrified by our attitude. Still, we told our son we cannot give him our blessing and will not attend his wedding. Now, no one is speaking with us. Thoughts?

headline: Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia, Quiet Force in Middle East, Dies at 75
abstract: Prince Saud, who served for four decades as Saudi Arabia’s foreign minister, was known for his behind-the-scenes, conservative diplomacy in a time of major changes.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Prince Saud al-Faisal, the urbane diplomat who used quiet diplomacy to maintain Saudi Arabia’s regional influence and alliance with the United States during his four decades as foreign minister, died on Thursday, according to Saudi officials and state news media. He was 75.

headline: Theodore Roosevelt’s Sagamore Hill Home Cries ‘Bully!’
abstract: The house on Sagamore Hill, Theodore Roosevelt’s Long Island estate, is reopening with much fanfare after a $10 million restoration.
lead_paragraph: COVE NECK, N.Y. — The big house has been a pretty lonely place for a while now. It has been three and a half years since the public has been able to walk through Sagamore Hill, Theodore Roosevelt’s sprawling family home near Oyster Bay on the North Shore of Long Island. In December 2011 the doors closed, most of the artifacts were shipped out and crews of workers moved in for a $10 million restoration. Strollers on the grounds have been able to sit on its big front porch or press their noses to the windows, but the house itself has been locked up tight.

headline: Review: National Ballet of China Brings ‘Peony Pavilion’ to Lincoln Center
abstract: In its American debut, this Chinese production was performed by adept Chinese dancers, but there was not an aesthetically coherent and compelling ballet.
lead_paragraph: At the center of the Ming dynasty play “The Peony Pavilion” is a love story that advances through dreams and visions and across the boundaries between life and death. That’s a feature it has in common with Romantic ballets. On this commonality rests the hopes of the National Ballet of China’s 2008 production of “Peony Pavilion,” which itself seeks to fulfill a dream: to create a Western ballet with Chinese characteristics.

headline: Review: ‘Losing Tom Pecinka’ Challenges Audience to Get the Message
abstract: Purposefully formulaic characters, a gender bend and a ghost with the name of a company member come together in this sendup of a play.
lead_paragraph: The real Tom Pecinka didn’t die. He left for drama school. Still, loss is loss, and the handsome ghost who addresses the audience at the start of Morgan Gould’s “Losing Tom Pecinka” in the New Ohio Theater’s Ice Factory festival wears a Yale T-shirt, an emblem of that abandonment.

abstract: Big Dance Theater’s triple-feature choreography combines “Terms of Endearment,” “Dr. Zhivago” and “Le Cercle Rouge.”
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — In the 83rd season of Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, Big Dance Theater’s magnetic and enigmatic “Alan Smithee Directed This Play: Triple Feature” is something of an anomaly. While dance at the Pillow tends toward the ultra-dancey — strenuously physical stuff — Big Dance, directed by Annie-B Parson and Paul Lazar, traffics in many media, in text, sound and video as much as movement.

abstract: Andy Samberg and Kit Harington star in this deadpan sendup of tennis personalities and slavish sports documentaries.
lead_paragraph: Golf has its “Caddyshack.” Baseball has its “Major League.” And now tennis, another sport that some people find boring and that sometimes comes off as a wee bit pretentious, has “7 Days in Hell.” Center Court may never be the same.

abstract: Mr. Fowler waited four decades to publicly acknowledge his role in Jimmie Lee Jackson’s death, considered an impetus for the 1965 voting-rights marches from Selma to Montgomery.
lead_paragraph: Jimmie Lee Jackson, a 26-year-old laborer and church deacon, was shot to death in Mack’s Cafe in Marion, Ala., on the night of Feb. 18, 1965, and the killing proved historic: It provoked the fateful voting-rights march from Selma to Montgomery, turning the tide for the civil rights movement.

headline: Petra Cortright’s Desktop Dolls
keywords: ['Art', 'Computer Monitors', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: In a new exhibition, the artist manipulates software that provides the user with a customizable array of digital strippers.
lead_paragraph: The artist Petra Cortright has always committed her work to screens — she’s best known for her short webcam videos, which meld selfie technique with performance art, and for her “digital paintings” (on aluminum) and animations — and the screens keep getting bigger. The Santa Barbara, Calif.-born artist now shares a studio building in El Sereno (the easternmost neighborhood of Los Angeles) with her husband, Marc Horowitz, and Parker Ito. But regardless of where she plugs in her computer, she’s at home: Cortright has been making and showing work on the Internet since 2007, years before it was a medium comprehensible to many aficionados of analog art.

headline: Review: ‘Do I Sound Gay?’ Examines a Manner of Speaking
abstract: This documentary, written and directed by David Thorpe, dissects the stereotype of the so-called gay voice.
lead_paragraph: David Thorpe’s engaging personal documentary, “Do I Sound Gay?,” tiptoes into treacherous waters, where it stirs up a few ripples before gracefully backing out. Not so long ago, mockery of the sissy queen stereotype, with a limp wrist, a mincing gait and a lisp was a surefire laugh getter for comedians like Bob Hope, who made cruel sport of perceived effeminacy.

headline: Pope Francis Celebrates Mass in Bolivia
abstract: Pope Francis celebrated mass in Santa Cruz, Bolivia, on Thursday during his tour of south America.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis celebrated mass in Santa Cruz, Bolivia, on Thursday during his tour of south America.

headline: Review: Art Carved From Inequality by James ‘Son Ford’ Thomas
abstract: An inspirational exhibition, with animal sculptures, tiny open coffins and tableaus of everyday life, brings an underappreciated artist to light.
lead_paragraph: “James ‘Son Ford’ Thomas: The Devil and His Blues” at New York University’s 80WSE Gallery is an inspirational show about the perseverance of art, and the tragedy of inequality. But it is also a thing of joy: It brings the work of a wonderful and underappreciated artist to the fore.

headline: Review: Positions Wanted by Minions Experienced at Serving Evildoers
abstract: Those look-alike yellow guys become miserable when they have no one to help, albeit incompetently, in the first movie that’s all about them.
lead_paragraph: It’s fitting that the little yellow critters scampering through “Minions” look as identical as genetically modified corn kernels, save for a googly eyeball or two. Franchises operate on an axis of sameness and difference, so it’s amusing that one incorporates that truism into its actual character design. And while “Minions” explores nominally new narrative ground, it folds neatly into a series that now includes two features (“Despicable Me” and “Despicable Me 2”), various shorts, books, video games, sheet music and a theme park attraction. So, you know, different but also the same.

headline: No Need for DeAndre Jordan to Apologize
abstract: The etiquette of free agency may have been violated when Jordan decided to stay with the Clippers instead of signing with the Mavericks, but no actual contract or N.B.A. rule was broken.
lead_paragraph: A conflicted young man with a major career decision reneged on a handshake agreement to leave the nest because what he wanted most from his newfound leverage was love and attention from the most popular guys at the home office.

headline: Circus Cats Are Lions of Their Profession, but Domestic at Heart
abstract: A 14-cat circus is coming to New York, featuring performers who execute tricks, jump record-setting lengths and play music — unless they are distracted by shiny objects.
lead_paragraph: TO train a cat to balance on a ball and walk it forward, you will need a weighted ball, a track to place it on, a hand-held clicker and lots of kitty treats. Each time the cat masters part of the process — standing on the ball, say, or learning to walk backward to make the ball advance — you make a clicking noise while delivering a treat. It takes time, patience and a willing cat.

lead_paragraph: Have questions about recipes, cooking and food? That’s what I’m here for! Write me at foodeditor@nytimes.com and ask away. I’ll answer your queries herewith.

headline: Jeb Bush Outstrips Rivals in Fund-Raising as ‘Super PACs’ Swell Candidates’ Coffers
abstract: Bypassing vast networks of fund-raisers, Republican candidates are turning instead to super PACs able to draw on a few super-wealthy supporters.
lead_paragraph: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me. — Jeb Bush and his allies announced on Thursday that they had amassed more than $114 million in campaign cash over the last six months, dwarfing the combined fund-raising of his Republican rivals for the party’s presidential nomination.

headline: ‘Tap Forward’ Showcases Contemporary Tap
abstract: Part of the Tap City festival, the performances offered acts like Syncopated Ladies, Caleb Teicher and the veteran Brenda Bufalino.
lead_paragraph: This week, Tony Waag, the perpetually cheerful director of the American Tap Dance Foundation, presides over Tap City, a festival now in its 15th year. On Wednesday in “Tap Forward,” a program highlighting contemporary tappers at the intimate Duke on 42nd Street, there was even a flash from the past: The veteran Brenda Bufalino showed off her polished finish as she quietly blended in and out of a groove in “Strayhorn Medley.”

headline: Review: In ‘Self/less,’ Immortality at a Cost
abstract: Ben Kingsley plays a terminally ill real estate magnate who pays a lot of money to have his consciousness uploaded into Ryan Reynolds’s body.
lead_paragraph: At the start of “Self/less,” Damian Hale, a ruthless New York real estate magnate, is played by Ben Kingsley, who seems to have fired his dialect coach halfway to mastering what is apparently supposed to be a Brooklyn accent. No matter. Damian, who has a terminal illness, has purchased immortality — or at least extended life on his original warranty — from a smooth and shady British scientist named Albright (Matthew Goode). After his death, Damian’s unique cognitive software, his reservoir of memories and feelings and thoughts, is uploaded into the body and brain of Ryan Reynolds. So is the job of carrying this entirely preposterous, not entirely unenjoyable movie.

headline: Brooklyn Expats Come Home
abstract: Many former Brooklynites can’t help returning often to visit friends and their favorite places. Some find they have to move back.
lead_paragraph: The average person will move 11.7 times in his or her lifetime, census data shows. Of these homes, many will be fondly remembered, but once the tape is sealed on the last moving box, rarely do people continue to regularly visit their old stamping grounds. That is, unless the last place they lived was Brooklyn.

lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a tugboat captain and the Police Department’s graduating class.

lead_paragraph: Fashion could use a little Iowa. That’s what stylish Japanese men think, and since when has Japan ever been late to a trend?

headline: Review: ‘Tangerine,’ a Madcap Buddy Picture About Transgender Prostitutes
abstract: Sean Baker’s fast, funny comedy, shot on iPhones, doesn’t dive deep into transgender identity but shows that femininity is a mask that can be slipped on and off.
lead_paragraph: Little is as it seems in “Tangerine,” a fast, raucously funny comedy about love and other misadventures. That’s true of its main attractions, a pair of transgender lookers with motormouths and killer gams, as well as the nominally straight men occupying their hearts and minds. Appearances both deceive and delight in this tough yet tender, gritty yet gorgeous movie, which was made with ingenious skill and what would count as chump change at the big studios. Shot along a grubby stretch of Los Angeles, it takes place in the looming shadow of the Hollywood sign, but as far from industrial cinema as another galaxy.

headline: New York Attorney General Creates Special Unit on Killings by the Police
abstract: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman said his office was responding to a “crisis in confidence” in the public’s perception of the ability of local prosecutors to handle these cases properly.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general, prompted by an executive order from the governor, announced on Thursday the formation of a special unit to investigate cases in which people killed by the police are unarmed or serious doubts exist about whether they were armed and dangerous.

abstract: The agreement between the Transport Workers Union Local 100 and NYC Bike Share is a first for bike-share workers in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Less than a year after Citi Bike employees in New York City joined a union, they became the first bike-share workers in the country to reach an agreement for a union contract.

headline: Pete Rose Says He Is Among Four Reds to Be Honored at All-Star Game
abstract: Rose said on a conference call that he had been voted by fans as a member of Cincinnati’s so-called Franchise Four players, who will be recognized on the field before the game.
lead_paragraph: Pete Rose, who is on baseball’s permanently ineligible list, will be on the field before the All-Star Game in Cincinnati on Tuesday as one of the four most influential players in Reds history, selected by fans’ votes.

headline: Review: ‘Stations of the Cross,’ a Portrait of Religious Fervor
abstract: This movie by the German director Dietrich Brüggemann can be viewed three ways: as a critique, a spiritual work or a sly comedy.
lead_paragraph: There are three ways to look at the German director Dietrich Brüggemann’s “Stations of the Cross,” an austere, beautifully filmed and powerfully acted portrait of extreme religious fervor that slyly flirts with comedy.

abstract: Carlos Marques-Marcet’s film about a couple’s shift to a long-distance relationship looks at the role technology plays in negotiating absence.
lead_paragraph: The opening scene of “10.000 km,” which is more than 20 minutes, follows Alex and Sergi through the intimate rituals of a Sunday morning: making love, making breakfast, brushing their teeth, imagining the baby they are thinking about having.
