abstract: James B. Comey, said that authorities had thwarted multiple attacks being plotted by the Islamic State and its sympathizers in the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said on Thursday that counterterrorism authorities had thwarted multiple attacks being plotted for July 4 by the Islamic State and its sympathizers in the United States.

headline: Review: ‘The Gallows’ Somehow Finds More Horror Footage
abstract: This movie about high school students trapped in a seemingly haunted auditorium has plenty of rickety camerawork, but that doesn’t add to the scariness.
lead_paragraph: The horror movie “The Gallows” starts with a decent if improbable premise, and it ends with a pretty good jolt. But in between, the film sure wears out the already tired found-footage device.

headline: New Jersey Man Charged With Killing 7 People Over 2 Months
abstract: Todd West, 22, of Elizabeth, led police officers on a frantic chase from New Jersey to Pennsylvania, where he was arrested on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old man has been charged with fatally shooting seven people and wounding an eighth in a seven-week span that spread from New Jersey to Pennsylvania, punctuated by bursts of violence that left multiple people dead within several hours.

headline: Lionsgate Takes Fresh Approach to Promote ‘The Hunger Games’ at Comic-Con
abstract: To publicize “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay — Part 2,” the film studio brought in 34 kettle drummers and Conan O’Brien.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Trot some stars onto a stage. Get a gushy blogger or aspiring comedian to ask canned questions. Dim the lights and show footage.

headline: Review: In ‘Mad Women,’ a Small-Town Political Family With Issues
abstract: Characters in Jeff Lipsky’s dramedy include a mother running for mayor, a father facing a rape charge and a daughter trying to help her mother manage.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Lipsky has made a new film, which means more domestic turbulence and stripped-bare (often figuratively, occasionally literally) characters for his fans. The movie is “Mad Women,” and this time Mr. Lipsky, who wrote and directed, throws in a political side plot that gives these sometimes satirical proceedings a skewed topicality.

headline: A Prayer Sung by a Long-Lost Son
abstract: Cantor David Rosenberg chanting in Hebrew.
lead_paragraph: Cantor David Rosenberg chanting in Hebrew.

headline: Review: ‘Meet Me in Montenegro,’ Romance for Ex-Lovers
abstract: The directors Linnea Saasen and Alex Holdridge both wrote and starred in this film, which is a semi-autobiographical love story of their own lives.
lead_paragraph: Based on a true love story — the filmmakers’ — “Meet Me in Montenegro” stars its directors, Alex Holdridge and Linnea Saasen, as former lovers who reconnect in Berlin years after a romantic jaunt in the Balkans. He’s Anderson, a stagnating independent filmmaker; she’s Lina, the Norwegian dancer who broke his heart. Like Mr. Holdridge’s previous film, “In Search of a Midnight Kiss,” this story has echoes of a Richard Linklater story, but peters out early on and an interminable voice-over grinds every other dramatic moment into dust.

headline: Dark Cloud Lifts Over Denver, but Experts Warn of More to Come
abstract: The pollution-laden haze, which degraded air quality across the region, was pushed down from extensive wildfires that have spread across Western Canada.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — An ugly and ominous dark cloud that has enveloped this city and much of eastern Colorado this week finally dissipated on Thursday, prompting public health officials to lift a warning against spending too much time outside, particularly for young children, old people and people with lung problems.

headline: Review: ‘SlingShot’ Documentary Pitches Solution to Global Water Crisis
abstract: The inventor of the water purifier, Dean Kamen, thinks his device can bring fresh water to the world.
lead_paragraph: According to the documentary “SlingShot,” the Slingshot — a purification device known as a vapor compression distiller — can make polluted water drinkable. If brought to impoverished communities, the machine, we’re told, would have vast implications for global health.

headline: F.D.A. Is Set to Toughen Nonaspirin Warnings
abstract: Labels on painkillers like ibuprofen that are taken by millions of Americans will be subtly changed to say that they cause an increased risk of heart attack and stroke.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration is strengthening warnings on painkillers like ibuprofen to say that they cause an increased risk of heart attack and stroke. The over-the-counter forms include Advil, Motrin IB and Aleve.

headline: Review: In ‘Strangerland,’ Relocating Does Little to Ease a Family’s Strains
abstract: This fiction feature debut from Kim Farrant centers on a family of new arrivals in an Australian desert town, which is soon clouded by mystery and a dust storm.
lead_paragraph: “Strangerland” centers on a family of new arrivals in an Australian desert town. Whether the title refers to their presence — or whether they are, perhaps, more alien to one another than to those around them — is a question left unresolved by this well-acted fiction feature debut from Kim Farrant.

headline: Review: ‘Tap World’ Documentary Features a Variety of Quick-Stepping Dancers
abstract: Dean Hargrove’s film focuses on an assortment of tap dancers proclaiming their love for the art, although it is light on the nuts and bolts of the discipline.
lead_paragraph: “Tap World” is a pleasant documentary full of tap dancers proclaiming their love of the form and showing off their skills. It would be better if it had a bit less proclaiming and a bit more nuts-and-bolts information, but still, it’s refreshing to see people bubbling over with enthusiasm for an art that is somewhat out of the mainstream.

headline: Florida Court Finds Politics Determined District Lines
keywords: ['Supreme Courts (State)', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Law and Legislation', 'Elections']
abstract: A State Supreme Court ruling calls for eight congressional districts to be redrawn within 100 days, finding evidence of political gerrymandering at work.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Florida Supreme Court on Thursday rejected political gerrymandering by state legislators and ordered eight congressional districts redrawn within 100 days, a decision likely to complicate preparations for next year’s elections.

headline: With Flag Gone, South Carolina May Host College Playoffs
abstract: The N.C.A.A. announced that the state’s colleges could once again bid to host championships after the governor signed a law removing the Confederate flag from the grounds of the State House.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina signed a law Thursday afternoon removing the Confederate battle flag from the grounds of the State House, the N.C.A.A. announced that the state’s colleges may once again bid to host championships.

headline: Facebook Said to Seek Music Video Licensing Deals
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: If the company, which has been expanding its video offerings, can strike a deal with music labels, it could rival Google’s YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, Facebook has slowly encroached on YouTube’s territory as a go-to outlet for online video, showing popular content from publishers like BuzzFeed and Vice and a growing number of user-loaded clips. Now Facebook is considering going after another piece of YouTube’s signature turf: music videos.

headline: Review: ‘What We Did on Our Holiday’ Transfers Sitcom Formula to the Big Screen
abstract: David Tennant and Rosamund Pike star as squabbling parents in this family movie directed by the team from the BBC sitcom “Outnumbered.”
lead_paragraph: A family of bickering, broken adults has its priorities realigned by three children and a terminally ill grandpa in “What We Did on Our Holiday,” a damp-eyed comedy whose banal title isn’t the only thing needing improvement.

headline: Myanmar Signs Treaty on Chemical Weapons
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: The Southeast Asian country, which has gradually embraced reintegration with the world, became the 191st country to sign the agreement.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar, a former pariah state in Southeast Asia once run by a military junta that has gradually embraced some democratic changes and reintegration with the world, has become the 191st country to sign the treaty that bans chemical weapons, the international body that monitors that accord said Thursday.

lead_paragraph: GWALIOR, India — The Supreme Court of India on Thursday ordered federal investigators to take over from a state police force in a sprawling testing scandal that has involved about 2,000 arrests and at least 23 deaths, some of them possibly suspicious.

headline: In Bolivia, Pope Francis Apologizes for Church’s ‘Grave Sins’
abstract: Francis repeated familiar themes in sharply critiquing the global economic order and warning of environmental catastrophe — but also added a new twist with his apology.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia — Pope Francis offered a direct apology on Thursday for the complicity of the Roman Catholic Church in the oppression of Latin America during the colonial era, even as he called for a global social movement to shatter a “new colonialism” that has fostered inequality, materialism and the exploitation of the poor.

headline: An Uber I.P.O. Looms, and Suddenly Bankers Are Using Uber. Coincidence?
abstract: JPMorgan Chase became the latest bank to publicize its use of the Uber ride-hailing service, as Wall Street jockeys for favor ahead of an initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street banks can be hidebound in their ways: insisting on suits and ties and handing out BlackBerries after everyone else has moved on to the iPhone. But if there is one thing that can push even the most conservative bank into the future, it is the prospect of business.

headline: Catholics Defy Boston Archdiocese With 11-Year Vigil to Keep Church
abstract: Parishioners in Scituate, Mass., have occupied a Roman Catholic church to keep it from closing, the last of a handful of such battles still going.
lead_paragraph: SCITUATE, Mass. — It was a bright Sunday morning at St. Frances Xavier Cabrini Church, and the building’s stained glass windows cast a jewel-colored glow over the service. An elegant 81-year-old woman led a few dozen congregants in Catholic prayer. A single flutist accompanied the hymns.

headline: Surge of Ebola in Liberia May Be Linked to a Survivor
abstract: The conclusion was made by scientists who analyzed the genetic sequence of the virus from the body of a Liberian boy who died of Ebola last week.
lead_paragraph: A resurgence of Ebola in the last week in Liberia, which had been declared free of the disease, may have originated with a survivor still carrying the virus, according to scientists who analyzed the genetic sequence of the virus from the body of a 17-year-old Liberian boy who died of Ebola last week.

headline: Can the U.S. and China Get Along?
abstract: Relations are at their worst point since 1989. To avoid conflict, bold steps are needed.
lead_paragraph: FOR longtime observers of China, the last two years have been unsettling. Under Xi Jinping the Chinese Communist Party has made it more difficult than ever to hope that the People’s Republic is still dedicated to the agenda of “reform and opening up” that was the mantra of the Deng Xiaoping era. Instead, Beijing has served up a neo-Maoist cocktail of autocracy within and truculence without.

headline: Wimbledon 2015: Garbiñe Muguruza Realizes a Dream, but Faces Nightmarish Odds
abstract: Muguruza has reached her first major final at Wimbledon, but her opponent will be Serena Williams, who has a record of 20-4 in singles finals in the majors.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — The only way to know how you will handle a first Grand Slam final is to wake up in the morning, feel the hope and tension rise, walk onto the court with the cameras clicking and the crowd buzzing, and actually play that first Grand Slam final.

headline: Takata Says No to Fund for Victims of Defective Airbag
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Liability for Products', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Japanese supplier of airbags, involved in the largest automotive recall in American history, says it will give the matter further consideration.
lead_paragraph: As the recall of defective airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata has mushroomed and the death and injury toll has mounted, the company has come under increasing pressure to take more responsibility for its faulty products.

headline: Unharmed by a Gas Explosion, but Choked by the Red Tape That Followed
abstract: The B&H Dairy Restaurant on Second Avenue in Manhattan was unscathed by the March 26 gas explosion on its block. But that’s when its troubles began.
lead_paragraph: To begin with, although the B&H Dairy Restaurant on Second Avenue in Manhattan now hangs by a thread, no one was hurt there on March 26, the day that three buildings on the same block were leveled by a gas explosion. Two men were killed in a sushi restaurant two doors away. Dozens of people lost their homes.

headline: James Marcus, Opera Benefactor and Ex-Goldman Partner, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Marcus served as a managing director of the Metropolitan Opera beginning in 1976. Ten years later he was named chairman, a position he held until 1993.
lead_paragraph: James S. Marcus, who fell in love with opera at a student performance of Wagner’s fairy tale “Lohengrin” when he was 9 and who went on to become a board chairman and benefactor of the Metropolitan Opera, died on July 5 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: A Bush and a Clinton Side by Side on Stage, and Not a Political Zinger Between Them
keywords: ['Scholarships and Fellowships', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: George W. Bush and Bill Clinton found common ground in Dallas as they helped promote a joint scholarship program.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The last names Clinton and Bush typically mean political combat of the past, present and potential future. But on Thursday, Bill Clinton and George W. Bush were all charm as they took the stage together here in a bipartisan love fest to promote a joint scholarship program.

headline: Giants’ Jason Pierre-Paul Should Be Able to Overcome Loss of Finger, Former Players Say
abstract: Pierre-Paul will have to rely on his athleticism as he adjusts to the amputation of his right index finger in a fireworks accident.
lead_paragraph: Jason Pierre-Paul was viewed as a high-risk, high-reward prospect when he was drafted higher than projected, going to the Giants 15th over all in 2011. He had played only one season at the major college level after transferring to South Florida as a defensive end following stints at two junior colleges.

headline: Federal Monitor Proposes Larger Trial of Body Cameras for New York Police
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Cameras', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Peter L. Zimroth, the monitor, recommended a broader, more scientific plan than a federal court did in a 2013 decision on the city’s stop-and-frisk program.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers would be more likely to encounter a police officer wearing a body camera under a vast new trial program recommended by the federal monitor for the Police Department.

headline: A Photographer Takes the Road West
abstract: The New York Times staff photographer Ruth Fremson is driving toward Seattle, posting photos to Instagram along the way.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times staff photographer Ruth Fremson is driving toward Seattle, posting photos to Instagram along the way.

headline: Eisenhower Memorial Design Approved
abstract: Frank Gehry’s design for the National Eisenhower Memorial received final approval from the National Capital Planning Commission.
lead_paragraph: Frank Gehry’s design for the National Eisenhower Memorial received final approval on Thursday from the National Capital Planning Commission, completing the federal approval process for the design. The action is the last federal approval required for the memorial, planned for the National Mall in Washington; the United States Commission of Fine Arts also recently gave approval. “This is an important day for those of us who are committed to memorializing Dwight D. Eisenhower, a brilliant military strategist, a visionary world leader, a man who saved Western democracy, and a proud Kansan,” said Senator Pat Roberts, a Kansas Republican who is chairman of the Eisenhower Memorial Commission. “It’s my belief we can finish a memorial that is fitting for a man who has given so much to our freedom.” The project has been plagued by conflict, since Eisenhower family members have objected to the design and Congress has not funded construction. Representative Mike Thompson, a California Democrat, added: “It’s time to put aside the squabbling and attacks and move forward to give to the American people, to Ike’s remaining troops, and to the world, a great memorial to a great man.”

headline: From the First Round to a Last Chance for Thomas Robinson
abstract: Robinson, 24, is trying avoid the label of “bust,” and he underlines an energetic youth movement designed to allow the Nets to rebuild while trying to make another playoff run.
lead_paragraph: While N.B.A. fans heatedly debated DeAndre Jordan’s decision to spurn the Dallas Mavericks and remain with the Los Angeles Clippers, the Nets introduced their free-agent signings on Thursday in a subdued atmosphere at Barclays Center.

headline: The National Youth Orchestra’s Moment in the Sun
abstract: Founded by Carnegie Hall’s Weill Music Institute, the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America has assembled 110 teenage musicians who will perform at the hall before touring seven cities in China.
lead_paragraph: PURCHASE, N.Y. — Ah, the great indoors!

headline: Friend, on Stand, Recalls Losing His Job After Doing Brooklyn Senator a ‘Favor’
abstract: Sam Noel, who worked for the United States attorney’s office, testified that State Senator John L. Sampson told him to “find out information” about a friend’s mortgage-fraud case.
lead_paragraph: Sam Noel called State Senator John L. Sampson “John-O.” Mr. Sampson called him “N.O.” They were high school friends, and Mr. Noel was a groomsman in Mr. Sampson’s wedding, the godfather to his daughter. He stood by the bedside of Mr. Sampson’s mother as she died of cancer.

headline: Masabumi Kikuchi, Jazz Pianist Who Embraced Individualism, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Kikuchi’s playing had a cloistered originality and a style of free improvisation he described as “floating.”
lead_paragraph: Masabumi Kikuchi, a Japanese jazz pianist known to New York audiences in his final decades for his highly idiosyncratic approach, often heard in his work with the drummer Paul Motian, died on Monday at a hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 75.

headline: Review: In ‘The Weir,’ Things Go Bump in the Night, at the Pub
abstract: Conor McPherson’s haunting drama, first seen on Broadway, is revived by the Irish Repertory Theater in a cozy, intimate setting.
lead_paragraph: The Irish Repertory Theater’s superb revival of “The Weir,” Conor McPherson’s haunting drama about strange occurrences and the comfort of sharing them with strangers, has returned for a summer run at the DR2 Theater, while the company’s home base undergoes renovation.

headline: Review: ‘Sayonara’ Reimagines a Story of Cross-Cultural Love
abstract: Pan Asian Repertory Theater’s production of this show promises a fresh approach to the material in this wartime musical.
lead_paragraph: It’s 1952 in Kobe, Japan, and the American airmen stationed there must confront an unfamiliar culture with its strange rituals and customs. Even the booze is perplexing. “This is the first rice I ever drank,” says Maj. Ace Gruver, tasting sake. “Back home we make pudding out of rice.”

headline: Built to Commemorate Triumph
abstract: The return of Barry C. Silk.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This was an odd solving experience for me. I started out, happy as a clam, in the northwest and then came to a dead halt. Not that there’s anything wrong with that.

headline: Is Greece Worse Off Than the U.S. During the Great Depression?
abstract: The economy has been in disarray. People have been out of work for years. The banks have been running out of money. It sounds a lot like the Great Depression in the United States. But it is Greece – and in some ways, the situation is worse.
lead_paragraph: The economy has been in disarray. People have been out of work for years. The banks have been running out of money. It sounds a lot like the Great Depression in the United States. But it is Greece – and in some ways, the situation is worse.

lead_paragraph: Forget “Angry Birds,” or “2048.” The latest star of a maddeningly addictive iPhone game is the composer Steve Reich.

lead_paragraph: Three men were charged on Thursday in connection with the murder of a shopkeeper, who was fatally shot last month and found by a customer behind the register of his family’s odd-and-ends store on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

abstract: As South Carolina lawmakers delivered impassioned speeches for and against taking down the Confederate battle flag, three distinctive voices emerged.
lead_paragraph: As South Carolina lawmakers delivered impassioned speeches for and against taking down the Confederate battle flag, three distinctive voices emerged.

headline: Settlement Over Anti-Semitic Bullying at Pine Bush Central Schools Is Approved
abstract: Two 17-year-old girls told a federal judge about repeated acts of harassment at the New York State district; he approved a $4.48 million payment to aid the victims.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — The two 17-year-old girls told of repeated acts of anti-Semitic bullying — one girl had money shoved into her mouth, another kept seeing swastikas pervasively in school hallways and lockers — yet school officials in the largely rural Pine Bush Central School District made only feeble efforts to combat the abuse.

headline: Carlos Martinez Leads Cardinals Past Pirates
abstract: Martinez allowed four hits in seven and one-third scoreless innings, helping St. Louis win a matchup between the teams with the best records in baseball.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Martinez made his case on Thursday for being included on the National League All-Star team by pitching seven and one-third scoreless innings, and the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-1, in a matchup between the teams with the best records in the major leagues.

headline: De Blasio Stands by His Criticism of Cuomo
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, in his first appearance since returning from vacation, made clear that time apart from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had not led to a change of heart.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Bill de Blasio launched a startling broadside last week at Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, accusing his fellow Democrat of moral and political malpractice, he threw back the curtains on one of the more rancorous disputes between a mayor and a governor in decades.

headline: Kristaps Porzingis, Knicks’ Top Draft Pick, Is Set for Summer League Debut
abstract: Porzingis, the fourth overall pick in the N.B.A. draft last month, said he expected to play Saturday in a summer-league team against the Spurs in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Kristaps Porzingis, two weeks into his tenure with the Knicks, said he was looking forward to making his summer league debut here on Saturday against the San Antonio Spurs. After straining his hip in a predraft workout, Porzingis said he felt healthy. But he was still grappling with unknowns.

headline: North Korea: Pesticide Factory May Have Sinister Purpose, Report Says
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Pesticides', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: A pesticide factory recently visited by the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un may be used to produce biological weapons, like anthrax, according to an online report.
lead_paragraph: A pesticide factory recently visited by the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un may be used to produce biological weapons, like anthrax, according to an online report posted Thursday. On June 6, the state-run North Korean news media reported that when Mr. Kim visited the Pyongyang Biotechnical Institute, he was so happy with scientists’ work there in developing insecticides that he “wanted to carry them on his back.” But 38 North, a website run by Johns Hopkins University’s U.S.-Korea Institute, said photographs North Korean media released with the reports of Mr. Kim’s visit showed that North Korea has been importing dual-use equipment. “It is hard to avoid the conclusion that the institute is intended to produce military-size batches of anthrax,” it said. “Regardless of whether the equipment is being used to produce anthrax today, it could in the near future.”

headline: Italian Farm to Table
abstract: Delicacies at your door, courtesy of Fattoria La Vialla.
lead_paragraph: Why do the simplest Italian ingredients — ripe tomatoes, sharp pecorino, a splash of fruity olive oil — taste so sublime? It has something to do with where you’re eating them, but mostly it’s the location where they’re made. Until recently, savoring the spoils grown and prepared at Fattoria La Vialla meant having to make a trip to the 3,000-acre organic, biodynamic family farm and winery in Tuscany, where visitors can buy from the shop or stay in one of the 23 rental villas and dine al fresco under the olive trees. But now, all that deliciously authentic cheese and fresh pasta can be delivered directly to customers in the U.S. and Europe — so that you can think globally, and eat locally.

headline: How to Throw a Clambake Like You’re From Rhode Island
abstract: The Castle Hill Inn's take on the Native American tradition has been voted the state's best.
lead_paragraph: In Newport, R. I., the clambake is more than just a way to pass a summer afternoon; it’s a beloved New England tradition that locals take very seriously. Castle Hill Inn’s summer clambakes, overseen by the chef Karsten Hart (the director of restaurants at Newport Harbor Corporations), have been voted the state’s best by Rhode Island Monthly. They’re inspired, Hart explains, by the Wampanoag and Narragansett tribes’ centuries-old customs — but presented with some modern twists.

headline: Mets’ Steven Matz Is Out for at Least a Month With a Torn Muscle
abstract: Matz, a 24-year-old left-hander who had pitched two impressive games for the Mets, has a partially torn muscle and has been ordered not to throw a baseball for at least three weeks.
lead_paragraph: When Steven Matz made his major league debut for the Mets on June 28, everything went right. He dominated the Cincinnati Reds’ hitters, he went three for three at the plate with four R.B.I. and he reinvigorated a Mets season that had begun to flatten out from lack of hitting and too much shaky defense in the infield.

headline: Ken Stabler, Quarterback Who Led Raiders to Title, Dies at 69
abstract: Stabler, a star quarterback under Bear Bryant at Alabama and under John Madden for the Raiders, was the National Football League’s most valuable player in 1974 and led Oakland to a Super Bowl victory in 1977.
lead_paragraph: Ken Stabler, a precision passer who was famously cool under pressure in becoming one of pro football’s leading quarterbacks of the 1970s and engineering the Oakland Raiders’ first Super Bowl victory, died on Wednesday in Gulfport, Miss. He was 69.

headline: U.S. Women’s Open: Marina Alex and Karrie Webb Are Tied for Lead
abstract: Alex, 24, was in an unfamiliar position: sharing the first-round lead with Webb, a Hall of Famer, after a four-under-par 66.
lead_paragraph: LANCASTER, Pa. — After a 66 in the first round of the United States Women’s Open on Thursday, a quick television interview, a news conference, another television interview and a bite to eat, Marina Alex was finally able to find some peace and quiet. The demands of being a co-leader of the Open can be burdensome, especially if you have never been in that position.

headline: After Week of Turmoil, Chinese Stocks Post Further Gains
abstract: Government policies to prop up shares seem to be having their desired impact, even as many Chinese companies remain suspended from trading.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A week of volatility in China’s stock markets ended on a better note than many investors expected, as government policies to prop up shares seemed to have muted some of the panic among sellers.

headline: Kenneth G. Lieberthal on the Political Effects of China’s Stock Market Plunge
abstract: Mr. Lieberthal, an observer of Chinese politics and a former policy maker in Washington, discusses the implications for President Xi Jinping, who until now had benefited from an aura of omnipotence.
lead_paragraph: China’s stock market is in crisis. By Wednesday, the main Shanghai stock index had plummeted an astounding 32 percent since its peak on June 12 of 5,166 points. The Shenzhen index suffered a similar plunge. Chinese leaders have been rolling out a range of policies to try to halt the slides and restore investor confidence. Some may be working, if haltingly — the Shanghai index on Thursday closed 28 percent down from the peak. But the efforts could forestall what many analysts say is a necessary market correction.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) HARPER LEE: AMERICAN MASTERS In honor of the release of Ms. Lee’s novel “Go Set a Watchman” on Tuesday, Mary McDonagh Murphy — who was able to read an advance copy — has updated her 2011 documentary, “Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and ‘To Kill a Mockingbird.’ ” (Above, Ms. Lee with Gregory Peck at the movie’s premiere in 1962.) Ms. Murphy will also post on Twitter (#HarperLeePBS) during the broadcast. “It gives the fascinating history of how the book came to be, which involved Truman Capote, a perceptive editor and an act of generosity that helped give Ms. Lee, the novel’s author, the time she needed to write,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times of the original documentary, adding that the best moments come from other authors, who read passages and talk about the book’s impact on their work. “But just when this is beginning to seem like pandering,” he added, Oprah Winfrey “gives the most eloquent reading of all, of the scene in which Atticus leaves the courtroom after the pivotal verdict.” The broadcast is part of “Thirteen Days of Harper Lee,” an event featuring videos, book discussions and a link to “Essential Longform: The Best Harper Lee Reads,” assembled by the New York Public Library. (thirteen.org)

headline: Crowning Glory
abstract: The Milliners Guild arose to help professional hat makers deal with the dwindling number of suppliers in the once-thriving hat district in Manhattan’s West 30s.
lead_paragraph: For centuries, no self-respecting woman was considered fully dressed without a hat; no outfit was complete if your head was bare. Today, alas, the hat has been reduced to a novelty item. So once a month, a group calling itself the Milliners Guild meets with a singular purpose: to restore the well-made hat to its rightful place on top of the fashion world.

headline: Greece’s Economy Is a Lesson for Republicans in the U.S.
abstract: Economic policy promoted by American conservatives is how Greece got in severe trouble.
lead_paragraph: Greece is a faraway country with an economy roughly the size of greater Miami, so America has very little direct stake in its ongoing disaster. To the extent that Greece matters to us, it’s mainly about geopolitics: By poisoning relations among Europe’s democracies, the Greek crisis risks depriving the United States of crucial allies.

headline: Trapped by New York’s Bail System
abstract: No one should have to await their trial in jail simply because they could not afford bail.
lead_paragraph: Imagine, for a moment, that you are accused of a misdemeanor or even a nonviolent felony in New York. The judge sets a low bail, maybe $500, but even that is too much for you or your family. So you sweat it out in New York City’s hellhole of a jail on Rikers Island, waiting for a trial months, even years away. Plead guilty and the terrors of Rikers are behind you. But now you have a criminal record, which could damage your future.

headline: Ryanair Says It’ll Accept I.A.G.’s Takeover Bid for Its Aer Lingus Stake
abstract: The offer, which came from the parent of British Airways, removes the final hurdle to a combination that analysts say will bolster Ireland’s position as hub for trans-Atlantic travel.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ryanair said on Friday that it would accept a takeover bid for its 29.8 percent stake in the Irish flag carrier, Aer Lingus, from the parent company of British Airways, removing the final hurdle to a combination that analysts say will bolster Ireland’s position as hub for trans-Atlantic travel.

headline: Greece and Creditors Move Toward Deal, and Investor Optimism Surges
abstract: Markets responded after the government agreed to meet most of the terms demanded by its creditors and requested a bailout as a starting point for talks.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Optimism rose on Friday over the prospects of an accord between Greece and its international creditors, as the two sides weighed the latest measures from Athens aimed at overhauling its economy and securing its place in the euro currency bloc.

headline: Boston’s 2024 Olympic Bid Faces Skepticism Despite New Proposal, Poll Finds
abstract: There appeared to be a slight rise in support among Massachusetts voters for hosting the Games, but more people opposed the bid, with proposed tax breaks and traffic adjustments especially unpopular.
lead_paragraph: Statewide support in Massachusetts for holding the 2024 Summer Olympics in Boston appears to have inched up slightly since organizers proposed a new plan last month, but it remains tepid, and more voters still oppose the move than support it.

headline: Cuomo Is Put on Defensive by Fellow Democrats Over His Style
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo faces a choice: Appease offended party members by adjusting his style, or continue the hard-edged methods his supporters call essential to governing.
lead_paragraph: It was a moment for reflection and, perhaps, reconciliation with fellow Democrats who had grown exasperated with what they said were Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s tactics of bullying and intimidation. But he was having none of that.

keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: A symbol of the Old South that once seemed untouchable was lowered at the State House just 23 days after a massacre at a Charleston Church.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — They pooled by the thousands in the scorching July heat — white and black, old and young, civil rights veterans and everyday Southerners who grew up with the symbols and assumptions of the racial order of the South. They waited quietly at first, but eventually erupted into spontaneous chants of “Take it down!”

headline: In North Korea, Fears of Extreme Drought Ease

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Fears of a severe drought in impoverished North Korea have eased after a partial rebound in rainfall in recent weeks, the South Korean government said on Friday.

headline: A Honeymoon Through Italy
abstract: We danced at midnight in Venice, motored through Tuscany and made memories. Just as newlyweds should.
lead_paragraph: The trip began years before we met, when Sara wrote a short story about the perfect marriage. It started like this: “____ and I are moving to Europe to paint and make love, right after he finishes his diamond floor. We will live in a gigantic home filled with magic and passion. One of our favorite things to do in the summer will be to drive our ’68 Ferrari to the end of Italy and take a boat to a tiny island with nothing on it. There, we will have a picnic at sunset, fall asleep with blankets and small furs and wake up in the morning and go home. …”

lead_paragraph: Amit Singhal, Google’s search chief, has spent the past 15 years creating the miracle that is the Google search box. Now, as he and his team face a shifting landscape in which phones and apps are starting to rival computers and websites, he is in a race to make Google “the Google of Apps.”

headline: Britain’s Dangerous New Tribalism
abstract: The real threat to social cohesion is not enmity between Muslims and non-Muslims but a regressive politics of identity.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This past week marked the 10th anniversary of the 7/7 attacks in London. On July 7, 2005, 52 people were killed when four suicide bombers detonated explosive devices on subways and buses. There were commemorations across the nation to honor the victims, including a ceremony of remembrance at the 7/7 memorial in Hyde Park and a service at St. Paul’s Cathedral.

headline: Stampede in Bangladesh Kills at Least 23 at Clothing Handout
abstract: More than 2,000 people, most of them residents of slums, had assembled outside the home of a factory owner for the giveaway.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — At least 23 people, all women and children, were killed in a stampede Friday morning in a district north of here, after a large crowd gathered for clothes that were being donated during the month of Ramadan, the police said.

abstract: The presidential race, slow-forming for much of the year, sprang clearly to life this week.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning from Washington, where Congress took up the debate over the Confederate battle flag and where former President Jimmy Carter can still draw a crowd in the rain. While the summer election cycle has seemed to be mostly about adding a new candidate every few days, this week offered a look at some story lines that are bound to endure.

headline: ‘After a New Moon’

headline: The Bicycle Thief
abstract: A mistaken assumption leads to a police encounter in Japan.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been living in Japan for two years, and I pretty much know all the rules. Laws, customs, etiquette, that kind of thing. I never blow my nose in public, and I always remember to take off my shoes, though at first I would forget. That felt really embarrassing, so I learned quickly.

headline: Tennis’s Top Women Balance Body Image With Ambition

lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — While most celebrities go incognito behind a hat and sunglasses, Serena Williams uses a different tactic to blend into a crowd: long sleeves.

headline: Not Like Us
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Foreign Workers', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: As Donald Trump reminds us, the xenophobes have always been with us — but they are a diminishing presence.
lead_paragraph: They were criminals — thugs and thieves — a single ethnic group that filled the jails of big cities. “Scum unloaded on American wharves,” one speaker in Philadelphia said of them. Dirty, filthy, foreign. As for their children, they were “utterly ignorant of a place such as school,” The New York Herald reported.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Hangovers
abstract: They’re undeniably unpleasant, but not without value.
lead_paragraph: I used to loathe hangovers. I used to keep my bedside table stacked with bananas, Pedialyte, do-­it-­yourself guides to bootleg saline. Home from nights out, I used to dis- and replace fluids with the verve of an undertaker. I tried every which way to delay the inevitable. Still I woke up hung over, of course. Blanched in the a.m. sun, feeling like death, I used to offer up that childish, transactional petition: I promise I’ll never do this again if you just make it hurt less.

headline: How to Conduct an Auction
abstract: Perfect your warble. Spot the serious buyers.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘It’s the sound that sells,’’ says Brandon Neely, describing an auctioneer’s hard-­driving patter. Strive for a melodic chant that lulls your audience, even as it pushes them into fast-­paced bidding wars. Potential buyers should be able to ‘‘sit and listen to you all day without getting agitated,’’ says Neely, 29, of Southside, Ala., who auctions cattle, vehicles and farm equipment and was recently named this year’s winner at the World Livestock Auctioneer Championship in Clifton, Tex.

headline: How Does Paul Rudd Work?
abstract: The actor is known for being "likable," but that doesn't fully explain his appeal.
lead_paragraph: On a Friday night in May, I met Paul Rudd to see a play on Broadway. In advancing the task of examining his fundamental Ruddness, I thought a shared activity would provide us something to talk about beyond the mandatory promotional patter. (Which is this: He is starring in the newest Marvel movie, ‘‘Ant-Man,’’ out July 17.) Rudd suggested ‘‘Fun Home,’’ the musical based on a graphic memoir by Alison Bechdel, which deals with topics like parenting, queer theory and Chippendale furniture.

headline: A Living Wage for Caregivers
abstract: Domestic workers, who have long been denied equal protection in the work force, are now at the forefront of a growing and perhaps pivotal rights movement.
lead_paragraph: Marlene Juarez worked as a nanny for a family near Boston, taking care of four children ranging in age from 6 months to 6 years old; she organized play dates, cooked, did laundry and cleaned a large house. Both parents worked full time and in some weeks asked Juarez to work as many as 60 or 70 hours. Juarez had recently emigrated from Honduras, and was afraid to complain. She couldn’t afford to lose her job. But, once, she requested a few hours off to deal with a personal matter — and in response, her employers docked her pay.

headline: Going Off the Grid on a Swedish Island
abstract: Furillen, a remote peninsula on Gotland, an island in the Baltic Sea, is the perfect hideaway from the digital world.
lead_paragraph: I needed a break.

abstract: Adapting Capt. Brian Castner’s “The Long Walk,” a memoir of war and its aftermath, for the opera.
lead_paragraph: Early in the opera adaptation of “The Long Walk,” Brian Castner’s dark memoir of his tour as a bomb-disposal officer in Iraq and his struggles with anxiety and brain injury after returning home, the performance signals that it will build on the original account’s claustrophobic exploration of what its protagonist calls, with a convincing mix of detail and bluntness, his “Crazy.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Greece Accepts Austerity Measures
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Greece Accepts Austerity Measures | Chinese Stock Markets Sustain Rebound | Bankers Sign Up for Uber as Its I.P.O. Looms | P.&G. Sells Beauty Brands
lead_paragraph: GREECE ACCEPTS AUSTERITY MEASURES | European markets rallied again on Friday after Greece submitted proposals that appeared to accept the austerity measures that its creditors wanted,  David Jolly and Liz Alderman write in The New York Times. On Thursday, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece sought a three-year bailout loan totaling 53.5 billion euros, or about $59 billion, and asked for the country’s European creditors to commit to a discussion about debt relief, which has been a major sticking point in the bailout talks,  Ms. Alderman and James Kanter write in The New York Times. Germany’s finance minister, Wolfgang Schäuble, finally softened his stance on that issue on Thursday, admitting that “debt sustainability is not feasible without a haircut,” although he then appeared to backtrack.

The generation that lived through that terrible time is on its way out, taking its unrecorded memories.

abstract: A journalist gives her account of the Egyptian uprising in 2011 and its aftermath.

The protesters were brave, idealistic, unarmed and media-savvy. Many were young and beautiful. But they weren’t experienced in practical politics. After their chief demand — Hosni Mubarak’s removal from power — was met, they had few plans for what came next.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “The Little Paris Bookshop,” No. 16 on the hardcover fiction list, is the first international hit for the German novelist Nina George, who has written almost 30 books in 22 years.
lead_paragraph: Best Regards: The German novelist Nina George is prolific: In the 22 years since she started her career at age 19, she has written almost 30 books, including mysteries, relationship guides and steamy romances. (“Americans get all finicky when it comes to the graphic nature of my erotic scenes,” she has said. “They prefer to leave a lot of it up to the imagination: more Barbie doll sexlessness, less Anaïs Nin eroticism.”) But with “The Little Paris Bookshop,” new at No. 16 on the hardcover fiction list, George has her first bona fide international hit, the tale of a lovelorn bookseller who peddles his wares from a barge on the Seine and sees his calling as one part matchmaker, one part witch doctor. “There are books that are suitable for a million people, others for only a hundred,” he explains. “There are even remedies — I mean books — that were written for one person only.” The novel’s success has introduced George, happily, to the world of international publishing, as she describes at some length on her website: “The captains and navigators in publishing are women! From agents to list managers, women negotiate with other women on everything from money and content to sales,” she writes. “The agents and publishers always sign their first names to their emails: Vanessa, Cecile, Mirjam. From New York to Paris, they write: ‘Best regards/Yours, Christine, Rowan, Anna, Hedda, Elise.’ They discuss money with the cold clarity of a glass of vodka. No dancing around the issue as is so often the case in Germany. What’s even more cathartic, though, is the praise I’ve received from Cecile, Rowan, Anna, Hedda and Christine. No praise for my work has ever been as profuse and sincere as the compliments I’ve received from these foreign publishers in Paris, New York, Rome, Amsterdam and Riga. First they bought my book, then they wrote me long letters explaining what they liked about it. I suspect the reluctance to compliment authors and their novels is a typically German phenomenon. What if it makes the author too expensive? Or if the accolades go to her head? Or if she becomes, somehow, too difficult to work with? Nonsense! Bring on the praise, my dear German book people! It is pure joy.”

headline: The Boston Symphony and Steven Beck Entice Concertgoers
abstract: The Boston Symphony Chamber Players will perform a Naumburg Orchestral Concerts series program in Central Park, and Steven Beck will present a piano recital at Bargemusic in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: When the weather cooperates, the free Naumburg Orchestral Concerts in Central Park draw overflow crowds, for both the outdoor ambience and fresh programming. Next, the acclaimed Boston Symphony Chamber Players perform Mozart’s Oboe Quartet, Carl Nielsen’s Wind Quintet and a novelty: Brahms’s Serenade No. 1 for Winds and Strings (best known as his First Serenade for Orchestra, presented in Alan Boustead’s 1988 reconstruction of an earlier chamber version). With seats set up for 1,000 early arrivers, the Naumburg Bandshell makes an inviting concert space. (7:30 p.m., Tuesday, Central Park, naumburgconcerts.org.)

headline: ‘The Amazing Acro-Cats’ Visit New York
abstract: Rescues and strays walk tightropes, skateboard, jump through hoops, balance on balls and more under the direction of Samantha Martin.
lead_paragraph: George Balanchine used to say that in Mourka, his beloved white-and-orange alley cat, he had a body worth choreographing for. (As documented in Tanaquil Le Clercq’s book featuring Martha Swope’s photographs of the feline charmer, Mourka did possess delightful ballon.) In “The Amazing Acro-Cats,” a troupe of rescues and strays led by the Chicago animal trainer Samantha Martin roll on balls, soar through the air in long and high jumps, push shopping carts, and leap through hoops. The finale is a six-cat band, better known as the Rock Cats; Tuna, on cowbell, is the show’s star. “Acro-Cats,” which makes its New York debut, was first presented in an art gallery in 2006.

headline: Kelly Clarkson Takes Her Tour to Holmdel, N.J., and Radio City Music Hall
abstract: The pop star and first “American Idol” winner continues her North American tour with stops in New Jersey and New York.
lead_paragraph: The next season of “American Idol,” its 15th, will also be its last. Naturally, that will occasion all sorts of think pieces about the show’s success stories, its influence and its staying power. All of those pieces can pre-emptively be replaced with just two words: Kelly Clarkson. She was the winner of the show’s first season, in 2002, but more important, she was a transcendently good and totally unknown singer: the proof of concept “Idol” needed to continue bushwhacking through the country for more than a decade trying to recapture that first high. That model has collapsed, for now, but Ms. Clarkson remains — not quite the reliable hitmaker she was five or 10 years ago, but still one of the most technically precise executors in pop. She’s lasted this long because “Idol” couldn’t have predicted the sort of pop star she would become: bombastic, demure, aggrieved, flamboyantly talented but awww-shucks modest. (Tuesday, PNC Bank Arts Center, Holmdel, N.J.; Thursday and Friday, Radio City Music Hall.)

That film, “Heavenly Creatures” — playing Friday in Film Forum’s True Crime series — offered the feature debuts of Kate Winslet and the indie stalwart Melanie Lynskey and earned Mr. Jackson and his wife, Fran Walsh, Oscar nominations for their poignant script.

headline: As Superheroes Go, Ant-Man Was Always a Wimp
abstract: Surrounded by other Marvel characters like Spider-Man and the Fantastic Four, Ant-Man had an inferiority complex.
lead_paragraph: In the Marvel Comics big bang of the early 1960s that brought forth memorable characters like the Fantastic Four, the Amazing Spider-Man and the Mighty Thor, Ant-Man always seemed like a mortified orphan. Thor was an Asgardian god; Ant-Man had the strength of a regular joe. Spidey reveled in snappy repartee; Ant-Man cooed to ants. The Thing’s catch phrase was “It’s clobberin’ time!” Ant-Man was never known to shriek, “It’s shrinkin’ time!”

Titled “Bronx Calling,” the exhibition features sculpture, photography, installations, prints, collage, painting, performance, drawing, video and animation. headline: New Walking Tours Explore Nashville’s Food Scene
abstract: The company Walk Eat Nashville offers tours of the city, with a new expansion exploring the restaurants and artisan food shops in the Midtown/Vanderbilt area.
lead_paragraph: Nashville is famous for its country music. But its food scene is hopping, too. The company Walk Eat Nashville offers tours of the city, with a new expansion exploring the restaurants and artisan food shops in the Midtown/Vanderbilt area, near Music Row, of Nashville. The neighborhood is known as the place where the city’s culinary roots took hold, and includes upscale dining and down-home cooking, said Karen-Lee Ryan, the Walk Eat Nashville founder. Tastings at each location include discussions with chefs, owners and managers. “I want people to connect to the food and the people who make it possible,” she said.

abstract: Ms. Saujani is up at 6; time enough to get to the gym before her baby, Shaan, awakes. In between family brunch and perusing Facebook, she might prompt Shaan to post on his Twitter account.
lead_paragraph: If Reshma Saujani had been elected New York City public advocate in 2013 (she ran in the Democratic primary), it’s unlikely that 1,200 rising high school juniors and seniors would be learning computer science this summer through the organization she founded, Girls Who Code. “We scaled enormously since 2013 because I came back here and I gave this organization my 1,000 percent attention every day,” said Ms. Saujani, 39, who lives in Chelsea with her husband, the 37-year-old tech entrepreneur Nihal Mehta, and their son, Shaan, born in February. This year the seven-week summer-intensive program is operating in nine cities, including New York, where about 250 girls will participate.

Call it echo-chamber music, if you like.

headline: Review: Harper Lee’s ‘Go Set a Watchman’ Gives Atticus Finch a Dark Side
abstract: In Ms. Lee’s long-awaited novel, Scout Finch, or Jean Louise as she is now known, finds some disturbing truths about her father.
lead_paragraph: We remember Atticus Finch in Harper Lee’s 1960 classic, “To Kill a Mockingbird,” as that novel’s moral conscience: kind, wise, honorable, an avatar of integrity who used his gifts as a lawyer to defend a black man falsely accused of raping a white woman in a small Alabama town filled with prejudice and hatred in the 1930s. As indelibly played by Gregory Peck in the 1962 movie, he was the perfect man — the ideal father and a principled idealist, an enlightened, almost saintly believer in justice and fairness. In real life, people named their children after Atticus. People went to law school and became lawyers because of Atticus.

headline: Wednesday Night Fever in Bay Ridge

lead_paragraph: As dusk fell on a recent balmy Wednesday, it was still bright underneath the arched marquee of the Alpine Cinema. Young families, groups of students finally free for the summer and older couples milled around in the amber light, sidestepping piles of shoes spilling out of the neighboring Islamic Society of Bay Ridge, which was packed for Ramadan services. The line snaked past a shuttered comic-book store and was joined by people exiting Middle Eastern sweets shops, queuing up to watch dinosaurs maul one another in “Jurassic World.”

headline: ‘The Strain’ Rolls Out Season 2 of Its Vampire Invasion Tale
abstract: From house-to-house combat to research on an anti-vampire vaccine, the heroes of this FX horror series seem to have shifted their battle to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn becomes the epicenter of the fight against the vampire invasion in Season 2 of FX’s highly enjoyable horror series “The Strain,” beginning on Sunday night. Most of the action in the first season took place in Manhattan and Queens, but now the show’s fearless vamp hunters are ensconced in an abandoned pathology lab on Smith Street and a warehouse in nearby Red Hook, where the smiling exterminator Vasiliy Fet (Kevin Durand) engages in a Falluja-like house-by-house campaign to eradicate the bloodsuckers. And you thought hipsters were a problem.

headline: Review: Lianne La Havas Sings of Love and Identity
abstract: The English singer-songwriter introduced “Blood,” a new album of songs that go beyond love ballads to issues of heritage and identity, at the Bowery Ballroom.
lead_paragraph: In the songs of Lianne La Havas intricate cross-currents are something to sail above. There are cross-currents of rhythm and harmony, of melancholy and bliss, of romance and self-determination, of playfulness and purpose. But what comes across first is the sheer grace of her voice. It can be a breathy purr, a lilting tease, a liquid confession or a torchy declaration. She often introduces a melody by landing firmly on each note, then returns to toy with it in sliding, fluttering phrases, not for vocal display but to convey a sense of freedom.

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (HBO) 7 DAYS IN HELL (2015) Andy Samberg, below, stars as Aaron Williams, the brother of Serena with the behavior of John McEnroe and the hair of Andre Agassi, and Kit Harington is Charles Poole, a British prodigy bred to play tennis, in this satire about the longest match in Wimbledon history and the people who overinflate the importance of athletic events. Ms. Williams, Chris Evert, Jim Lampley, Soledad O’Brien and Queen Elizabeth (or is it?) play themselves; Lena Dunham, Fred Armisen, Mary Steenburgen, Will Forte and Michael Sheen also find their way into the story, which features revealing men’s underwear, a prison orgy and performance-enhancing cocaine. “If raunchy isn’t your thing, skip ‘7 Days’ and watch the real Wimbledon,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. But “if you’ve always wanted to chase down the anonymous tennis tournament official who intones ‘Quiet, please’ before a serve and smack him or her upside the head for the crimes of affectedness and self-importance, ‘7 Days in Hell’ is made for you. Bonus points if you recognize the well-disguised Howie Mandel.”

lead_paragraph: American Crossroads, a Republican “super PAC,” conducted two four-hour focus groups in Florida to test a series of attack ads against Mrs. Clinton. Here are descriptions of some ads, along with some reactions from the participants.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans are using focus groups in an expensive and sophisticated effort to refine the most potent lines of attack against Mrs. Clinton in campaign ads against her.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Inside an office park here, about a dozen women gathered to watch a 30-second television spot that opened with Hillary Rodham Clinton looking well-coiffed and aristocratic, toasting champagne with her tuxedoed husband, the former president, against a golden-hued backdrop.

headline: While Some Are Shocked by ‘Go Set a Watchman,’ Others Find Nuance in a Bigoted Atticus Finch
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The lawyer who fought racial inequality in Harper Lee’s “To Kill a Mockingbird” is an aging racist in her new novel “Go Set a Watchman,” a more complex character in which some see added value.
lead_paragraph: With all the debate brewing over the origins of Harper Lee’s novel “Go Set a Watchman,” the biggest bombshell turned out to be an explosive plot twist that no one saw coming.

headline: In Fiery Speeches, Francis Excoriates Global Capitalism
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Income Inequality', 'Global Warming', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Having returned to his native Latin America, Pope Francis has renewed his left-leaning critiques on the inequalities of capitalism, describing it as an underlying cause of global injustice, and a prime cause of climate change.
lead_paragraph: ASUNCIÓN, Paraguay — His speeches can blend biblical fury with apocalyptic doom. Pope Francis does not just criticize the excesses of global capitalism. He compares them to the “dung of the devil.” He does not simply argue that systemic “greed for money” is a bad thing. He calls it a “subtle dictatorship” that “condemns and enslaves men and women.”

headline: Why Employee Ranking Can Backfire
abstract: Showing workers how they measure up to their colleagues can have drawbacks, studies find.
lead_paragraph: Big Data has made it possible to measure employee performance more thoroughly than ever. But two recent studies offer a warning: Be careful about how you deploy that data.

headline: Hillary Clinton Will Call for Economic Policy Changes to Lift Middle-Class Wages
keywords: ['Endorsements', 'Organized Labor', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton, who plans to give her first major speech on the economy on Monday, also earned an endorsement from the American Federation of Teachers, a major teachers’ union.
lead_paragraph: A major teachers’ union voted on Saturday to give Hillary Rodham Clinton an early endorsement for president, a boost to her pro-labor credentials as she prepares to outline in more detail an economic vision focused on lifting middle-class incomes and tries to fend off a stronger-than-expected challenge from the left.

headline: Abigael Hoeschler: A Real Balancing Act
abstract: Ms. Hoeschler teaches logrolling in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: Abigael A. Hoeschler, 28, is a logrolling teacher in Minneapolis.

headline: Greek Debt Crisis Pits Greeks Against Germans
abstract: What happens when rules-bound Germany meets anything-goes Greece? A standoff, in this case.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — If the scramble to hold together Europe’s single currency has highlighted one thing, it is that national mind-sets can be more stubborn than the 60-year-old mantra of the Continent’s “ever closer union” once supposed. And no national psyche is more important to the outcome at this moment than Germany’s.

headline: Rays Center Fielder No. 941 in Draft, No. 1 in Defense
abstract: Rays center fielder Kevin Kiermaier, taken in the 31st round in 2010, is probably the best defensive player in the major leagues.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Kiermaier will always remember the number 941. That was his overall draft position in the 31st round in 2010. Essentially, 30 teams passed on him 30 times before the Tampa Bay Rays gave him a chance to play in the pros.

headline: Player Ratings: United States (1) vs. Haiti (0)
abstract: Judging the performances of the U.S. men’s national team players in their Gold Cup victory over Haiti.
lead_paragraph: After yet another poor start, the United States men’s national team improved in the second half and defeated a Haiti team that was unlucky not to earn a result in the game. For the first 30 minutes, Haiti was by far the better team, and the United States was on its heels.

headline: With Greeks Now Ready to Make a Deal, What Can We Expect?
abstract: Meetings this weekend in Brussels will determine if Europe will press ahead with negotiations for a third bailout, or leave Greece to exit the euro.
lead_paragraph: Q. Now that the Greek Parliament has approved a package of pension cuts, tax increases and other changes along the lines of what the country’s creditors have been demanding as a condition for more bailout money, what happens next?

lead_paragraph: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from July 3 to July 9.

headline: Mike Giannattasio of Montblanc North America: Finding Tranquility in an Urban Jungle
abstract: Mr. Giannattasio, the chief executive and president of Montblanc North America, says he collects pens because “the act of putting pen to paper conveys to recipients how important they are.”
lead_paragraph: Mike Giannattasio is the chief executive and president of Montblanc North America in New York.

headline: Money, Sex and Las Vegas Pool Parties
keywords: ['Casinos', 'Swimming Pools', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Discrimination', 'Waiters and Waitresses', 'Women and Girls', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Models (Professional)']
abstract: Behind the velvet rope at Sin City’s hottest daytime parties, sex discrimination is rampant.
lead_paragraph: Las Vegas — IMAGINE this: Before a job interview, you wait five hours in a room with your competition, but instead of business attire, you’re in bikinis and swimsuits, and prep with self-tanning lotion rather than hypothetical interview questions. When your turn comes to stand before the hiring panel, they ask you to walk, turn around, strike a pose for the camera. If you’re lucky, they might also ask about your past work experience. In the span of one minute, your interview is over. Exit stage right.

headline: My Mother, Lost and Found
abstract: Can Alzheimer’s ever have an upside?
lead_paragraph: DENVER — “CAN you make sure it has lots of stuff?” my mom regularly asked the server at her favorite Italian restaurant. Apparently, the minestrone soup was mostly broth with just a couple of noodles, which was unacceptable. “Really scoop it up,” she instructed, adding her nervous, friendly laugh. With her salmon, she demanded all sauces on the side, and an additional plate of lemon slices. Sometimes she brought her own dessert from the place she liked down the street. Her fastidiousness made me want to shrink into the jar of Parmesan cheese, but what could I do? That was my mom.

headline: D.I.Y. Education Before YouTube
abstract: Students once learned more out of the classroom than in it.
lead_paragraph: EACH summer, when school ends, education mostly stops short, too. But it hasn’t always been that way. For the striving youths of 19th-century America, learning was often a self-driven, year-round process. Devouring books by candlelight and debating issues by bonfire, the young men and women of the so-called “go-ahead generation” worked to educate themselves into a better life.

headline: Addicted to Your Phone? There’s Help for That
abstract: There’s new technology to save us from technology.
lead_paragraph: LIKE pretty much everyone these days, Susan Butler stares at her smartphone too much. Unlike most everyone, she took action, buying a $195 ring from a company called Ringly, which promises to “let you put your phone away and your mind at ease.”

headline: What Type of Nostalgic ’90s TV Fan Are You? (The Wrong Kind)
keywords: ['Television', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Nineteen Hundred Nineties', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: We want to be 2015 fans of the shows we loved as kids — but let’s resist the impulse to reboot.
lead_paragraph: WE held the meeting on the floor of my childhood bedroom, where centerfolds torn from Bop magazine and Teen Beat were stuck to the walls with Fun-Tak that looked like wads of chewed up Bubblicious. Ricky Schroder and Kirk Cameron smiled down on us as my neighbor Rebecca took minutes with a multicolored click-pen.

lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A ‘Lost Boy’ Battles AK-47s With Education
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Books and Literature', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Valentino Deng is using royalties from “What Is the What,” the book about him by Dave Eggers, to transform young lives.
lead_paragraph: MARIAL BAI, South Sudan — If there’s a world center of despair, it may be South Sudan, enveloped in an increasingly brutal war in which children are raped and then burned alive. But against that grim backdrop, one local man has undertaken a journey that is an affirmation of hope, inspiration and the transformative power of education.

headline: The Bernie Sanders Moment
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The unlikely presidential bid from the Vermont senator represents a culmination of major thinking on the left in the past half-century.
lead_paragraph: THE white-haired politician stands before 10,000 cheering supporters in Madison, Wis., and calls for “political revolution,” denouncing a “rigged economy” that produces “a grotesque level of inequality,” returning to a theme that ’60s radicals have long been trumpeting.

headline: Sam Altman
abstract: A tech venture capitalist who shuns social media and cherishes silence.
lead_paragraph: Sam Altman is a serial technology entrepreneur and president of Y Combinator, a venture capital firm in Mountain View, Calif., that has funded and nurtured a number of technology start-ups, including Airbnb and Dropbox.

headline: The New Child Abuse Panic
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Medicine and Health', 'Doctors', "Munchausen's Syndrome and by Proxy", 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting']
abstract: Is it a crime to disagree with your kid’s doctor?
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — FEW things are tougher for a parent than dealing with a child’s serious medical condition, particularly if it is complicated and hard to diagnose. The parent has to make hard choices about treatment, navigating conflicting advice from doctors or even rejecting one doctor’s opinion and seeking another.

headline: Aid-in-Dying Laws Are Just a Start
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospice Care', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Medicare']
abstract: Most of us will face quandaries far more nuanced than those covered by end-of-life legislation.
lead_paragraph: One co­ld March day, when she was 84 and suffering from congestive heart failure, my beautiful mother went to the garage and measured her Camry’s tailpipe, planning to buy a hose to fit it. She was grieving my father’s recent death, living alone in Connecticut with occasional visits from her three grown children in California, and suffering too much chest pain and breathlessness to weed her beloved garden. “There is a possibility for a timely escape,” she wrote in the journal I discovered after her death. “And I will take it.”

headline: When This Man Is Irked, He Might Just File a Suit
keywords: ['Smartphones', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Trans Fatty Acids']
abstract: Stephen Joseph first sued in San Francisco over graffiti. He lost, but the city cleaned up the graffiti. His latest victory is trans fats. He has learned that you can lose in court, but carry the day.
lead_paragraph: “You should be ashamed of yourself!”

headline: Review: ‘Closure’ at the New Jersey Repertory Company
abstract: Set on a Caribbean island, a new stage drama, “Closure,” revolves around the disappearance of a young woman, the strain it puts on her parents and a detective’s efforts to find her.
lead_paragraph: When my mother would scold me as a child, she’d often add a compliment to soften the sting. That is not a bad strategy for critics, either. So many people in the theater work so hard that even a tedious show deserves some recognition for all the effort involved.

headline: The End of Federally Financed Ghettos

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court issued an important ruling last month when it reminded state and local governments that the Fair Housing Act of 1968 bars them from spending federal housing money in a manner that perpetuates racial segregation.

headline: Stateless in the Dominican Republic
abstract: Tens of thousands of Dominicans of Haitian descent were rendered stateless by a 2013 court ruling. The government has failed to do right by them.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, the Dominican Republic’s highest court issued an unconscionable ruling that rendered tens of thousands of Dominican-born people of Haitian descent effectively stateless. Last year, the Dominican government, responding to international criticism, established a process that ostensibly offered them a path to be recognized as citizens. But because the application process was so onerous and poorly administered, tens of thousands of people remain in limbo, shunned in their homeland and unwelcome in neighboring Haiti.

headline: A Battle Over Eisenhower in Washington
abstract: National consensus, not family members, should determine the fate of a memorial to a national hero.
lead_paragraph: After a steady siege of Washington infighting and aesthetic backbiting, the plan to build a national memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower, the 34th president and five-star military leader of World War II, has run into its toughest hurdle yet — growing congressional resistance to financing the project and even calls to “reset” the planning process from scratch.

headline: What You’ll Be Remembered For …
abstract: For never picking up the check; for always missing the point; for saying, “I don’t need an entree, I’ll just have a taste of yours.”
lead_paragraph: LANE TEBBETT, the actor, 83, died at home in Brooklyn on May 11. His death was announced by his wife of 52 years, the former Elaine Gaspar. Mr. Tebbett, a graduate of the Actors Studio and a longtime fixture on the Off Broadway stage, was perhaps best known for originating the part of Bishop Stansfield in the 1956 tragicomedy “Mrs. Pelton’s Purses.”

headline: A Review of ‘Punctuating Space: The Prints and Multiples of Richard Artschwager’ at Vassar College
abstract: An exhibition at Vassar connects the dots, showing how in Richard Artschwager’s work paintings and sculpture, elitist art takes a democratic bow.
lead_paragraph: Richard Artschwager made ordinary things extraordinary. In fact, much of his remarkable career soared on an unremarkable black dot. Artschwager, who died in 2013, elongated it into a lozenge shape, called it a “blp” (pronounced blip), then stenciled or attached his sundry creatures throughout a city or in oddball museum locations.

headline: Baltimore Mayor’s Challenge: Fighting Crime While Reining In Police
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Some of Stephanie Rawlings-Blake’s detractors say that she, not the ousted police commissioner, Anthony W. Batts, is to blame for a rise in killings.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — On the day after Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake fired her police commissioner last week, a man was doing a brisk business selling DVDs from a folding table in front of a Baptist church in West Baltimore. A block away, a CVS Pharmacy stood as a reminder of riots in April, its windows still boarded with plywood, its red brick stained by black smoke.

headline: A Makeover for the Mother of Parliaments
abstract: The crumbling condition of Westminster is all too symbolic of the state of British democracy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — LONDON BRIDGE is not falling down, but the Houses of Parliament and Buckingham Palace are. In recent weeks, each building has been declared unfit for habitation, with the prospect of members of Parliament, as well as the monarch, moving out during renovations that may take decades to complete.

headline: Review: The Nuns Are Back in ‘Sister Act’ at the Gateway Playhouse
abstract: The Bellport production of the musical stars Rashidra Scott as a singer fleeing hoodlums and Jennifer Allen as the leader of the convent where she hides.
lead_paragraph: Light entertainment is the hallmark of summer theaters, and that is just what the Gateway Playhouse is serving up nicely with its current staging of “Sister Act.” Situated on about seven acres of greenery in Bellport, the Gateway has a red clapboard exterior offering visitors a picture-perfect vision of those classic barn theaters of yesteryear.

headline: Roger Rees, Actor Who Won Tony as Nicholas Nickleby, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Rees, a lanky, Welsh-born actor and director, was known for roles on “Cheers” and “The West Wing,” but made his biggest mark as Nicholas Nickleby in the early 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Roger Rees, the handsome Welsh-born actor and director who rose to fame as the title character in “The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,” for which he won a Tony Award, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 71.

headline: At Tour de France, Riders From Eritrea Hope to Blaze a Grueling Trail for a Continent
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Cycling, Road', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)']
abstract: Daniel Teklehaimanot and Merhawi Kudus ride for the Tour’s first modern African team, MTN-Qhubeka, which hopes to make Africa an important force in cycling.
lead_paragraph: MÛR-DE-BRETAGNE, France — All manner of flags are waved at the Tour de France. But at the start in Rennes on Saturday there were a few dozen examples of one that had probably not made an appearance: the red, blue and green of Eritrea.

headline: In Tourist Destinations, a Picture of Excess
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Social Media', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Vandalism', 'Photography']
abstract: A surge in reckless and damaging behavior by tourists, which often goes viral on social media, has officials considering measures to limit the damage.
lead_paragraph: MAGALUF, Majorca — For a holiday photograph from this resort town on the island of Majorca, two tourists wiped a drunken friend’s face clean with a crumpled flier advertising a deal for all-you-can-drink cocktails. Then they hoisted his sagging body upright between them while another buddy clicked away with a smartphone.

headline: Chinese Authorities Detain and Denounce Rights Lawyers

abstract: At least five lawyers from a firm that specialized in rights cases have been detained and accused of running a criminal syndicate to smear the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At least five Chinese lawyers from a firm that specialized in rights cases have been detained by the police in Beijing and accused of running a criminal syndicate to smear the Communist Party and “create social chaos” through their litigation, state-run news media said on Saturday.

headline: For Boston Sports Fans, It’s All About Rallying Cries
abstract: The suspension and appeal of the Patriots’ quarterback Tom Brady has seized hold of the Boston sports psyche when it is normally engaged with the plight of the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Around the corner from venerable Fenway Park, in the vending hustle of Kenmore Square, outnumbering and outselling the T-shirts mocking the Yankees for making a familiarly unflattering slurping sound were relatively new ones defending Tom Brady from the arbitrary justice of Roger Goodell.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Dmitry Zimin, the telecommunications billionaire and benefactor of a foundation known as the Dynasty Fund, was not calling for revolution or election monitors. His efforts were elsewhere: awarding grants to young Russian researchers and financing high school science camps.
