headline: Ukraine’s Explosive YouTube Stars
abstract: In Luhansk, two men leverage YouTube fame to shed light on and report about the realities of life in Ukraine’s conflict-torn East.
lead_paragraph: In Luhansk, two men leverage YouTube fame to shed light on and report about the realities of life in Ukraine’s conflict-torn East.

headline: In Bleak Ukraine City, a Duo’s Odd Experiments Win a Niche Online
abstract: As Luhansk’s prospects worsened, Pavel Pavlov and Aleksandr Kryukov emerged as quirky but candid guides to a war zone, an Internet voice for locals.
lead_paragraph: LUHANSK, Ukraine — THE microwave was a loaner, left for repairs by a family that fled last year’s shelling and never came back. With a few tweaks and the judicious use of a soup can, it had been weaponized, shooting microwave rays capable of blowing up a boombox.

headline: Michael Grimm, Former Congressman, Is Sentenced to 8 Months
abstract: Mr. Grimm, a Republican from Staten Island, resigned from Congress after he pleaded guilty in December to one count of tax fraud, a felony.
lead_paragraph: He spoke of his service to his country, his remorse for breaking the law, and the humiliation he has suffered because of it. Then the former congressman, Michael G. Grimm, asked for mercy from the court.

headline: One-Film Wonders: Hits Without Follow-Ups
abstract: This Anthology Film Archives series includes James William Guercio’s “Electra Glide in Blue,” Leonard Kastle’s “The Honeymoon Killers” and Wynn Chamberlain’s “Brand X.”
lead_paragraph: James William Guercio never knew from one-hit wonders when he was producing Grammy winners by Chicago. But he did have a single cinematic dalliance, now included in the One-Film Wonders series at Anthology Film Archives: “Electra Glide in Blue,” a 1973 police story for the “Easy Rider” set, starred Robert Blake as an Arizona motorcycle cop trying to solve a murder. More than an artifact, the movie is also beautiful, thanks to the immense vistas shot by Conrad L. Hall (“In Cold Blood,” “Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid”).

headline: At Terminal 5, a Triple Bill of Courtney Barnett, Speedy Ortiz and Torres
abstract: The three singer-songwriters — Speedy Ortiz is led by Sadie Dupuis — deliver some of the best of today’s pop culture.
lead_paragraph: A little while ago — 10 years? — it felt almost right to say, for those who like to cross things off lists, that singer-songwriter guitar rock had sunk to the bottom of the ocean. As is always the case regarding absolute statements about art, this was wrong, and women were especially good at demonstrating why. And so, an exceptional triple bill at Terminal 5 on July 22: Courtney Barnett, Speedy Ortiz, Torres — three singer-songwriters (Speedy Ortiz is led by Sadie Dupuis) deep in the zone. Ms. Barnett, from Australia, generates endless graffiti about insecurities and irritations to a steady but flexible meter; Ms. Dupuis’s words are rich and sanded-down and wry, as if designed to be read on a page; Mackenzie Scott, a.k.a. Torres, wants you to feel a philosophical chill, putting contemplative space around her best thoughts or repeating them.

headline: Arlene Shechet Has a First Museum Retrospective in Boston
abstract: “Arlene Shechet: All at Once” traces the artist’s career from her seated Buddhas to the traditional and the abstract.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, when a lot of New York artists were making art about gender, racial identity and the devastation of AIDS, Arlene Shechet was producing worked that looked like no other: hand-molded plaster sculptures of seated Buddhas. Rough-textured, splashed with color, her art was very much a meditation on change and loss, but added an extra element: a sense of emotional resolution.

headline: ‘Delusion of the Fury,’ a Dream, Carried Out by Ensemble Musikfabrik
abstract: Harry Partch dreamed up his own instruments, and Ensemble Musikfabrik is bringing them to the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: A menagerie of alien-looking instruments will fill the stage at City Center on Thursday and Friday at 8 p.m. as the German new-music mavens Ensemble Musikfabrik together with the director Heiner Goebbels bring to life “Delusion of the Fury” by the maverick West Coast composer Harry Partch.

headline: On TV One’s ‘Runaway Island,’ Characters Find Healing
abstract: A group retreat gives time for renewal for a characters with varied pasts.
lead_paragraph: Shows like “Empire” and “black-ish” received a lot of attention this past season for bringing more diversity to network prime time, but lower-profile cable outlets have showcased strong minority characters for years. Among those is TV One, which describes its programming as “designed to entertain and inform a diverse audience of adult black viewers.” On July 25 at 8p.m., it offers its latest made-for-TV movie, “Runaway Island.”

headline: Taye Diggs Takes Over in ‘Hedwig’
abstract: Mr. Diggs steps into a new Broadway role on Wednesday, replacing Darren Criss in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch.”
lead_paragraph: There was a time when it was hard to imagine anyone other than John Cameron Mitchell starring in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch.” As the book writer and charismatic original Off Broadway star, he created something that seemed distinctly his. That the role of Hedwig, the German transgender rock singer, has been capably filled and even reinvented, most smashingly by Neil Patrick Harris in the current Broadway production, takes nothing away from Mr. Mitchell. If anything, it means he’s created a prime musical theater showcase for any man or woman (Ally Sheedy once played the part) willing to strut, pose and belt while wearing fishnet stockings. Replacing Darren Criss, who kicked up a bit of controversy improvising and then apologizing for a joke about Bruce Jenner, the latest performer is Taye Diggs, the first African-American to play the role in New York. Mr. Diggs — who starred in the original “Rent” and filled in earlier on long-running Broadway hits, including “Wicked” and “Chicago” — has charm to burn, the kind that has lit up many movie scenes. But now he has a chance to let loose a more flamboyant side. You can see how he stacks up, starting Wednesday. (Belasco Theater, hedwigbroadway.com)

headline: New York, French Canadian and German Energy at Jacob’s Pillow
abstract: Daniil Simkin’s Intensio and Gauthier Dance from Stuttgart, Germany, appear at the annual dance festival in Becket, Mass.
lead_paragraph: Two internationally minded companies are bounding into the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival. Daniil Simkin’s Intensio makes its debut there with works by Alexander Ekman (Sweden), Jorma Elo (Finland), Annabelle Lopez Ochoa (Colombian-born, Belgian-based), and the New Yorker Gregory Dolbashian. Mr. Simkin, a dancing whirlwind from American Ballet Theater, says that his troupe, drawn from Ballet Theater and Les Ballets Jazz de Montréal, takes its name from a linguistic union of “intention” and “intensity.” So expect energy.

headline: Vegan Ice Cream From ‘Van Leeuwen Artisan Ice Cream’
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Books and Literature', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Veganism']
abstract: The new cookbook offers 90 inventive recipes, but it’s the 10 vegan variations that make it stand out.
lead_paragraph: If you’re the kind of ice cream lover who thinks the more butterfat and egg yolks in a pint the better, you’ll be tempted to skip the vegan chapter of the new “Van Leeuwen Artisan Ice Cream” cookbook (Ecco, 2015). Why contemplate vegan roasted banana ice cream when there is a recipe for the original dairy-rich version 60 pages earlier?

lead_paragraph: BY the mid-1990s, the Houghton family, whose wealth is derived from the glass and ceramic material manufacturer Corning, was into its sixth generation. Many of the cousins felt they had lost touch and were drifting away from the family.

headline: Bridget Nugent and Dean Reineking: Embracing an Adventure of a Lifetime
abstract: The couple was ready to build a life together. But first, they needed to help restore the bride’s family home.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Massapequa, N.Y., Bridget Nugent lived less than a block from the Great South Bay, in a Victorian house with a conch-shell-like turret, several balconies, a wide front porch and 75 windows, many with pale blue or yellow stained-glass panes, like weathered sea glass you might find on the beach.

abstract: Several people were injured and four were believed to be missing after an explosion caused a fire at a wood mill in Cheshire, in northern England, on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Several people were injured and four were believed to be missing after an explosion caused a fire at a wood mill in Cheshire, in northern England, on Friday.

headline: Wilco’s Surprise: A New Album for Free Download
abstract: Wilco makes “Star Wars,” its first collection of fresh studio recordings since 2011, available free online.
lead_paragraph: Wilco, the always-tinkering alternative rock band from Chicago, became the latest act to release a surprise album when it made 11 new songs available for free download on its website on Thursday night.

headline: What the Country Owes Harriet Tubman
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'US Dollar (Currency)']
abstract: The abolitionist and Union Army spy is more than worthy of replacing Andrew Jackson on the $20 bill.
lead_paragraph: American capitalism is deeply implicated in slavery. The traffic in human beings produced profits, not just for plantation families, but for bankers, merchants, manufacturers and insurance companies that issued policies on slaving vessels and the lives of the people who were carried in their holds.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: CALIFORNIA, by Edan Lepucki. (Bay Back/­Little, Brown, $16.) A couple expecting their first child confront a feral, apocalyptic reality and future. After Cal and Frida are driven from a dystopic Los Angeles into the wilderness, they attempt to eke out a life of security.

headline: ‘Death and Mr. Pickwick,’ by Stephen Jarvis
abstract: A novelist argues that ‘The Pickwick Papers’ was hijacked from its illustrator.
lead_paragraph: You don’t normally wish a novel would come with a bibliography, but Stephen Jarvis’s new book practically begs for one. “Death and Mr. Pickwick” makes some eyebrow-raising claims: that Charles Dickens’s “The Pickwick Papers” was “so widely circulated that only the Bible, Shakespeare and perhaps the Book of Common Prayer can better its circulation”; that for a century or more Samuel Pickwick, the book’s genial bumbling hero, was “the most famous character in fiction there has ever been”; and that Dickens didn’t name or invent Samuel Pickwick.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: David E. Hoffman’s “The Billion Dollar Spy,” No. 13 on the hardcover nonfiction list, traces the Cold War exploits of a Soviet military engineer who for years passed secrets to the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: Secret Agent Man: “The English Spy,” Daniel Silva’s latest espionage thriller to feature the art restorer and Israeli agent Gabriel Allon, drops out of the top spot in its second week on the hardcover fiction list, falling to No. 4. Meanwhile, a real-life spy story has climbed onto the hardcover nonfiction list: “The Billion Dollar Spy,” by the journalist and Pulitzer Prize-winning author David E. Hoffman, is new at No. 13. Hoffman’s book traces the Cold War exploits of Adolf Tolkachev, a Soviet military engineer who for years passed secrets to the C.I.A. “He put the documents in his coat,” Hoffman told NPR this month, “and he walked out of that top-secret institute at the lunch hour back to his apartment, which was a 20-minute walk, and he took out a camera and he photographed the pages and then he went back to work and put them back in the file. And he did this for years.” One way the book brings its subject to life, as Scott Shane noted in his review for The New York Times’s daily Arts section, is through the detail that Tolkachev asked his American handlers to pass along rock ’n’ roll for his teenage son, including Led Zeppelin, Pink Floyd and the Beatles. “My son, as many of his contemporaries in school, has a passion for Western music,” he explained in one letter. “I too, in spite of my age, like to listen to this music.”

headline: ‘North Korea Confidential’ and ‘North Korea Undercover’
abstract: Two books of reporting from North Korea offer details about daily life and the changing economy.
lead_paragraph: He was the Tammany Hall boss of North Korea, the man who dispensed favors and stayed close to the ruling Kim family, so close he married the daughter of the nation’s founder. He got rich by selling commodities to China: low-end coal and probably the more valuable rare earths. He ran the Ministry of People’s Security. Those gilded connections did not shield one of North Korea’s most powerful men from the wrath of the young new leader, the 30-something Kim Jong-un, and for reasons that no one outside the inner sanctums of Pyongyang knows, Jang Song-thaek suffered a bloody downfall.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE UNRAVELING: High Hopes and Missed Opportunities in Iraq, by Emma Sky. (PublicAffairs, $28.99.) The Briton who was the political adviser to American Gen. Ray Odierno from 2007 to 2010 offers an important and disturbing memoir.

headline: ‘Let Me Explain You,’ by Annie Liontas
abstract: A debut novel centers on a father who thinks he will soon die.
lead_paragraph: Annie Liontas’s debut novel, “Let Me Explain You,” opens with a type of communication that many of us know intimately: an email from a parent. This one follows many of the comedic conventions of the form. There is the gnomic subject line, the unorthodox punctuation, the needlessly formal greeting and sign off. There is a reckless use of the “cc” function, and a ­CASUALLY idiosyncratic ­RELIANCE on THE CAPS lock KEY.

headline: Foul Players
abstract: Peter Lovesey’s new whodunit, “Down Among the Dead Men,” involves a professional car thief, a missing art teacher and two formidable women.
lead_paragraph: What’ll it be today? A knotty puzzle mystery? A fast-paced police procedural? Something more high-toned, with a bit of wit? With the British author Peter Lovesey, there’s no need to make those agonizing decisions, because his books have it all. Take DOWN AMONG THE DEAD MEN (Soho Crime, $27.95), his new mystery featuring Peter Diamond, detective superintendent of the Bath constabulary. The story opens on a light note, with a professional car thief (call him “Driveaway Danny”) updating his skills with a remarkable gizmo that prevents a car from being locked — only to discover that the silver BMW he’s stolen has a body in the trunk.

headline: ‘Rise,’ by Karen Campbell
abstract: A Glasgow prostitute dumps her pimp and becomes a nanny.
lead_paragraph: The Scottish writer Karen Campbell’s new novel begins with its heroine, Justine, making a panicked escape from the Glasgow home she shares with her psychotic pimp-cum-boyfriend, Charlie Boy. On a randomly chosen bus, heading in the general direction of Oban, she tries not to fidget, but her legs itch desperately — because her jeans are lined with stolen 10 and 50 pound notes.

headline: ‘The Wolf Border,’ by Sarah Hall
abstract: A novel tracks a self-determined woman involved with the reintroduction of the gray wolf in England.
lead_paragraph: The English zoologist Rachel Caine doesn’t have relationships: “Just sex.” Her mother had been the same way. When Rachel finds herself pregnant after one drunken night with Kyle, her longtime friend and colleague at a wolf recovery program in the Idaho wilds, she can’t face the situation — at least not as a couple. Her panicked flight brings her back home to the Lake District, to help with a powerful aristocrat’s quixotic scheme to reintroduce gray wolves to Britain. Her own reintroduction proves just as complicated and dangerous.

headline: ‘The Pinch,’ by Steve Stern
abstract: A character writes a history of a Jewish neighborhood in Memphis in Steve Stern’s novel.
lead_paragraph: If your name is Stern and you seek literary attention, the evidence suggests you ought to consider a pseudonym. When Richard Stern — the brainy, digressive Chicago novelist and story writer who was better known for being unknown than for anything he wrote — died two years ago, his burden passed to Steve Stern, a fellow chronicler of Jewish experience via deeply schooled stories that can’t seem to get reviewed without reference to the author being not “as well known as he should be.”

headline: A Summer Reading List Inspired By Both Coasts
abstract: On the occasion of the first birthday of his New York outpost Book/Shop, the store’s owner Erik Heywood selects eight titles inspired by the east and west coasts.
lead_paragraph: Book/Shop’s New York location at 2 Bond Street turns one this week. Tucked into a bright corner inside the men’s clothing store C’H’C’M, it’s less a bookshop and more a shop about books. More interesting, perhaps, than its hard-to-find titles are its bibliophilic oddities: a Spanish book brush for dusting, Absorene Paper & Book Cleaner for maintenance and hand-sewn canvas book sleeves for travel. Minimal yet lively graphic prints (related to reading, of course) hang on the wall of the shop — which is lined with unique, morsel-size slotted bookshelves, all designed in-house.

headline: Judges Rebuke Limits on Wiping Out Student Loan Debt

abstract: Erasing student loans requires proof that paying the debt would cause “undue hardship,” and some judges think the rigid standard should be reconsidered.
lead_paragraph: On a typical day in her last job, Janet Roth left home at 4 a.m. each day and drove 40 miles to a tax preparation office in Glendale, Ariz. When she finally got back home, she had less than an hour before starting her 6 p.m. shift decorating cakes at Walmart. She worked until midnight, giving her just a few hours to sleep before starting all over again.

headline: They Told You So: Economists Were Right to Doubt the Euro
abstract: How Greece’s problems have proved economists like Milton Friedman and Martin Feldstein correct.
lead_paragraph: The continuing saga of Greece and its creditors is more tragic than comic. But watching it, I am reminded of that old line about the recurring travails of Laurel and Hardy: “Well, here’s another nice mess you’ve gotten me into!” For the problems facing Europe today are not sui generis. They are merely the latest installment of a story that has been unfolding for many decades.

headline: OMI Soars With ‘Cheerleader’ Remix and Aims to Keep Riding High
abstract: It is rare for a Jamaican to top the chart, and OMI, while basking in the publicity of his song’s remix hitting No. 1, hopes to continue to appeal to a variety of audiences.
lead_paragraph: Don’t call OMI a reggae artist.

headline: Popcast: Reggae’s Summer Flirtation
abstract: On this week’s Popcast, a look at the proven desire for for a reggae or reggae-like worldwide pop hit between Memorial Day and Labor Day, and roughly how the filtering system works.
lead_paragraph: Omi, a 28-year-old Jamaican singer, has the No. 1 song in the country: “Cheerleader,” in the Felix Jaehn remix version,a mildly island-y song of serene monogamy in the light electronic dance genre called Tropical House. The song has rolled through Europe and the rest of the English-speaking world for the last two years: six-times platinum in Sweden, four times platinum in Australia, regular old platinum in Britain. Omi doesn’t have an album or a fan base, really; “Cheerleader” is his only song, unless you count the original version, released in 2012, decidedly more reggae.

headline: The Law That Keeps People on Death Row Despite Flawed Trials
keywords: ['Habeas Corpus', 'Capital Punishment', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Federal Courts (US)']
abstract: How a piece of Clinton-era legislation stops federal judges from overturning convictions.
lead_paragraph: One of the more curious rulings the Supreme Court handed down last month, overshadowed by its landmark health care and same-sex-marriage decisions, concerned a death-row inmate named Hector Ayala. In 1989, Ayala was charged with participating in the execution-style murder of three men in an auto-body shop in San Diego, an apparent result of a heroin deal gone bad. During jury selection for the trial, prosecutors struck all seven of the prospective jurors who were black or (like Ayala) Hispanic.

At work in the unmarked, gray suburban building, the rapper born Marshall Mathers held a pen and a tattered Detroit Lions composition book, writing in solitude for no project in particular.

As he told a standing-room-only crowd here the other night, turning America around would be a lot like running the Trump National Doral golf club in Miami, which he bought when it was in bankruptcy in 2012.

headline: Amazon Says Prime Day Beat Black Friday in Sales Numbers
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'E-Commerce', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Discount Selling']
abstract: Despite derision in social media, the one-day sale appeared to achieve the company’s goals: more sales, and a big bump in subscribers to its Amazon Prime service.
lead_paragraph: Despite a much-derided  product lineup and clunky wait-lists, Amazon said on Friday that it sold more products during its Prime Day sale this week than Black Friday last year, and that more new members tried its Prime subscription service than on any single day in the retailer’s 20-year history.

headline: Errant Ball Hurts on Both Sides of Rope
abstract: Ernie Els and Justin Rose are among those golfers who recalled the sick feeling they got when an errant shot struck an unintended target.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Ernie Els’s gallery at the Old Course on Thursday morning included John Jones, who was in the vicinity of the first fairway, but not too close, when Els struck his opening shot at the British Open. Jones attended the tournament as Els’s guest, but to say he did not pay a price for his ticket would be skirting the truth.

headline: Honoring the International, Adaptable Eggplant
abstract: Found in myriad shapes and colors, it can be delicious prepared in as many different ways.
lead_paragraph: Eggplants are arriving at the market in all shapes, sizes and hues. Some are pear-shaped, fat, shiny and black; others are thin, footlong and dark purplish. There are bright fuchsia eggplants and eggplants with magenta and white striations. Some are pale violet; some pale green. Some are truly egg-shaped and ivory white. And there are tiny round pumpkin-colored ones no bigger than an inch in diameter.

headline: As Chattanooga Death Toll Rises, Mourning Deaths on Home Soil
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Portraits of the victims of the shooting in Chattanooga emerged as the death toll rose to five on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Gunnery Sgt. Thomas Sullivan was in the Marine Corps for 18 years, survived truck bombs and a rain of mortars during one of the biggest assaults of the Iraq war, earned a Combat Action Ribbon and two Purple Hearts, and was expecting to retire soon. Instead he was ambushed on home soil, in a suburban Chattanooga, Tenn., office park.

headline: What Is Known About the Chattanooga Gunman

lead_paragraph: Investigators have identified Mohammod Youssuf Abdulazeez as the gunman who killed four Marines in attacks on two military sites in Chattanooga, Tenn. on Thursday.

headline: Dropping $100 for a Day at Jacob Riis, the ‘People’s Beach’
abstract: Riis Park in the Rockaways has gone artisanal, part of the upscaling of public recreation space.
lead_paragraph: Standing in line at Pier 11, where Wall Street terminates at the East River, on a Sunday morning in July can make you feel old and dull and limited, at once socially and idiomatically. “Your shoe game is strong,” a young woman tells a friend who has arrived just in time to board the ferry that is scheduled to leave at 11:30. The shoes in question are flat-heeled gladiator sandals in coral suede. The woman wearing them is tired. “We started with bottomless brunch and drank all day and I didn’t get home until midnight,” she says. Another friend caroused more aggressively, not landing at home until 7 o’clock, and the feeling is that she will not rouse for the beach.

lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry defended the Obama administration’s work to free Americans held in Iran on Friday, saying he had raised the issue at every meeting in final bargaining over the nuclear dispute and was “very, very hopeful.”

headline: A Party to Celebrate a Shared Love of Sneakers
abstract: In honor of its new exhibition, “The Rise of Sneaker Culture,” the Brooklyn Museum hosted a night of revelry.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Brooklyn Museum opened “The Rise of Sneaker Culture,” a sweeping exhibition that includes 150 pairs of sneakers — from 1920s Keds to Nike’s first pair of Air Jordans. Last night, in honor of the show, the museum hosted an evening of revelry: a sneaker drive thrown by Heeling Soles and a dance battle, capped off with one big party. The photographer Amy Lombard captured the scene, which included a set from DJ collective I Love Vinyl, a choreographed dance and many, many pairs of shoes.

headline: Public Enemy? At Home in Mexico, ‘El Chapo’ Is Folk Hero No. 1
abstract: A daring break from a secure prison by the notorious cartel figure has enhanced his status as an outlaw folk hero in his home state and beyond.
lead_paragraph: CULIACÁN, Mexico — When José Antonio Sevilla and his three brothers learned that the notorious drug trafficker known as El Chapo had escaped from prison, they jumped out of their chairs and shouted with glee.

headline: How John Mattera, Shipwreck Explorer, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Mattera, a Staten Island diver, takes a break from searching for sunken treasure by visiting parks with his children, taking walks and getting cocktails with his wife.
lead_paragraph: “I find shipwrecks,” John Mattera said the other day, when asked to describe what he does for a living. No, really, that’s what he does: search for sunken treasure. Mr. Mattera, 53, a former nightclub owner, bodyguard, moneylender and Staten Island tough guy, is a subject of Robert Kurson’s new book, “Pirate Hunters: Treasure, Obsession and the Search for a Legendary Pirate Ship,” about a quest for 17th-century booty in the seas around the Dominican Republic. It’s a yarn with plenty of guns and danger and breathless prose. Between dives, Mr. Mattera stays closer to home, doing research and writing and — along with his wife, Carolina — raising their three children, ages 8 months to 4, in the Great Kills section of Staten Island. His daughter from his previous marriage lives nearby.

In a memorable episode of “Louie,” Louis C.K. ultimately gives up on deciphering a group of contradictory parking signs. When he comes back later, his car is being destroyed by city workers.

headline: Lasting Art, a Flower Store Where Everything Is 100% Fake
abstract: The shop, in Manhattan’s flower district, carries items including faux flowers and plastic champagne glasses.
lead_paragraph: Now that it’s summer, the sidewalks of West 28th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues have been transformed into miniature forests as merchants display their wares for weekend shoppers. Rows of tiny succulents, potted perennials and even small, graceful Japanese maple trees are neatly lined up at the curb along both sides of the street. Long serving both professional floral arrangers and civilian plant lovers, these stores are what remain of the New York’s once expansive floral district.

headline: Recalling Marlene Sanders, a Force in TV Journalism
abstract: A television journalist is remembered for her forthrightness and determination by her son and by women for whom she was a pioneer.
lead_paragraph: In 2000, Cynthia McFadden, the senior legal and investigative correspondent for NBC News, attended a party given by her friend Jeffrey Toobin, a staff writer for The New Yorker and legal analyst for CNN. There, Ms. McFadden was catching up with Mr. Toobin’s mother, Marlene Sanders, the pioneering television reporter. She asked for her advice on managing motherhood and a career.

headline: Review: ‘Monchichi,’ a Love Story in Different Languages
abstract: Company Wang Ramirez’s show at Jacob’s Pillow Dance crosses hip-hop with tanztheater.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — A ballerina and a b-boy fall in love. It sounds like the setup for a sentimental American movie about people with radically different backgrounds connecting. But what if she is German, with a Korean mother? And what if he is French, with Spanish and Catalonian parents? That sounds not just like a European variation but also one with potentially less predictable complications.

headline: Merger Vote at Samsung Is Not the End for the Lee Family
abstract: The narrow victory shows that serious opposition is finally emerging against the chaebols, the powerful family-run conglomerates that dominate in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: The Lee family behind Samsung must be breathing a heavy sigh of relief. Its plans for an $8 billion merger of two Samsung affiliates, Samsung C&T and Cheil Industries, was narrowly approved on Friday by shareholders. The move came despite strong opposition from by Elliott Management, the hedge fund led by Paul E. Singer.

headline: A Courtyard Idyll Beside the High Line
abstract: Two friends met at Alta Linea, outside at the High Line Hotel, rain be damned.
lead_paragraph: Tenth Avenue in the 20s is not usually thought of as an idyllic spot, but Alta Linea, in the tree-lined courtyard of the High Line Hotel (itself once part of the General Theological Seminary), makes it work with al fresco tables under white umbrellas, strings of white lights and lanterns in the trees and a bubbling fountain. The frozen Negronis ($14) might help, too.

lead_paragraph: Woman, says the woman dressed as a man in a bowler hat, is “an imperfect animal.” That’s because, as her vaudevillian partner points out, the female of the species “was formed from a bent rib.”

headline: From the Vault of the Museum at Fraunces Tavern: A Drinks Kit
abstract: The Manhattan landmark, where Washington bade farewell to his troops, holds items like a Martha Washington slipper and a camp chest from Baron von Steuben, a Continental Army general.
lead_paragraph: Every patriotic New Yorker worth his or her weight in saltpeter knows that the 253-year-old Fraunces Tavern (the actual edifice was built in 1719) is the site where, in 1783, a war-weary George Washington bade a tearful farewell to his troops. Six years later the former commander in chief retook the title as America’s first president in the country’s first capital.

headline: Men’s Wear Designers Lead the Pack for the CFDA/Vogue Award

lead_paragraph: It may have been just a coincidence, but it was somehow fitting that the nominees for this year’s CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Award were announced on Wednesday, right in the middle of the men’s wear shows being held in New York.

headline: Jerrod Carmichael’s Comedy, and Tourism, Call for Reflection
abstract: The soon-to-be sitcom star’s astute observations are central to his stand-up and his sightseeing in New York.
lead_paragraph: Jerrod Carmichael slipped into the glass atrium of the Whitney Museum of American Art recently with 45 minutes to spare before closing time. The 27-year-old comic was in New York to promote his coming NBC sitcom, “The Carmichael Show,” and, after a long day of interviews, was taking in a few sights before heading back to Los Angeles.

They mingled with other generations — throngs of government workers, young law students inspired by recent protests, and even a few lesser-known legends of that struggle.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — For decades, Germany saw its role as the financier and beneficiary of European unity, a combination of penance for the past and self-interest. The rest of the Continent came to rely on it as the country that could be trusted to keep its great experiment moving forward.

headline: At New York Fashion Week: Men’s, California Was the Muse
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Men and Boys', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: For their first New York fashion week in more than a decade, men’s wear designers, old-guard and newcomers alike, looked west for inspiration.
lead_paragraph: In the language of recovery programs, folks who try to run from their problems by constantly changing location are “pulling a geographic.” Returning to New York after more than a decade away, the men’s fashion week that finished up Thursday took a generally sober approach to the buzzed and almost giddy excitement that has lately attached itself to men’s wear.

headline: A Play on Words
abstract: If “Hamilton” survives the huge audiences, expensive tickets and high demands of Broadway, it will speak well of the potential relationship between quality and popularity — a connection we like to champion through the stories we tell in T.
lead_paragraph: All of us who have ever been (or had) a sulky teenager who considers time spent adjacent to adults an impossible drag can imagine that being taken to a play on the life of the American founding father Alexander Hamilton might represent a special kind of hell. The suspicion that your parents may be trying to inject history or culture straight into your brain adds fuel to the offense. That it is a musical performed in rap does little to mitigate the insult. Hip-hop politics?! Please!

headline: My Digital Cemetery
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Smartphones', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Deleting the name of a dead friend from your phone can feel like removing that person from the world.
lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, GA. — MY digital address book lists 2,743 contacts. This is not because I’m popular or extroverted; I’m neither. It’s because this collection of names stretches back two decades, the oldest contacts tracing to a 1996 Palm Pilot and preserved through transfers involving more devices than I care to remember. It covers life in four cities and work on countless reporting projects. The idea of organizing and pruning this slow-motion data dump is by now unthinkable.

headline: From White Sharks to Tigers, Can We Get Comfortable with Carnivores?
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE', 'Sharks', 'Tigers']

headline: Inside T’s Summer Entertainment Issue
abstract: The Broadway visionary behind “Hamilton,” a jewel of a home in New Orleans’ Garden District, and so much more.
lead_paragraph: T’s latest issue is all about entertainment. On the cover is Lin-Manuel Miranda, the Broadway visionary whose groundbreaking musical, “Hamilton,” recasts an oft-overlooked American founding father as a hip-hop renegade. We talk to the Tony-winning dramaturge, as well as the cadre of collaborators and confidants (including Stephen Sondheim and Questlove of the Roots) who helped bring his vision to life. We also swing by the happiest place on Earth — Disneyland — where one father revels in the power of suspended disbelief. And lest we forgot that other kind of entertaining — at which photographer Paul Costello and his wife, Sara Ruffin Costello, are so adept — we visit the couple’s home in New Orleans’s Garden District for a lesson in Southern hospitality. Elsewhere in the issue, T gets familiar with Christine and the Queens, a French music sensation who relies on originality, rather than sex, in her bid for pop stardom; Liesl Schillinger makes the case for modest summer suppers in an age of Carrara countertops and Instagram-worthy cooking; Alice Gregory explores the 50-year-old planned community of Sea Ranch, Calif., where the Modernist housing and embrace of nature are surprisingly of the moment; and the filmmaker Errol Morris and the actress Parker Posey try out 3D wallpaper, a healthy tequila drink and an adult coloring book — with predictably amusing results. See all stories from this issue >>

Mr. Netanyahu’s office released a statement saying that the prime minister had told President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority that “the citizens of Israel want peace” and that “Israel would continue to act toward regional stability.” Palestinian news agencies reported that Mr. Abbas responded that it was important to reach a peace accord in the coming year. In the 13 months since the two men last spoke, in June 2014, Israel fought a devastating war with Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip, and Mr. Abbas led the Palestinian Authority to join the International Criminal Court and pressed for Palestinian statehood through other international forums.

lead_paragraph: At least 50 people were killed in a suicide car bombing in a central marketplace in eastern Iraq on Friday, as people shopped for Eid al-Fitr, the Muslim holiday that marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan, the authorities said. The attack took place in the heart of Khan Bani Saad township, a mostly Shiite area about a dozen miles from Baquba, the capital of Diyala Province. At least 90 people were wounded, and some reports said that as many as 80 may have died. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing, although the Islamic State has carried out a number of bombings in predominantly Shiite areas of Iraq.

headline: Maine: Ex-Convict Arrested in Rampage That Killed Two
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Assaults', 'ARSON']
abstract: A man with a long criminal history shot five people, two fatally, during a spree before being apprehended Friday near the Canadian border, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man with a long criminal history shot five people, two fatally, during a nightlong spree before being apprehended on Friday near the Canadian border, the police said. The man, Anthony Lord, 35, faces murder and kidnapping charges. Mr. Lord is also suspected of starting a barn fire, stealing weapons and two vehicles, assaulting one person and leading officers on a chase. The authorities did not have a motive. Mr. Lord is a registered sex offender in Maine. The Bangor Daily News reported that he had been convicted of theft and domestic violence assault, among other charges. Lt. Sean Hashey of the Maine State Police said the sequence began Thursday night with a fire at a barn in Benedicta. Early Friday, a man was beaten in nearby Silver Ridge Township, and his truck and weapons were stolen. Later, Kyle Hewitt, 22, was shot dead and Kim Irish, 55, was wounded at the residence where the barn burned. Mr. Lord, the police said, left the scene with Ms. Irish’s daughter, Brittany Irish, 22. Another man, Carlton Eddy, who drove by the scene, was shot in the shoulder. Police later received a call about a shooting at a woodlot in Lee, about 40 miles south of Benedicta. Kevin Tozier, 58, was killed and Clayton McCarthy, 54, was injured there. A truck was stolen from that scene, and officers searching for it found Mr. Lord and Ms. Irish at his relative’s home in Houlton.

headline: Texas: Officer Placed on Desk Duty After Woman Is Found Dead in Cell

abstract: A police officer who arrested a woman who later was found hanged in her cell has been placed on desk duty after a preliminary review by the state.
lead_paragraph: A police officer who arrested a woman who later was found hanged in her cell has been placed on desk duty after a preliminary review by the Texas Department of Public Safety. The department said it found violations of “procedures regarding traffic stops and the department’s courtesy policy” in the arrest of the woman, Sandra Bland, on July 10. The officer was not named. Ms. Bland was arrested after a traffic stop in Prairie View on charges of assaulting a public servant and was found hanged three days later. The Harris County medical examiner ruled her death a suicide, but family and friends dispute that. They said Ms. Bland, who was black, was a vocal opponent of police brutality and they have accused the local police of a role in her death.

headline: Pakistan: Senior Political Officials Arrested in Karachi

The Pakistan Rangers, the paramilitary force that provides law enforcement for the city, sealed off all roads leading to the party’s fortified headquarters a few hours after midnight, the authorities said. A spokesman for the Rangers said the party officials were charged with “arranging and facilitating hate speeches against the people of Karachi.” The raid and arrests were the latest blow to Altaf Hussain, the party’s embattled leader, who has controlled the fortunes of Karachi, Pakistan’s largest city and its economic and commercial hub, for nearly a quarter-century while operating from self-imposed exile in London.

headline: 1890: The Pope Leaves The Vatican in Broad Daylight
abstract: Pope Leo XIII left his self-imposed captivity in the Vatican and drove out to his summer residence in 1890.
lead_paragraph: The fact that the Pope has driven out of the Vatican in broad daylight and shown himself in the streets of Rome is a political event of no small importance, since it destroys the fiction that he is a prisoner. Apparently His Holiness has decided that he will no longer risk his health in order to comply with the wishes of the party which seeks to make political capital by requiring him to imprison himself. Everybody remembers Artemus Ward’s story of the prisoner who one day had a happy thought — that of opening the window and walking out. Now that the Pope has had the happy thought of opening the gates of the Vatican and driving through the streets, the Cardinals who have insisted that he was a prisoner will not be pleased to have their legend so completely contradicted, for nothing could show more plainly that, for the present at least, their influence is no longer dominant. The Pope may now be expected to withdraw to Castel Gundolfi for the rest of the hot season, as was in former days the invariable custom of his predecessors. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 19, 1890

lead_paragraph: Whenever­ we talk about happiness we also talk about something else: morality. We may not know what happiness itself signifies, but we do know how it has been evoked historically — to set out a template for a moral life. As we rush to make happiness the ultimate aim both for ourselves and society at large, we might want to recall some of the wonderfully rich and depressingly contradictory history of the concept. This might help us better understand our own time and the moral values we subscribe to today.

headline: Iraq: Toll Rises in Market Bombing
abstract: The Islamic State group has claimed responsibility for a bombing in eastern Iraq, and officials on Saturday said that the death toll had risen to 100 people, with 20 more missing.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State group has claimed responsibility for a bombing in eastern Iraq, and officials on Saturday said that the death toll had risen to 100 people, with 20 more missing. The bomb tore through a marketplace on Friday in Khan Bani Saad, above, a mostly Shiite town in Diyala Province. It also wounded at least 133 people, the police said, and destroyed several buildings. Government troops and Shiite militias months ago wrested back parts of the province from the Islamic State group, also known as ISIS or ISIL. In a statement taking responsibility for the blast, ISIS, which has often singled out Shiites as targets, declared that the attack was revenge for what it called a massacre of Sunnis in the town of Hawija farther north. The statement may have been referring to an episode in March, during a battle that eventually drove ISIS from Tikrit. Residents of Hawija reported at the time that dozens of ISIS fighters had been killed by their commanders for trying to flee the battlefield. ISIS, which follows an extremist interpretation of Sunni Islam, views Shiites as apostates and has often targeted Shiite civilians. Its statement declared that it used three tons of explosives to kill and injure more than 180 “apostates.” Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said that ISIS was targeting civilians in revenge for recent government advances.

headline: China: 2 Relatives of a Tibetan Monk Who Died in Prison Have Been Arrested
abstract: The authorities in southwest China have reportedly detained two relatives of a prominent Tibetan monk whose unexplained death in prison set off protests that left dozens injured after it was announced on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in southwest China have reportedly detained two relatives of a prominent Tibetan monk whose unexplained death in prison set off protests that left dozens injured after it was announced on Monday. According to Students for a Free Tibet, an overseas advocacy group, the police on Friday detained the sister and niece of Tenzin Delek Rinpoche, 65, a widely revered monk and community leader who was serving a life sentence on terrorism and separatism charges. Human rights advocates contend that the allegations against him were politically motivated. He died in a prison near Chengdu, the provincial capital of Sichuan, under circumstances that the authorities have yet to explain. On Thursday, prison officials, brushing aside the pleas of family members and supporters, cremated his body rather than allow them to carry out traditional Buddhist funeral rites. Witnesses say the relatives, Dolkar Lhamo, 52, and her daughter, Nyima Lhamo, 25, were detained in Chengdu on Friday, according to Padma Dolma, campaigns director for Students for a Free Tibet. Dolkar Lhamo and another sister were among nearly 100 Tibetans who staged a sit-in outside the building in Chengdu where Tenzin Delek was thought to have been imprisoned for the 13 years before he died.

headline: Hillary Clinton Draws Scrappy Determination From a Tough, Combative Father
abstract: Mrs. Clinton rarely talks publicly about her father, Hugh E. Rodham, who exerted a powerful, if sometimes bruising, influence on her life before he died in 1993.
lead_paragraph: As a little girl, if Hillary Rodham forgot to screw the cap back on the toothpaste, her father would toss the tube out the bathroom window. She’d scurry around in the snow-covered evergreen bushes outside their suburban Chicago home to find it and return inside to brush her teeth, reminded, once again, of one of Hugh E. headline: After Cancer’s Calm, a Daughter’s Emotional Storm
abstract: During all the year of dealing with her parents’ cancers, I never saw my daughter cry.
lead_paragraph: I’m the only mother I know who is happy to see her daughter cry. Not because she deserves to, but because after everything she has faced, her tears are our first glimpse of emotions that have been missing for a very long time.

lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — They came to see history, the fans who poured into this seaside town this week, roaming around the course in the rain and cold and wind. They came to see history, and they just might.

headline: 1915: Russians Gain Success Against Austro-German Onslaught
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Russian and Austro-German troops clash in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fighting is in progress along practically the entire Russian front, extending for a thousand miles from the Baltic to the Bukowina. Despite the activity of the enemy in Courland and on the Narew front, the Germans’ great effort is apparently being made between the Vistula and the Bug, immediately south of the Lublin-Kholm railway, where General von Mackensen has been rapidly accumulating reinforcements during the recent lull in the fighting and now disposes of armies amounting to almost 2,000,000 men.

headline: 1940: Italy Sending Mission to Syria to Disband the French
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Italy planned to move into Syria in 1940.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Italy, it was learned here tonight [July 19], is making the final arrangements to dispatch a military mission to Syria to arrange there details of the demobilization of the French Army of the Near East, which is under the command of Gen. Eugene Mittelhauser. In some quarters it is thought that the disclosure that Rome is taking this step may prove the signal for some action by the British forces in the eastern Mediterranean calculated to insure that Syria shall not be left in a position to serve as a potential base for enemy operations.

headline: The Euroskeptic Vindication
abstract: Economics worked, again.
lead_paragraph: One theme I’ve returned to often in this blog is that far from failing in the crisis, more or less conventional Hicks/Keynes macroeconomics — whether or not you dress it up in New Keynesian algebra — has performed very well. The quiescence of interest rates and inflation despite large budget deficits and huge increases in the monetary base, the strong negative correlation between fiscal austerity and growth, all have been just what someone who knew his or her IS-LM and took it seriously would have predicted. Anti-Keynesians keep making more or less desperate efforts to refute this proposition, usually by taking something I said out of context and pretending that something that happened for one year somewhere or other is contrary to what the Evil One claimed. But the overall shape of events has been very Keynesian, and very much at odds with alternative stories.

headline: Kanye West-Steve McQueen Video to Have American Premiere in Los Angeles

They have, and the result, an extended or expanded sort of music video, makes its American debut on Saturday at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Called “All Day/I Feel Like That,” the video will run in a gallery for four days during regular museum hours.

headline: Express Bus Service Shows Promise in New York

lead_paragraph: Last week, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled its first express bus line: the 86th Street crosstown, running back and forth between York Avenue on the east side and Broadway on the west. There was a news conference to celebrate, at Columbus Avenue. Polly Trottenberg, the mayor’s transportation commissioner, hailed “modest investments” yielding dividends in terms of saved time for long-beleaguered riders, to which Ben Kallos, a city councilman, added that time saved translates into revenue for businesses whose taxes help pay for further transit improvements: a virtuous circle.

headline: Review: The Cleveland Orchestra Plays Strauss With Abundant Color

As its stars, KT Sullivan and Jeff Harnar, dug into Mr. Sondheim’s catalog, it was as though they had suddenly grown up.

headline: The ‘Wire’ Cast Gathers
abstract: Cast members of HBO’s “The Wire” gathered in Baltimore to reflect upon the recent unrest in the city and pay homage to its residents.
lead_paragraph: Cast members of HBO’s “The Wire” gathered at the Modell Performing Arts Center at the Lyric in Baltimore on Saturday to reflect upon the recent unrest in the city and pay homage to its residents. The event, “Wired Up!,” was part of the annual Baltimore arts festival Artscape and featured the cast members Michael K. Williams, Sonja Sohn, Andre Royo and Larry Gilliard Jr. The sold-out event came about thanks to Ms. Sohn and her fellow cast member Maria Broom, who interviewed residents in West Baltimore about their experiences during the protests after the death of the young black man Freddie Gray. They turned the interviews into monologues that were read in tandem by the residents, including single mothers and self-professed gang members, and actors from the show. Dominic West and Wendell Pierce, two of the show’s stars, and the director David Simon were not present, but sent video messages.

abstract: Greece is expected to pay 4.25 billion euros due on bonds; later this week, earnings reports will be announced by Apple, Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse and General Motors.
lead_paragraph: After receiving a short-term loan from the European Union last week, Greece is expected to pay 4.25 billion euros ($4.6 billion) due on bonds held by the European Central Bank, as well as €2 billion in overdue payments to the International Monetary Fund. Failure to pay the E.C.B. would have forced the bank to cut off emergency funding for Greek banks, causing them and the Greek economy to collapse. The debt payments represent a step back from the precipice of a eurozone exit for Greece, but the government led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras must cope this week with the political turmoil caused by his decision to accept unpleasant conditions set by eurozone creditors in return for financial aid. In a move toward normalcy, Greek banks reopened on Monday. —Jack Ewing

abstract: How fantasy economics led to disaster.

Greece is experiencing a slump worse than the Great Depression, and nothing happening now offers hope of recovery. Spain has been hailed as a success story, because its economy is finally growing — but it still has 22 percent unemployment. And there is an arc of stagnation across the continent’s top: Finland is experiencing a depression comparable to that in southern Europe, and Denmark and the Netherlands are also doing very badly.

keywords: ['Methadone', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Heroin', 'Buprenorphine (Drug)', 'Addiction (Psychology)']
abstract: Indefinite maintenance is a proven treatment for drug addiction. All drug courts should allow it. But they don’t.
lead_paragraph: WHEN an old offense caught up with 28-year-old Robert Lepolszki last year, he had a full-time job and had kicked heroin. But Frank Gulotta Jr., the Nassau County judge assigned to his case, forced him to end the only treatment that had ever worked: methadone maintenance. Judge Gulotta said that methadone does not enable a defendant “to actually rid him or herself of the addiction.” Complete abstinence programs were the only treatments his court allowed. Not long after stopping the medication, Mr. Lepolszki was dead from an overdose.

headline: Alex Guarnaschelli’s Variation on Summer Corn
keywords: ['Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Food', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Hamburgers', 'Candy']
abstract: A new version of Mexican street food; another burger blend from Pat LaFrieda; nut brittle in rectangles; and more.
lead_paragraph: Ready for a variation on fresh summer corn? Consider Alex Guarnaschelli’s take on Mexican street food. It’s lip-smacking good with drinks in the secluded backyard garden at the Cassa Hotel, home of her restaurant, Butter. And it’s easily done at home. She swaps out the usual salty cotija cheese for less-forceful ricotta salata. To make it, shuck and briefly boil 6 ears corn, and melt 6 tablespoons unsalted butter. Season 2 tablespoons mayonnaise with 1 teaspoon ancho chile powder (or to taste), ½ teaspoon Spanish sweet paprika and a spritz of lemon; mix with 4 tablespoons sour cream. Spread ⅓ pound crumbled ricotta salata on a plate. Daub the corn with butter and grill until lightly charred. Break each cob in thirds. Brush with the sour cream mixture and roll in cheese. Dust with salt, pepper and chives and serve: Butter, Cassa Hotel, 70 West 45th Street, 212-253-2828, butterrestaurant.com.

In Mr. Ilyin’s view, the government would not control all aspects of society, but in certain important areas would be “dictatorial in the scope of its powers.”

He would plumb the catacomb-like tunnels beneath the prison, where he was serving a life sentence for murder, searching for an escape route, confident that the guards would have no idea he was gone because they were asleep. headline: At Home, One Dean and DeLuca Founder Can’t Stop Drawing
abstract: In East Hampton, Jack Ceglic invites people to sit in his small studio, where he simply sketches them — or sketches them simply. A series of his portraits go on view this week in Amagansett.
lead_paragraph: In a lofted studio steps away from his industrial-style East Hampton home, the Dean and DeLuca co-founder Jack Ceglic is constantly drawing people. In the past two months alone, he has used the simple, bright space to complete 143 portraits of “people that I meet at dinner parties or socially who I think have something very special about them,” he says. “They kind of glow, and I’m drawn to them.” And in return, they come to sit for him. Each subject wades through the tall grass that surrounds the open, single-room building, toward the faint notes of whatever Joseph Haydn symphony is emanating from his workspace at that moment, and enters through a floor-to-ceiling window that swings open like a garage door. This week, 26 of his compositions will be on view in his second solo exhibition, “Aura,” at ILLE Arts gallery in Amagansett.

headline: Iran: Reporter’s Espionage Trial May Be Nearing End, Editor Says
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: After three hearings in Tehran, the fourth was likely to be the last for the Washington Post correspondent, although no date has been set.
lead_paragraph: The secretive trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who has been imprisoned for nearly a year, may soon be over, the newspaper’s executive editor, Martin Baron, said Monday. In a statement, he said the correspondent’s Iranian lawyer, Leila Ahsan, had been told that after three hearings in Tehran over the past two months, the fourth was likely to be the last, although no date has been set. Mr. Rezaian faces up to 20 years in prison on charges that include espionage. He has asserted his innocence since his arrest last July 22, and Ms. Ahsan has said there is no evidence to support the charges. Mr. Baron, who has denounced the prosecution as ludicrous, said in the statement that “it is long past time for the Iranian authorities to bring this process to an end.” Mr. Rezaian is one of at least three Americans held in Iran, an issue that has become more pressing to their relatives and supporters since an international deal on the country’s disputed nuclear activities was reached last week, potentially easing the estranged relations between Washington and Tehran. Also on Monday, the Committee to Protect Journalists, a press advocacy group, published a letter  to Sadeq Larijani, the head of Iran’s judiciary, asking him to “ensure that this case is resolved immediately.”

headline: When the Internet’s ‘Moderators’ Are Anything But
keywords: ['English Language', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The title suggests a steward of civility and decency. But online, unpaid moderators can become a force for mayhem.
lead_paragraph: Let us begin with a toast to the unsung hero of the social-media age: the moderator. Slayer of Internet trolls! Extinguisher of flame wars! Bulwark against race hatred and child pornography! The Internet as we know it could not exist without moderators, constantly pruning back the wild undergrowth of human nature that proliferates there. Nearly every major commercial site with user content is policed by human moderators. Some are unpaid volunteers who agree to enforce administrators’ rules; others are outsourced workers in the Philippines who flag dirty pictures posted to social media, or domestic employees who delete libelous comments. If you want to see what the Internet looks like without moderators … well, I’m not even going to tell you where to go, because we’d all be raided by the F.B.I. Let’s just say it’s immoderate.

In addition to the boots, he wears black drop-crotch sweatpants and a gray tank top that soon becomes drenched in sweat. His nails sparkle with dark green glittery polish. He’s still a little wobbly on the platform heels and exaggerates the swing of his hips, but when the choreography calls for a high kick, his leg stretches up almost impossibly above his shoulders. He drops to the floor and rolls his body from head to toe with an impressively liquid suppleness. When he turns, his smile is bashful, modest.

headline: Jeff Koons’s Suggestions for What to See, Read and Do This Summer
abstract: The artist shares what he’s up to this season — and what, in a perfect world, he’d like to be doing.
lead_paragraph: With exhibitions around the globe, the contemporary artist Jeff Koons has had a travel-filled summer — but it hasn’t been all work and no play. At the season’s start, he flew off to Bilbao, Spain for the opening of his major retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum there (the same one that originally debuted at the Whitney in New York before then being installed at Paris’s Centre Pompidou). After that, he headed straight to his family farm in York, Pennsylvania, as he does this time of year with his wife Justine and the six of his eight children that still live at home. At the property once owned by his grandfather, and which Koons refers to simply as “the country,” the man known for balloon sculptures and playful, larger-than-life structures carpeted in live, flowering plants (and a handful of risqué oil paintings) passes the warm summer months playing baseball with his offspring, practicing batting and catching skills at night — and occasionally watching the Phillies, Nationals and Yankees play.

headline: Restaurant Review: Lupulo in Chelsea
abstract: The flavor and feel of a Portuguese beer hall come through loud and clear.
lead_paragraph: If George Mendes did not have such a strong grip on the flavors and aromas of Portugal, Lupulo might have slipped away from him. It can be a confusing restaurant at first, its messages mixed, its fairly simple concept fuzzed over with complications. But give the place a chance, and you can find clarity in the smells of garlic and wood smoke that fill the dining room; in the way sweet paprika and cilantro sidle up to each other in olive oil; and in the fresh, firm seafood, the grilled sardines and carabineros, red as a lobster, their heads dripping with juices that are as rich and intense as any sauce. The restaurant may be unfocused, but the cooking isn’t.

headline: Scientists Trace an Ancient DNA Link Between Amazonians and Australasians
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Genealogy', 'Research', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Two papers agree that some people in the Brazilian Amazon are distant relations of indigenous Australians, New Guineans and other Australasians, but they disagree on the source of the ancestry.
lead_paragraph: Some people in the Brazilian Amazon are very distant relations of indigenous Australians, New Guineans and other Australasians, two groups of scientists who conducted detailed genetic analyses reported Tuesday. But the researchers disagree on the source of that ancestry.

headline: Classical Playlist: Christiane Karg, Alan Feinberg and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: ‘SCENE!’ Christiane Karg, soprano; Arcangelo; Jonathan Cohen, conductor(Berlin Classics)This soprano’s latest recital recording of six concert arias has everything one could wish for. Her refined voice is wonderfully pliable, her sense of text acute. Haydn and Mozart dominate, but there’s a welcome push toward repertoire normally associated with a heavier voice in Beethoven’s “Ah! perfido” as well as a rarity, Mendelssohn’s radiant, later stormy “Infelice pensier.” Add the stylish, often tumultuous playing of Mr. Cohen’s period orchestra and a charming guest appearance on fortepiano by Malcolm Martineau in Mozart’s “Ch’io mi scordi di te?” and this disc makes an immediate impression. (David Allen)

headline: No Schmear, but Selfies Are Welcomed
abstract: Two towers of bagels — sculptures made of styrene and polyurethane — were installed in New York.
lead_paragraph: The artist Hanna Liden, from Stockholm, was unfamiliar with bagels until she moved to New York. Now she has fashioned her own in styrene and polyurethane in an installation sponsored partly by the Art Production Fund. On Monday, two towers of bagels — plain, everything, sesame and pumpernickel — rose at Hudson River Park, seen here, and the Ruth Wittenberg Triangle in the West Village. A single bagel also appears outside the flagship Kiehl’s store, in the East Village; the company was a backer of the project.

headline: Critics of Solitary Confinement Are Buoyed as Obama Embraces Their Cause
abstract: An estimated 75,000 state and federal prisoners are held in solitary confinement in the United States. This is too many, President Obama argues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before he was exonerated of murder and released in 2010, Anthony Graves spent 18 years locked up in a Texas prison, 16 of them all alone in a tiny cell.

headline: Nationals Could Use Some Help. Mets Could Use It More.

headline: Germany’s Top Court Strikes Down Federal Aid for Home Child Care
abstract: The Federal Constitutional Court ruled that it is illegal for the federal government to pay parents who chose to care for their toddlers at home.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s highest court ruled on Tuesday that it was illegal for the federal government to pay parents who chose to care for their toddlers at home, rather than send them to publicly subsidized day care, striking down a program that was touted by conservatives.

headline: At Vatican, Mayors Pledge Climate Change Fight
abstract: The two-day conference was the first time the Vatican specifically invited local officials to address the issue, hoping to keep pressure on world leaders.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — About 60 mayors from around the world gathered here on Tuesday and pledged to combat global warming and help the poor deal with its effects, at a conference swiftly organized by the Vatican barely a month after Pope Francis’ sweeping encyclical on the environment.

headline: Denver Church’s Security Efforts Highlight New Reality
abstract: At the Potter’s House of Denver, which uses armed guards and surveillance cameras, the shooting in Charleston, S.C., was a reminder of the importance of security measures.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Armed guards, security patrols and surveillance cameras — at the Potter’s House of Denver, they are just another part of Sunday services, like prayer, psalms and sermons. Much of the security effort is hidden so it does not interfere with worship, but church leaders insist that the military-style protocols are necessary.

headline: Security Researchers Find a Way to Hack Cars
abstract: Early next month, two security researchers plan to detail how they were able to hack into a Jeep remotely and control the lights, brakes and steering from the Internet. Their discovery impacts some cars sold by Fiat Chrysler from late 2013 to 2015.
lead_paragraph: Some cars can now be hacked.

headline: Why It Will Be Hard for Obama to Downsize Prisons

headline: Cellphone Ordinance Puts Berkeley at Forefront of Radiation Debate
abstract: A city measure requiring retailers to warn cellphone customers about radiation exposure is on hold pending a lawsuit from the wireless industry.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Leave it to Berkeley: This city, which has led the nation in passing all manner of laws favored by the left, has done it again. This time, the city passed a measure — not actually backed by science — requiring cellphone stores to warn customers that the products could be hazardous to their health, presumably by emitting dangerous levels of cancer-causing radiation.

headline: Sail Amsterdam 2015 Set for August
abstract: The nautical festival will host 43 tall ships and begin with a parade of hundreds of historic ships along the North Sea Canal.
lead_paragraph: The nautical festival Sail Amsterdam 2015, from Aug. 19 to 23, will host 43 tall ships, including 13 first-timers from around the world. The free event, held every five years in the Netherlands’ capital since 1975, begins with the 7.5-mile-long Sail-In parade, which also features four Dutch Marine vessels, marine training ships from 11 countries, and hundreds of historic ships and replicas, all sailing in line along the North Sea Canal from IJmuiden to Amsterdam.

headline: Chris Christie, Springsteen Superfan, Puts Bon Jovi Ahead of the Boss

lead_paragraph: Theirs is a tale of two star-crossed New Jerseyans: a rock-and-roll hall-of-famer with a decidedly leftist political bent, and one of his most passionate fans — who is also the state’s Republican leader.

headline: A History of France’s Love Affair With the Bicycle
abstract: Elaine Sciolino ponders the country’s historically romanticized cycling culture.
lead_paragraph: As Tour de France bikers furiously pedal their way to the Champs-Élysées for their July 26 finish, this American in Paris contemplates the culture of the bicycle in France. Consider bike-sharing. New Yorkers are latecomers to the phenomenon; Citi Bike began only two years ago. Bike-loving Parisians, by contrast, are old hands. They’ve been getting around town on rent-to-ride two-wheelers since 2007. Their system, called Vélib’, now has more than 1,000 stations and about 18,000 bikes.

headline: As a Broadcaster, Greg LeMond Returns to Tour de France’s Embrace
abstract: After a long, deliberate absence from the Tour, LeMond, a three-time winner, has quickly become the face of cycling on Eurosport, which broadcasts the event live.
lead_paragraph: GAP, France — Lance Armstrong’s reappearance on the fringes of the Tour de France last week was greeted at the race with the sort of enthusiasm usually reserved for bad odors. That is in stark contrast to Greg LeMond, another American Tour winner, who not only received a warm reception when he returned last year, but who is increasingly becoming an institution.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — A 24-year-old man was charged Tuesday with plotting to run over an American serviceman stationed in Britain and then kill him with a knife in an attack echoing the daylight slaughter of a British soldier on a London street two years ago.

headline: Review: ‘White People’ Looks at a Majority in an Ever More Diverse America
abstract: This MTV documentary by Jose Antonio Vargas studies college-age whites’ perception of their status.
lead_paragraph: “White People” is a challenging title, and a trailer for the MTV documentary that bears it drew criticism  from conservative pundits last week. The show itself, however, shouldn’t upset anyone when it makes its premiere on Wednesday night. Its exploration of how young white people see themselves and their status in an increasingly diverse America is earnest and upbeat, going out of its way to avoid blame or bad feelings.

headline: Listen: Donald Trump’s Future
abstract: On the Times Insider podcast, Andrew Rosenthal discusses recent comments by Mr. Trump and other Republican presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the Times’s editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal took a look at some comments made by the presidential candidates Donald Trump, Chris Christie and Ted Cruz. “Not only are the crazy things they say crazier than what the average Republican says,” he wrote, “they really don’t have anything at all to say that’s worth hearing.” This week, he discussed some of those candidates on the Times Insider podcast. He noted that Mr. Trump had seen some fallout from his comments about Mexican immigrants, with Univision and others severing their ties with him. “It’s possible that Donald Trump will worry about losing business,” Mr. Rosenthal said. “On the other hand, this is who he is.”

headline: Ground Rules for Body Shimmer
abstract: The celebrity makeup artist Fiona Stiles offers tips for that just-got-back-from-vacation look.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to summer beauty products, body shimmer is the lovable but gorgeous ditz. It has nothing to do with efficacy or even practicality, but it sure is pretty. Yet even though there are innovative and upscale versions (like the new golden Nuxe shower oil, $15, and the Omorovicza shimmer oil, $80, that I’m favoring lately — it has actual gold particles and practically screams “yacht party in Hvar”), allover shimmer runs the risk of looking tawdry.

If social media and recent red carpets are an indication, décolletage is in vogue. See: social media darlings like Emily Ratajkowski and the D.J. May Kwok flaunting the plunging ’70s-era look on Instagram. (One risqué bodysuit, a black lace-up style by Reformation, has been a particular hit.)

headline: Reviving a Harry Partch Work With Hubcaps and Wine Bottles

lead_paragraph: Some looked like Picasso’s wooden sculptures. A few others might have been designed by Rube Goldberg. In fact, the contraptions jumbled backstage at City Center this week were musical instruments — painstaking re-creations of the whimsical, ingenious instruments invented and built by Harry Partch, a truly unusual 20th-century American composer, theorist and tinkerer whose works created a unique soundscape based on a tonal system all his own.

headline: In Chelsea, Art for Bibliophiles
abstract: Shows on view at three galleries this summer celebrate the written word.
lead_paragraph: It’s summer reading time at three Chelsea galleries: This season, Fredericks & Freiser, Sean Kelly and Paul Kasmin are all exhibiting work that integrates text and image, celebrating the written word and contemporary literature through visual art. At Fredericks & Freiser, the artist Sam Messer has collaborated with the literary luminaries Jonathan Safran Foer and Denis Johnson to produce sculptures, paintings, drawings, prints and a stop-motion animated video called “Denis the Pirate.” The actor Liev Schreiber narrates the film, while the indie-music mainstays Sarah Neufeld (of the Arcade Fire) and Colin Stetson provide the score. In “Atlas of Stress and Anxiety,” arrows and scribbled text describe elements of a drawing that looks very much like Safran Foer’s face in front of a laptop. headline: Yemen: Ship Loaded With Food Aid Reaches Aden
abstract: The World Food Program said the vessel, the MV Han Zhi, was loaded with 3,000 metric tons of food, enough to feed 180,000 people for one month.
lead_paragraph: A ship full of aid chartered by the World Food Program, the United Nations’ antihunger agency, berthed Tuesday in Yemen’s southern port of Aden, the agency reported. It was the first vessel chartered by the agency to reach Aden since the Yemen conflict escalated nearly four months ago, when a Saudi Arabia-led bombing campaign began against Yemen’s Houthi rebels. In a statement, the World Food Program said the vessel, the MV Han Zhi, was loaded with 3,000 metric tons of food, enough to feed 180,000 people for one month. Muhannad Hadi, the agency’s regional director, called the ship’s safe arrival “a major breakthrough for our humanitarian response in Yemen,” which has been frustrated by extremely limited access to the country, the poorest in the Arab world. The World Food Program has made repeated attempts to send ships to Aden but until Tuesday all had been blocked because of fighting. More than half of Yemen’s population of 24 million is thought to urgently need food assistance.

Advocates have highlighted the case of the man, Arturo Hernández García, 42, as a test of an enforcement program the Obama administration started this year to focus deportations on serious convicted criminals. Mr. Hernández García, who has been in the United States without papers for 15 years and owns a small construction business with six employees, was identified by immigration agents as a result of his arrest on a criminal charge; he was later acquitted. Officials declined to cancel his deportation order but said they would not act on it.

abstract: Federal investigators said Tuesday that thousands of doctors and other health care providers had signed up to bill Medicare using “questionable addresses” like mailbox rental stores and vacant lots.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators said Tuesday that thousands of doctors and other health care providers had signed up to bill Medicare using “questionable addresses” like mailbox rental stores, vacant lots and a fast-food restaurant. The investigators, from the Government Accountability Office, said Medicare officials did not adequately verify the addresses that providers listed as their practice locations. The use of invalid addresses is “an indicator of potential fraud,” the investigators said in a report to Congress. The Medicare agency revised its screening procedures last year and “weakened its internal controls,” making it easier for some potentially ineligible providers and suppliers to qualify for Medicare payments, the report said. Medicare officials said they had revoked billing privileges for almost 28,000 providers and suppliers in the last few years.
