lead_paragraph: One person responded with a thumbs up. Another with an emoji of two hands clapping. A third wrote: “Thanks for the updates. Your efforts make Pope visit feel closer.”

headline: Greece Approves Second Set of Changes Needed for Bailout
abstract: Parliament approved a package of financial and judicial changes to keep negotiations on track for the bailout of about $94 billion.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Under the threat of yet another deadline, the Greek Parliament approved a second package of policy changes early Thursday that the country’s creditors had said must be in place before the detailed negotiations for a bailout of 86 billion euros could begin.

headline: Fire Ravages New Jersey Warehouse
abstract: Aerial video shows firefighters in North Brunswick, N.J., battling a massive warehouse fire that broke out early Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Aerial video shows firefighters in North Brunswick, N.J., battling a massive warehouse fire that broke out early Wednesday.

headline: Chris Christie Donor List Includes High-Profile Names
abstract: Business executives are on the donors’ list for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who is seeking to demonstrate that he will have the financial wherewithal to compete in a crowded Republican field.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey released a list on Wednesday of dozens of Republican donors and business executives who will raise money for his presidential campaign, seeking to demonstrate that he will have the financial wherewithal to compete in the party’s crowded field.

headline: De Blasio, Inspired by Francis, Describes an Evolving Relationship With Faith
abstract: The arrival of Pope Francis has prompted a deeply personal re-evaluation by Bill de Blasio, the liberal mayor of a famously secular city who has long called himself “spiritual,” not religious.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — His mother rejected her Catholic faith, and he grew up attending no church, a skepticism that, for Bill de Blasio, has endured to this day. As a young activist, he demanded change from the Vatican, aiding a reform movement that church leaders once denounced as a threat.

headline: Romans Put Little Faith in Mayor as Their Ancient City Degrades
abstract: Ignazio Marino is seen as a leader of unblemished integrity. But many question whether that is enough in the face of crumbling services, a declining standard of living and government scandal.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The grass in some public parks sways knee high. Disgruntled subway workers have slowed service to a crawl. Fire has rendered the city’s largest airport crammed and chaotic. The arrests of public officials pile up, revealing mob infiltration of the city government.

headline: Turmoil in China’s Stock Markets Takes a Psychic Toll
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Amid the recent turbulence in China’s stock markets, doctors have reported a surge in what they are calling “stock market anxiety syndrome.”
lead_paragraph: The symptoms, medical experts say, appear suddenly and often linger for months: insomnia, irritability, depression and an obsession with tracking stock prices.

headline: 1890: Shocking Tales of Buffalo Bill
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Mistreatment of Sioux warriors in Buffalo Bill’s traveling show in 1890.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — While that delightful dilettante of the plains, Buffalo Bill, is fascinating the crowned heads of Europe and reclining in luxury, some of the most famous of his Sioux warriors are straggling home, telling shocking tales of ill treatment and starvation. White-Horse- Kills-the-Weasel and Bear Pipe arrived in the steerage from Berlin. After devouring the first square meal they say they have had for months, they told of suffering which, though not directly attributable to Buffalo Bill, involves his agents seriously. The Indians say the food served to them was not fit for dogs. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 23, 1890

headline: The Historic Charm of Brooklyn Heights
abstract: Convenience to Manhattan, leafy streets, abundant historic buildings and the expanding Brooklyn Bridge Park are major neighborhood draws.
lead_paragraph: Convenience to Manhattan might have been the original impetus for the growth of Brooklyn Heights, but the neighborhood continues to attract residents for other reasons as well, including its leafy streets, its abundant historic buildings and the expanding Brooklyn Bridge Park.

abstract: Convenience to Manhattan, leafy streets, abundant historic buildings and the expanding Brooklyn Bridge Park are major neighborhood draws.

headline: Paul Gebhard, Sex Researcher Who Worked With Kinsey, Dies at 98
abstract: Dr. Gebhard, who trained as an anthropologist, wrote the groundbreaking “Sexual Behavior in the Human Female” with Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey in 1953.
lead_paragraph: Paul Gebhard, who with his mentor Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey broke American taboos by shifting sexual discourse from the bedroom to the living room and even beyond, died on July 9 in Columbus, Ind. He was 98.

headline: Celebrated Bass-Baritone Plans a Surprise Debut at Conducting
abstract: Thomas Quasthoff will direct Bach's monumental "St. Matthew Passion" at the Verbier Festival.
lead_paragraph: VERBIER, Switzerland — It was a sad day for the classical music world, in 2012, when the great German bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff announced his retirement from the concert stage at 52. Blessed with a rich, strong, beautiful voice, Mr. Quasthoff not only had established a major career against seemingly insuperable odds, but also had risen to the top of his profession.

headline: The Half-Lives of Others (Wonkish)
abstract: Nothing is forever, not even austerity.
lead_paragraph: What about Ireland? That’s what some people have been asking me; they’re under the impression that Ireland is a success story for austerity, and that this success is somehow a refutation of the broadly Keynesian account of the economy I’ve been giving. So I guess some clarification is in order.

headline: Verbatim: Marco Rubio Says the President ‘Has No Class’
abstract: “We already have a president now that has no class. We have a president now, that, you know, does selfie stick videos, that invites YouTube stars there, you know, people who eat cereal out of a bathtub.” — Senator Marco Rubio
lead_paragraph: — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on Fox News, comparing President Obama to Donald J. Trump.

headline: Annoying Euro Apologetics
abstract: Is this the best you can do?
lead_paragraph: Are there good arguments against the proposition that the creation of the euro was an epic mistake? Maybe. But the arguments I’ve been hearing lately are really bad. And they’re also deeply annoying.

headline: A Road Trip in Mexico Gone Wrong
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Road Trips', 'Deserts']
abstract: Thanks to a stranded rental car, scorching heat and poor planning, two buddies seeking adventure realize they’re not Rambo in Baja California Sur.
lead_paragraph: When my father heard I would be vacationing in Mexico and planned to rent a car, he told me, “Just don’t get lost in the desert down there.” A week later, I was lost in the desert in Mexico.

headline: Nicki Minaj: Black Women ‘Rarely Rewarded’ for Pop Culture Contributions
keywords: ['Music', 'MTV Video Music Awards', 'Women and Girls', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The singer set off a debate when she reacted to a snub from the MTV Video Music Awards by pointing to racism in the music industry.
lead_paragraph: The rapper Nicki Minaj reacted on Tuesday to not being nominated for MTV’s coveted Video of the Year award by saying that the cultural contributions of black women are often overlooked, raising the specter of racism in the music industry, and setting off a Twitter debate that drew thousands of people — including Taylor Swift.

lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton is showing some signs of weakness against potential Republican rivals in three swing states, according to a poll from Quinnipiac University that could raise concern within the Democrat’s campaign.

headline: China Targeting Rights Lawyers in a Crackdown
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Legal Profession', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: More than 200 lawyers and associates have been detained on accusations of exploiting cases to enrich themselves and to attack the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — More than 200 lawyers and associates have been detained, with 20 still in custody. Some have been paraded on television making humiliating confessions or portrayed as rabble-rousing thugs. A blast of commentaries in newspapers run by the Communist Party has accused them of subversion and swindles.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']

lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Marines and sailors risked their lives for one another in Chattanooga last week, trying to distract the gunman who assaulted a naval center, helping people scale a fence for safety and returning fire at the attacker, law enforcement officials said Wednesday.

headline: In Apple Watch Debut, Signs of a Familiar Path to Success
abstract: Some technology pundits have declared the device a flop, but Apple has a history of using incremental improvements to make its products indispensable.
lead_paragraph: Asking if the Apple Watch will become a hit or a flop is a bit like asking if my 2-year-old daughter is destined to go to Yale or to jail. Interested parties can speculate on the basis of thin evidence — she learned to walk pretty early, though on the other hand, she still thinks cats say “bow wow” — but youth is inherently unpredictable, and anyone venturing a long-term forecast based on short-term performance runs the risk of looking quite silly.

headline: Britain Plans to Cut Subsidies for Renewable Energy
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Solar Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Energy and Power']

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government on Wednesday announced plans to curb the costs of subsidies for renewable forms of energy like solar power, arguing that the industry could survive without the support.

headline: Twitter’s Ill-Timed ‘Frat Party’

lead_paragraph: At a time when women are struggling for an equal place in Silicon Valley, Twitter has acknowledged that a “Twitter Frat House” party was not the best idea.

headline: World Music Institute Festival Expanding in New York

lead_paragraph: The World Music Institute, a nonprofit organization that works to present traditional and contemporary international music and dance in the United States, announced the lineup on Tuesday for its first season under its new artistic director, Par Neiburger.

headline: Prototype Festival Announces 2016 Lineup
abstract: The festival returns in January with works by David T. Little, Du Yun, Donnacha Dennehy, Heidi Rodewald and many others.
lead_paragraph: The Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now festival, which has established itself as an important presenter of innovative new operas and musical works in New York, will return in January with the world premiere of “Angel’s Bone,” an opera about angels and human trafficking, by Du Yun with a libretto by Royce Vavrek, the festival’s organizers announced Wednesday.

headline: Writing Waves
abstract: Why are the pleasures and edifications of surfing so difficult to translate to the page?
lead_paragraph: For two years, between the fall of 2008 and the summer of 2010, I surfed nearly every day. At the time I was in my late 20s and living in San Francisco and in the sixth year of writing a bad novel about a young, disaffected man and his mentally disabled brother. Surfing, with all its repetition, physicality and mantras about “having fun,” offered me a ritualistic distraction from my disastrous writing life. I was already far too old and heavy-footed to ever have a chance at getting good, but I have an addictive personality and a relatively high tolerance for boredom, both of which are requisites for anyone who tries to learn to surf as an adult.

headline: Jason Segel Makes a Career U-Turn as David Foster Wallace in ‘The End of the Tour’
abstract: Early on, the actor was widely derided for taking the role of the author of “Infinite Jest.” Then the film appeared, and the tide turned.
lead_paragraph: For a while there it seemed that the coming David Foster Wallace movie was truly ill starred. Not only had it drawn the wrath of Wallace’s estate and his widow, but the casting of Jason Segel in the lead role — surely a stunt, Wallace’s fans said — had also unleashed howl after incredulous howl.

lead_paragraph: Authors recount memorable moments on tour.

lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby’s legal team pressed forward on Wednesday with a vigorous public defense of the entertainer, arguing that while Mr. Cosby acknowledged embarrassing personal details in a legal deposition 10 years ago, he admitted to no crime, a fact they say has been lost in the recent wave of media coverage.

headline: Bill Simmons to Join HBO, Going From Free Agency to Freedom
abstract: Simmons, whose relationship with ESPN ended in May, will host a weekly talk show and has a production deal to make video podcasts and documentaries for a network that should give him a wide berth.
lead_paragraph: Bill Simmons’s move to HBO, which was announced Wednesday after he had spent nearly three months in limbo, takes him to a premium network that can give him even more freedom to speak his mind than ESPN did and a chance to develop a strong TV presence.

headline: Spotify Gains Access to Beatport Music and Videos
abstract: Spotify’s deal with Beatport will also bring programming from the dozens of music festivals around the world operated by Beatport’s parent company, SFX Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Spotify has struck a deal with the electronic music site Beatport that will bring it new music and video content, the latest step in its intensifying competition with Apple over streaming music.

headline: Questions After Unarmed Ohio Man Is Killed in Traffic Stop
abstract: Officials in Hamilton County are investigating how a confrontation during a traffic stop led to the shooting death of Samuel Dubose.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Ohio are investigating how a confrontation with a University of Cincinnati police officer on Sunday led to the shooting death of an unarmed black man.

headline: Ryan Roche’s Guide to the Best of Upstate New York
abstract: The cult fashion designer shares her favorite places to buy furniture and long johns, eat rigatoni and pick berries in the Catskills.
lead_paragraph: “When I first moved to New York City, I never would have believed that I’d eventually long for the countryside again,” says the designer Ryan Roche, laughing. “But with little ones and living in Brooklyn, my day-to-day just wasn’t very peaceful. I grew up in Idaho in a really small town, with horses and wide open space and lots of fresh air, and I wanted to get back to my country-girl roots.” So in 2008, she and her family packed up the contents of their fourth-floor walk-up in Bushwick, and moved into a 17th-century stone farmhouse in the historic town of Hurley, N.Y.

headline: Jose Antonio Vargas on Donald Trump, Rachel Dolezal and His MTV Documentary, ‘White People’
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Television']
abstract: “You cannot have a conversation about race in this country and not include white people in it,” Mr. Vargas said.
lead_paragraph: Jose Antonio Vargas is a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and immigration activist. His new documentary “White People,” which airs tonight on MTV, follows Mr. Vargas as he travels the country speaking to young people about issues of race, particularly what it means to be white and experience white privilege. Because, Mr. Vargas said, “You cannot have a conversation about race in this country and not include white people in it.”

headline: Transport Group’s ‘Three Days to See,’ Inspired by Helen Keller
abstract: Taking their cues from an essay Keller wrote, actors try to approximate how she perceived the world.
lead_paragraph: “If I can get such pleasure from mere touch, how much more beauty must be revealed by sight.” So wrote Helen Keller in an essay in The Atlantic Monthly in 1933, in which she imagined what she might choose to look upon were she given the use of her eyes for 72 hours. Now the Transport Group is trying to achieve the reverse effect, by imagining itself into the mind of Keller in a play that shares its title with that of the Atlantic article, “Three Days to See.”

keywords: ['Series', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']

Lynch said on Wednesday as she announced federal hate crime charges against him.

headline: Donald Trump’s Income and Wealth Are Shown in Filing but Are Hard to Pinpoint

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump earned just $14,222 in salary. He owes at least $265 million in debt. He is paid about $250,000 per speech. And he received $110,000 from a pension with the Screen Actors Guild.

headline: Patricia Crone, Questioning Scholar of Islamic History, Dies at 70
abstract: Professor Crone challenged conventional views of the roots and evolution of Islam and her numerous books and articles shed new light on the history of the religion.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Crone, a scholar who explored untapped archaeological records and contemporary Greek and Aramaic sources to challenge conventional views of the roots and evolution of Islam, died on July 11 at her home in Princeton, N.J. She was 70.

headline: Prince Royce, a Bachata Star, Talks About His First English Album
abstract: In “Double Vision,” Mr. Royce displays fluency with modern hybrid pop that spans hip-hop, R&B, club music and more.
lead_paragraph: For the last few years, Prince Royce has had a productive career as bachata’s runner-up, thriving in the long shadow cast by the genre’s biggest star, Romeo Santos. He sings with swagger and sweetness, and over three albums, he’s demonstrated the continued vitality of bachata, a ballad-driven style born in the Dominican Republic.

headline: New York Plans $15-an-Hour Minimum Wage for Fast Food Workers
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Organized Labor', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Restaurants']
abstract: The increase would represent a raise of more than 70 percent for workers earning the state’s current minimum wage of $8.75 an hour.
lead_paragraph: The labor protest movement that fast-food workers in New York City began nearly three years ago has led to higher wages for workers all across the country. On Wednesday, it paid off for the people who started it.

headline: Caitlyn Jenner Is the Subject of ‘I Am Cait,’ a Show About a New Reality
abstract: This E! show, which has been unfurled in tantalizing snippets, will look at the way Ms. Jenner arrived at this place.
lead_paragraph: “Why did I decide to do a series?” Caitlyn Jenner ponders in a trailer for “I Am Cait,” debuting on Sunday at 8 p.m. Eastern on E! “I’m telling my story. People don’t understand looking into the mirror and nothing seems right. Putting on clothes that you just really don’t identify with. This is about getting to be who you really are.”

headline: Mostly Mozart Festival and the Knights Feature Don Quixote
abstract: This festival and a concert by the Knights both include Don Quixote pieces in their programs.
lead_paragraph: As usual, the Mostly Mozart Festival kicks off with Louis Langrée conducting the festival orchestra in an all-Mozart program on Tuesday. The soprano Erin Morley, known for her chiseled coloratura, performs two insertion arias, “Vorrei spiegarvi, oh Dio” and “No, che non sei capace,” that Mozart wrote for a Don Quixote opera by the now long-forgotten Pasquale Anfossi. The stalwart pianist Emanuel Ax takes on the sunny Piano Concerto No. 14 in E flat; the exuberant Symphony No. 34 rounds out the program.

headline: ‘Arena’ Builds and Crumbles a Temporary Civilization Through Dance
abstract: Walter Dundervill’s work is three-hour installation piece at Jack, in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The beauty of ancient sites lies partly in their decay. We call them “ruins” with affection; it’s the pillar intact and the pillar crumbled, side by side, that tell a compelling story. The multidisciplinary dance artist Walter Dundervill is something of an archaeologist of self-made worlds where grace sits at the edge of destruction. He layers historical references on top of one another, places them in colorful, immersive environments of his own design and populates them with splendidly clad characters. Then he starts excavating.

headline: Which Was Bigger: The Greek or American Bailout?

headline: Don Cheadle’s Biopic of Miles Davis to Close New York Film Festival
abstract: “Miles Ahead” is the actor’s directorial debut.
lead_paragraph: Don Cheadle’s directorial debut, “Miles Ahead,” in which he also stars as the jazz legend Miles Davis, will make its world premiere as the closing night selection of the New York Film Festival, which runs this year from Sept. 25 through Oct. 11. Mr. Cheadle also wrote the script for the film, which focuses on Davis’s hermit-like life in the late ’70s, holed up in his apartment on Manhattan’s Upper West Side. The film stars Emayatzy Corinealdi, who played the lead role in Ava DuVernay’s 2012 film “Middle of Nowhere,” and Ewan McGregor as the journalist Dave Brill.

abstract: Cooking on the grill can be a challenge, but these apps offer recipes and tips to help users serve up a tasty feast.

But since grilling is an art, and it’s easy to ruin a piece of meat on the flames, you may be seeking a little help from the right recipe apps to help cook up some mouthwatering feasts and avert a barbecue disaster.

lead_paragraph: Union Square Cafe, the restaurant that brought the farm-to-table movement to New York City and has helped transform American fine dining since it opened in 1985, has found a new home in its Manhattan neighborhood despite worries that it would have to leave.

headline: Lindsey Graham Destroys Cellphone After Donald Trump Discloses His Number

headline: Patrick Stickles Gets Very Specific
abstract: The lead singer of Titus Andronicus says that the group’s new album, “The Most Lamentable Tragedy,” is a rock opera and that “it’s not about whatever the listener thinks it’s about.”
lead_paragraph: Patrick Stickles, the lead singer of the Brooklyn via New Jersey punk band Titus Andronicus, calls his new album — a 29-track, 93-minute, five-act rock opera about his manic depression called “The Most Lamentable Tragedy” (Merge) — “precious and belabored.” He means it lovingly, with a realistic amount of self-deprecation, long a key tenet of his songwriting.

headline: 36 Hours in Siem Reap, Cambodia
abstract: Beyond Angkor Wat, the city has its own allure, with sprawling markets selling Cambodian wares, a lively dining scene and enticing street food.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago Siem Reap was the place where you stayed, ate and grabbed a beer or two between explorations of Cambodia’s 12th-century temple complex Angkor Wat. Now the city that Angkor made is something of a destination itself, luring visitors with a lively and varied dining scene, stylish hotels, genial residents and a laid-back river town ambience. Add a growing community of Cambodian and international artists, performers and designers reviving traditional arts and experimenting with new means of creative expression (the Angkor Wat International Film Festival celebrated its fourth year in February; the Angkor Photo Festival runs in December) and you’ve got an ideal short-break city, whether or not the temples are on your agenda. (Plan on using dollars in Siem Reap, where most prices are quoted in American currency. Small bills come in handy for incidentals like tuk-tuk rides and bottled water.)

headline: F.B.I. Discusses Chattanooga Shooter
abstract: Edward W. Reinhold, the special agent in charge of the F.B.I.’s Knoxville, Tenn., office, said on Wednesday that it was too early to tell if the shooter in Chattanooga had been radicalized.
lead_paragraph: Edward W. Reinhold, the special agent in charge of the F.B.I.’s Knoxville, Tenn., office, said on Wednesday that it was too early to tell if the shooter in Chattanooga had been radicalized.

headline: Sean and Sara Watkins Celebrate a Debut Album, ‘Watkins Family Hour’
abstract: These siblings, best known as two-thirds of the bluegrass band Nickel Creek, are releasing a record with a heavyweight supporting cast.
lead_paragraph: Sean and Sara Watkins have been known for most of their lives as two-thirds of Nickel Creek, the expansive, pop-literate bluegrass band. But since 2002, they have also parlayed their sibling chemistry into the Watkins Family Hour — a residency at the Los Angeles club Largo, anchored by Mr. Watkins on flatpicking acoustic guitar, Ms. Watkins on fiddle, and a heavyweight supporting cast including the singer Fiona Apple and the keyboardist Benmont Tench. To celebrate the release of its oak-solid debut album, “Watkins Family Hour” (Family Hour/Thirty Tigers), the whole crew will settle in Tuesday through Thursday at City Winery, with guest vocalists including Tift Merritt, Michael Daves and Ashley Monroe.

headline: ‘Listen to Me Marlon’ Lets Brando Talk
abstract: This documentary by Stevan Riley serves as a teaser for a 10-movie tribute for a quintessential 20th-century actor at Film Forum.
lead_paragraph: Marlon Brando has been dead 11 years, but he lives eerily on in “Listen to Me Marlon,” which begins a two-week run on July 29 at Film Forum. The movie creates a fitful biography of Brando using hundreds of hours of audio recordings he made and a weird holographic head of the actor. With Brando’s somewhat trippy observations as a guide, it looks at career highlights as well as the personal calamities that seemed to follow the man, like the suicide of his daughter Cheyenne.

lead_paragraph: Jennie Somogyi, who as a child played Marie in “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” at New York City Ballet and then went on to become a celebrated principal dancer with the company, performing major roles and battling her way back from several serious injuries, plans to retire this fall, the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: From the Mouth of an Artist Whose Own Fiery Hair Is Her Inspiration
abstract: Alice Anderson discusses the significance of various copper-wire-bound works on view in her new show in London.
lead_paragraph: There have been moments in the career of Alice Anderson when it felt as though her flame-red hair might just eclipse her. It is, after all, the artist’s constant inspiration, fantastically rendered time and again by her deft hands in copper wire. But her new show, “Memory Movement Memory Objects,” deflects the focus from her own physiognomy and out into the wider world — albeit in a familiarly burnished hue. In a throwback to childhood days spent playing with bobbins and unpicking hems, the London sculptor has turned again to the threadlike medium of copper wire to painstakingly mummify some 100 everyday objects as disparate as record players and human bones — but has left the work of covering a 1967 Ford Mustang to the show’s visitors. In her own words, she tells T the significance of a sample of these precious, tightly bound treasures, which are on view at the Wellcome Collection in London beginning today.

headline: Dr. Seuss and the Book Review Remind Us of the Joys of Childhood Reading
abstract: This week, a children’s book made a rare appearance on the cover of The New York Times Book Review. But the book is not just any children’s book and Pamela Paul, the section’s editor, explains why Dr. Seuss’ posthumous “What Pet Should I Get?” earned the cover review.
lead_paragraph: This week, for the first time ever, the Book Review featured a picture book on its cover — a book that, for all of its 32 pages, holds fewer words than the first page of an average novel.

lead_paragraph: Flamenco paired with ancient Greek tragedy? It’s the kind of idea that makes the brow furrow. But in Soledad Barrio and Noche Flamenca’s dark and explosive “Antigona,” this odd-couple match makes an “Aha!” kind of sense, uniting two fierce and stylized forms to tell the story of a sister’s defiance of a king in defense of her dead brother.

headline: The Performer and Baker Kristin Worrall Shares a Recipe for Her Very Dramatic ‘Vampire Kupcakes’
abstract: The treats will be served at the premiere of the experimental theater troupe Radiohole’s show “Tarzana!” this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Blogs may be bored of cupcakes, but the performer, sound designer and former Jean-Georges pastry chef Kristin Worrall doesn’t care — though, she explains, she “did try to elevate them a bit” when baking 200 exclusive “Vampire Kupcakes” for the upcoming premiere of the experimental theater troupe Radiohole‘s “Tarzana!” this weekend, which caps off Mass Live Arts‘ third season. “He’s pretty sweet, though he looks a little evil,” she says with a laugh of the Kupcake, a delectable confection of ganache, raspberry curd and chocolate Swiss buttercream. The “blood filled” treats, with eyes and fangs made of royal icing, are an integral aspect of the performance — even if their role takes place off stage. They’re for audience members only, served with milk as the Radiohole actors thrash about onstage. “There’s a lot of drinking, sweat, saliva and skin — not the most palatable stuff,” Worrall says of the performance. “Radiohole, their aesthetic is super punk, I would say. It’s a crazy experience, it’s a feast for all the senses — including cupcakes.”

headline: Fire Risk Prompts Fiat Chrysler to Recall 350,000 Vehicles
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Fiat Chrysler is recalling about 350,000 Journey sport utility vehicles because a plastic engine cover could come loose, contact a hot exhaust and cause a fire.
lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler is recalling about 350,000 Journey sport utility vehicles, including about 144,000 in the United States, because a plastic engine cover could come loose, contact a hot exhaust and cause a fire, the automaker said on Wednesday. Three fires in Chile resulting in one “minor” injury prompted the automaker’s investigation, a spokesman for Chrysler, Eric Mayne, said in an email. He said eight vehicles in the United States have had the problem, but while there was heat damage, there were no fires. The recalled vehicles are the four-cylinder models of the 2011-15 Dodge Journey, and a sibling sold outside North America as the Fiat Fremont.

headline: 1965: Home Resigns as Tory Leader
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Sir Alec Douglas-Home steps down as Tory leader in 1965.
lead_paragraph: LONDON— In a surprise move, Sir Alec Douglas-Home today stepped down as leader of the opposition Conservative party. The likeliest successor to the 62- year-old Sir Alec, who was prime minister for a year, is one of two younger men — Edward (Ted) Heath, 49, or Reginald Maudling, 48. Sir Alec’s resignation gives the go-ahead to the Conservatives to be an up-to-date, hard-hitting organization open to all classes. Mr. Heath and Mr. Maudling never went to Eton or other fancy prep schools and are immune from the charge that only the rich run the Conservative organization. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 23, 1965

headline: Letter of Recommendation: New Balance 990s

The year was 2007. Four months earlier, I had experienced that spiritual crisis stereotypical of young people — the one in which you can’t seem to square the scope of your ambitions with the limits of your daily life, which in my case was spent in a Midtown Manhattan cubicle. So I packed a bag and said goodbye to everyone I loved, including my wife, who was ecstatic to see me go.

headline: A Visit to Padang, Indonesia’s Food Paradise, During Ramadan

lead_paragraph: The afternoon market on the grounds of Imam Bonjol Stadium in Padang, Indonesia, lasts just one month a year and looks like a nibbler’s paradise. Padang is known across Indonesia for its cuisine and it showed: mountains of fried noodles studded with shrimp chips and whole fried eggs; heaps of snails spiced with turmeric; mounds of tiny silvery anchovies with green chiles; beef long-simmered in coconut milk to become tender rendang; es campur, an icy dessert full of unfamiliar fruits and fluorescent cubes of gelatin.

headline: 1915: Submarines Active Off Turkey

A telegram from Athens to the ‘‘Daily Telegraph’’ says that a British submarine recently attacked and sank, before the western entrance to the Bosphorus, four lighters laden with ammunition. Meanwhile Russian submarines continue their work of destruction in the Black Sea, where they have rendered practically impossible the navigation of enemy ships. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 24, 1915

headline: Wes Gordon’s Harbour Island Birthday
abstract: To celebrate turning 29, the designer made a Bahamian getaway with his boyfriend, Paul Arnhold, and their cockapoo, Bird.
lead_paragraph: “The ocean freaks me out, with all those sharks in there,” exclaims the fashion designer Wes Gordon. It was lucky, then, that Gordon chose Harbour Island in the Bahamas for a four-day beach getaway this month to celebrate his 29th birthday with his longtime boyfriend Paul Arnhold. “It was literally like bathtub water, it’s crystal clear, and there aren’t plants or rocks. I think even the sharks there would be too relaxed to do anything.” Good for Gordon, whose sophisticated silhouettes reflect his own sensibilities and who isn’t exactly a beach bum: “We don’t go that often — I get really red so easily,” he says. “There are certain places that have a very loyal cult following, and Harbour Island is definitely one of them, so we thought it was time to check out what that was about.”

headline: A Tasting Tour of Yorkshire’s Beers and Ales
abstract: Exploring the world of local brews that feel as much a part of the region as its moors and old textile mills.
lead_paragraph: The long hike across the West Yorkshire moors passed over hills peppered with scrubby grass, through fields of heather and over jagged rocks and gurgling streams. Along the way I’d been severely scolded by more than one chattering red grouse, and ignored by innumerable flocks of grazing sheep. Eventually I’d made it all the way to Top Withens, a ruined farmhouse whose setting was said to have been the inspiration for Emily Brontë’s “Wuthering Heights.” Sunburned and tired after the long walk, I needed refreshment.

headline: José Parlá to Bring Sculptural Paintings to the High Line
abstract: The pieces reflect the complex biography of Mr. Parlá, who was born in Miami to parents who had fled Cuba.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, when the High Line was an abandoned and derelict railroad, José Parlá used to sneak up onto the train tracks to take photographs that he called “memory documents.” Now visitors to the elevated High Line park in the meatpacking district will have a bird’s-eye view of the first outdoor installation in New York by Mr. Parlá, 42, a Brooklyn-based artist.

headline: Focusing on Women in Surrealism
abstract: Sotheby’s is organizing a selling exhibition, “Cherchez la Femme: Women and Surrealism,” opening in September.
lead_paragraph: Female artists are rarely among the go-to names in the Surrealist canon. Man Ray, Dalí and Magritte often come up, but Kay Sage or Leonora Carrington? But dropping the names of these and other women associated with the Surrealist movement of the early 20th century may become common, thanks to exhibitions at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art or “Frida Kahlo: Art, Garden, Life,” at the New York Botanical Garden. And now, Sotheby’s, hoping to capitalize on growing interest and raise awareness of these artists, will hold a selling exhibition, “Cherchez la Femme: Women and Surrealism,” from Sept. 15 to Oct. 17 in New York.

headline: Kinetic Works by the Artist Gego Are Headed for 2 Shows
abstract: New exhibitions showcase the German-born Venezuelan artist.
lead_paragraph: “In Latin America, Gego is like a goddess, in the same way Frida Kahlo has a myth around her, but she is not so known in America,” the gallerist Dominique Lévy said of the artist Gertrud Goldschmidt, whose delicate, three-dimensional geometric compositions expanded the possibilities of kinetic art. Born in Germany, Gego — the childhood nickname stuck — escaped anti-Semitism in Hamburg in 1939, at age 27, and fled to Venezuela, where she lived until her death in 1994.

headline: Meet Aalto, a New Finnish Brand Inspired by All-Night Raves

lead_paragraph: “Primitive” and “raw” are a few of the words Tuomas Merikoski would use to describe his new women’s label, Aalto — but judging from his first few collections, the terms “relaxed” and “retro” come to mind, too. “I’m not trying to make it too abstract or too conceptual — it’s still clothing you can wear,” says the 36-year-old designer who introduced the brand with a Pre-Fall 2015 collection in January.

headline: Amid the Donald Trump Show, Republicans Hit the Campaign Trail
abstract: Lacking Mr. Trump’s attention-generating celebrity, the other presidential candidates are working hard at traditional political events.
lead_paragraph: From their seats on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Marco Rubio and Rand Paul tried to score points for their presidential bids on Thursday by blasting Secretary of State John Kerry over the Iran nuclear deal. In New Hampshire, Jeb Bush and Gov. John R. Kasich fielded questions from voters at town hall-style meetings. Carly Fiorina hit four events over 10 hours in Iowa, while Gov. Scott Walker and Mike Huckabee spoke to conservative state lawmakers in California.

headline: Review: ‘Horse Money,’ a Surreal Voyage Into the Past
abstract: In Pedro Costa’s fantastical Portuguese film, a man passes through an abyss and finds himself in a hospital confronting specters from his younger days.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Costa, the Portuguese director of “Horse Money,” is one of a handful of filmmakers who could claim to have invented their own approaches to narrative. Beginning with “Ossos” (“Bones”) in 1997, he made a trilogy of films set in the Lisbon slum of Fontainhas, an enclave of Cape Verdean immigrants that has since been razed. In the subsequent “In Vanda’s Room” and “Colossal Youth,” Mr. Costa veered away from pure fiction and allowed Fontainhas residents to shape their dialogue and scenes. Drawn from real-life details though hardly documentaries, Mr. Costa’s movies unfold through monologues and tableaux, finding poetry and myth in the lives of the marginalized.

headline: Review: In ‘Southpaw,’ Jake Gyllenhaal Tries to Box His Way Back From Tragedy
abstract: Antoine Fuqua’s ode to boxing also stars Forest Whitaker as a tenacious trainer and Rachel McAdams as a loving tough-cookie wife.
lead_paragraph: Connoisseurs of boxing sometimes wax eloquent on the nuances of the sport, but boxing movies tend to value impact over finesse. Few genres are so reliably and bluntly conventional. Primal stories — rise and fall, ruin and redemption, the love of a good woman — are punctuated by scenes of carefully choreographed pugilism. Violence and sentimentality dance in the ring, and the audience leaves satisfied, if not exactly surprised.

headline: Costly to Treat, Hepatitis C Gains Quietly in U.S.

He went into rehab and was successfully treated for the virus. But he relapsed into addiction and reinfected himself, testing positive for hepatitis C again this spring.

He has called it a “historic mistake.” On Wednesday, his ambassador to Washington, Ron Dermer, met 40 conservative members of Congress as part of a full-court Israeli push to persuade American lawmakers to vote down the accord.

headline: Review: ‘Dark Was the Night’ Confronts a Demon in the Woods
abstract: The director Jack Heller’s horror film draws its talent from television: Kevin Durand, Lukas Haas and Bianca Kajlich.
lead_paragraph: There’s certainly talent in Jack Heller’s fright film “Dark Was the Night,” beginning with its cast. The busy TV actor Kevin Durand (“The Strain” on FX, “Vikings” on History) — here playing a small-town New York sheriff contending with a supernatural monster of Native American legend — conveys tender sorrow and steely resolve with understated dexterity.

abstract: Mr. Smith’s newest exhibition considers theme parks, Ponce de León and Baby Ikki’s flair for ballet.
lead_paragraph: What kind of world do we live in, where the fountain of youth is in a Florida theme park, ballet is used to demonstrate the frustrations of airport security, and our greatest existential conundrum is how to keep those white Apple earphones untangled?

headline: Flea Theater Sets Season Featuring a Hollywood Visitor (and Zombies)

headline: Review: ‘Unexpected,’ a Tale of 2 Pregnancies That Unite and Divide
abstract: Kris Swanberg’s film depicts a Chicago schoolteacher who discovers that she is pregnant just as one of her top students does, and peppers her protégée with advice.
lead_paragraph: There is barely a false note in Kris Swanberg’s intelligent, well-mannered drama “Unexpected,” which tells parallel stories of two unforeseen pregnancies. Sam (Cobie Smulders), 30, who teaches science at a crumbling, soon-to-be closed high school in a poor Chicago neighborhood, lives with her boyfriend, John (Anders Holm). With no immediate plans to marry and start a family, she has her heart set on landing a high-powered job at the Field Museum designing a science curriculum for the city school system.

headline: Marion Cotillard’s Effortlessly Chic Gala Look

lead_paragraph: As the invasion of Chelsea by giant glass boxes continues at a breakneck pace, Andrew Edlin is moving on (to the Lower East Side), its small, antiquated building slated for demolition. “Anthems for the Mother Earth Goddess,” a provocatively plaintive group show of temporary murals and one sculpture installation, is the gallery’s last exhibition at this location.

headline: Review: ‘A Gay Girl in Damascus,’ a Documentary About a Hoax

lead_paragraph: Even knowing the secret of “A Gay Girl in Damascus” doesn’t make this documentary any less tense. That’s a testament to Sophie Deraspe, a director who understands how to let a plot unfold.

headline: A Family Rift on Middle Ground
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Families and Family Life', 'Friendship']
abstract: Plus: an overly inquisitive friend; the pluses and minuses of a wedding invitation; and a few words about tight exercise clothes.
lead_paragraph: Since our father died 10 years ago, my sister and I have not spoken. I have tried to heal the rift, but it is useless. My psychiatrist and her counselor agree. But our cousin, with whom we are both close, refuses to accept my decision. This may be because my sister claims to want to reconcile, though her actions say otherwise. When I ask my cousin what’s going on with my sister, as I would about any family member, she refuses to tell me anything and accuses me of snooping. Is she trying to bully me into reconciliation by withholding information?

headline: Review: ‘Big Significant Things’ Compares Landmarks in Life and on the Road

lead_paragraph: “Big Significant Things” is a cute idea in search of substance. This wan film, a first feature by Bryan Reisberg, gives us Craig (Harry Lloyd), a young man who is on the verge of taking the next step with his longtime girlfriend. No, not that next step — they’re about to buy a house.

headline: Review: In ‘The Vatican Tapes,’ the Sinister Stare of Possession

headline: Review: ‘The Young Kieslowski’ Is a Sobering Comedy of Consequences
abstract: Two college students, a first sexual encounter and one pregnancy — with twins — in this uncomfortable comedy.
lead_paragraph: There are no grand romantic flourishes in “The Young Kieslowski,” an uncomfortable comedy about an accidental pregnancy that upends the lives of two freshmen at the California Institute of Technology. The title character, Brian Kieslowski (Ryan Malgarini), is a whiny dweeb with wide, frightened eyes who is obsessed with losing his virginity. He is certain that his lack of experience is visible to all. Leslie Mallard (Haley Lu Richardson), whom he accidentally impregnates in his first go at sex, is a self-professed Christian who has sworn to remain chaste until marriage.

headline: Review: In ‘Pixels,’ Attack of the Retro Video Games

lead_paragraph: Poor Washington is having a bad summer. The city was destroyed on television Wednesday night in Syfy’s “Sharknado 3: Oh Hell No!,” and it takes a beating again in theaters with Friday’s release of “Pixels,” in which it is attacked by giant versions of 1980s video-game characters. Expect some of those many presidential candidates to begin dropping out of the race this weekend.

headline: Pakistani Panel Rejects Fraud Accusations in 2013 Prime Minister Vote

abstract: The finding was a rare political victory for Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, who had faced huge protests that shut down the capital last year.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In a major blow to the Pakistani opposition leader Imran Khan, a judicial commission released a report on Thursday rejecting his accusations of widespread fraud and irregularities in the 2013 general elections.

headline: Review: ‘Five Star’ Casts a Cool Eye on Gang Culture
abstract: This documentary-fiction hybrid from Keith Miller looks at the softness that threatens hard-guy hierarchies.
lead_paragraph: Slow and steady, and with remarkable assuredness, Keith Miller’s “Five Star” plays mean-streets drama in the lowest of keys. Relying on neither raised voices nor cocked weapons — although both appear sparingly — this documentary-fiction hybrid observes gang culture with a calm eye and a clear head.

headline: Review: ‘Phoenix’ Shows Rebirth and a Ruse in Postwar Germany
abstract: Never less than intriguing, coolly intelligent and flawlessly paced, “Phoenix” often feels trapped in the logic of its conceit.
lead_paragraph: In Christian Petzold’s new film, Phoenix is the name of a Berlin nightclub where Nelly Lenz goes searching for her husband, a piano player she calls Johnny. World War II has just ended, which suggests that “Phoenix,” the title of this compact, haunting thriller, might have other, larger, metaphorical meanings as well. In a few years, Germany will ascend from the ruin of military defeat into an era of political stability and economic growth. Nelly, a Jewish singer who survived the Nazi death camps, is undergoing her own tentative rebirth — her face has been reconstructed after it was damaged by a gunshot wound — and her friend Lene (Nina Kunzendorf) encourages her to prepare for a new life in Tel Aviv.

headline: Review: ‘The Outrageous Sophie Tucker’ Recalls a Jazz Powerhouse

lead_paragraph: If you close your eyes and randomly select a page from the autobiography of the singer Sophie Tucker, you may well end up reading a throwaway anecdote like this: “Queen Marie of Romania came to Chicago during our run there. We all hoped she would come to see the show, and an invitation was sent to Her Majesty. But she sent a gracious letter of apology, and we had to be content that night with Al Capone and a party of 20.” Flip a few more pages, and there’s this: “Will I ever forget the hamburger dinner I cooked for Fanny Brice and Aunt Jemima!”

headline: Review: ‘Paper Towns’ Tries to Fold Significance Into the Everyday
abstract: A story about boy meets girl, girl forgets boy, girl returns to boy, based on a book by John Green, author of “The Fault in Our Stars.”
lead_paragraph: Teenage angst has been a lucrative movie racket for years, but what happens when the kids are pretty much all right? Not a whole lot, at least in “Paper Towns,” a serenely bland adaptation of the John Green young-adult novel about a regular boy in love with the mystery girl next door. Once upon a Hollywood time, when American adolescents were in the grip of social mores and studio censorship, nice guys wooed nice gals with boyish smiles, well-behaved hands and tamped-down desires. What’s old is new again in “Paper Towns,” a melodrama in which smiles still tremble, hands largely behave and freedom’s just another word for everything an ordinary boy doesn’t want to lose.

abstract: Fang Yuan stars as an engaged woman who suddenly hesitates to marry her fiancé and goes off in search of a man with the name given to her by fortunetellers.
lead_paragraph: Based on a 1994 Hollywood romance of the same title with Marisa Tomei and Robert Downey Jr., Zhang Hao’s “Only You” covers similar but not identical bases: Fang Yuan (Tang Wei), a Beijing veterinarian, has twice been informed by fortunetellers that she would marry a man named Song Kunming. Engaged to a dentist, she intercepts a phone call from her fiancé’s former classmate — a certain Song Kunming. Accompanied by her levelheaded friend Li Xiaotang (Su Yan), she impulsively flies to Italy to find him. But instead she meets Feng Dali (Liao Fan), an expatriate buyer and restorer of antiquities who impersonates the elusive Kunming until the ruse is uncovered and he must win over Yuan as himself.

headline: Review: ‘Dylan Goes Electric!’ Considers Folk, Rock and a ’60s Divide
abstract: Elijah Wald’s book revisits the night in 1965 that Bob Dylan shocked Newport Folk Festival audiences — by abandoning an acoustic guitar for a Fender Stratocaster — and analyzes why it really did matter.
lead_paragraph: Saturday night is the 50th anniversary of Dylanageddon: the night Bob Dylan savaged the Newport Folk Festival by making loud, electrified noise at a sanctuary that had never been thus sullied. The story of his 1965 assault on Newport is very well known. Its effects have been contemplated ad nauseam. Its details show up in every Dylan biography. It’s so essential to the Dylan story that it may even have engendered folk songs of its own. So the idea of a book to commemorate this geezer milestone seems unnecessary, to put it kindly.

headline: American Pharoah Has a Secure Spot in History, but a Tricky Future

headline: Charmed
abstract: Taking a Moroccan grandmother’s advice for warding off the evil eye.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon last April, I stood in the doorway of my daughter’s room, watching her prepare for a big recital. She was going to perform with her middle-school orchestra in Santa Monica. She packed her violin, rosined her bow, put on a black dress and tamed her wild hair into a bun. ‘‘There,’’ she said. ‘‘I’m ready.’’ How lovely she looked, how determined. Had I been half as confident as this when I was 11?

headline: How to Tell a Joke
abstract: Avoid the obvious setup. Measure your success in laughter, not retweets.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘People should not be able to telegraph where a joke’s going,’’ says Hari Konda­bolu, a stand-up comic from Queens. The only way to guarantee surprise is to create original material. Street jokes — the kind you read in a book or hear at summer camp and tell with the preface ‘‘Want to hear a joke?’’ — are almost never funny, Kondabolu says. They also often involve animals, inexplicably. (If you must go that route, ducks make for the funniest animal jokes, according to a global survey done by scientists at the University of Hertfordshire.) His routines playfully take on more serious topics like race and gender.

headline: The Singular Mind of Terry Tao
abstract: A prodigy grows up to become one of the greatest mathematicians in the world.
lead_paragraph: This April, as undergraduates strolled along the street outside his modest office on the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles, the mathematician Terence Tao mused about the possibility that water could spontaneously explode. A widely used set of equations describes the behavior of fluids like water, but there seems to be nothing in those equations, he told me, that prevents a wayward eddy from suddenly turning in on itself, tightening into an angry gyre, until the density of the energy at its core becomes infinite: a catastrophic ‘‘singularity.’’ Someone tossing a penny into the fountain by the faculty center or skipping a stone at the Santa Monica beach could apparently set off a chain reaction that would take out Southern California.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Ta-Nehisi Coates’s “Between the World and Me,” which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1, is an incantatory essay about being black in America.
lead_paragraph: Not O.K.: Ta-Nehisi Coates’s new book, “Between the World and Me” — an incantatory essay about being black in America, framed as a letter to his teenage son — enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1. Like another recent best seller, Claudia Rankine’s “Citizen,” the book burns with moral intelligence about the daily humiliations and degradations confronting black people, and refuses the easy consolations of hope and uplift. Early on, Coates addresses his son’s despair over the Michael Brown case in Ferguson, Mo. “I didn’t comfort you,” he writes, “because I thought it would be wrong to comfort you. I did not tell you that it would be O.K., because I have never believed it would be O.K. What I told you is what your grandparents tried to tell me: that this is your country, that this is your world, that this is your body, and you must find some way to live within the all of it. I tell you now that the question of how one should live within a black body, within a country lost in the Dream, is the question of my life, and the pursuit of this question, I have found, ultimately answers itself.” (The “dream” at issue is of course the American dream, which Coates points out depends on a vision of innocence that willfully ignores the American sins of slavery and institutional racism.) Some commentators have taken Coates to task for emphasizing social and historical frameworks more than personal choice and responsibility, but a recent profile in New York magazine leaves no question where he stands on that debate. “Coates noticed the good people on the wrong side of history,” the reporter Benjamin Wallace-Wells writes, “suggesting that individual virtue was a weak counter­weight to the pathologies of states. Had he been alive and had means, he tweeted, ‘I would have owned slaves too.’ ”

headline: ‘A Cure for Suicide,’ by Jesse Ball
abstract: After a life-threatening illness, a man known as the claimant is reintroduced to human behavior.
lead_paragraph: In Jesse Ball’s elegant, spellbinding fifth novel, “A Cure for Suicide,” a man known only as the “claimant” sits on a chair, which he has recently learned is called “chair.” He listens as a woman he knows as the “examiner” tells him how a story works. The examiner has not yet given the claimant a name. The claimant must first learn how to listen to a story and tell a story in turn. “It isn’t important that you understand what I say,” the examiner tells him. “It is not very important that you are understood as long as you give the person the happiness of being told a story.”

headline: An Unfinished Library
abstract: “The Greatest Books You’ll Never Read” is a new survey of books that are “unfinished, unbegun or lost, and today exist as only suggestive fragments or not at all.”
lead_paragraph: “The Greatest Books You’ll Never Read” is a new survey of books that are “unfinished, unbegun or lost, and today exist as only suggestive fragments or not at all.” Despite the title, not all of these works sound particularly great. Take, for example, Karl Marx’s “Scorpion and Felix,” a comic novel he wrote when he was 19 and under the influence of “Tristram Shandy.” According to the Marx biographer Francis Wheen, it’s “a nonsensical torrent of whimsy and persiflage.”

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: PERFIDIA, by James Ellroy. (Vintage, $16.95.) After a Japanese family is murdered in 1940s Los Angeles, a police force with questionable ethics is tasked with solving the case, blurring the lines between criminality and morality. As our reviewer, Dennis Lehane, wrote, “The police are not knights, they’re occupiers, and in ‘Perfidia,’ Ellroy comes closer than ever to making the case that he writes alt-histories not of the Los Angeles police but of the Los Angeles police state.”

headline: ‘The End of Plenty,’ by Joel K. Bourne Jr.
abstract: A journalist looks at the challenges involved in keeping the world from going hungry.
lead_paragraph: An 18th-century question matters for 21st-century foodies: “Are human beings perfectible?” If our species can improve itself, if we can learn to consume less, have fewer children and wean ourselves off meat, the planet might yet flourish. If not, the fear is that we’ll breed and eat ourselves into extinction. Many have addressed this quandary, but Robert Malthus’s ideas are the ones Joel Bourne puts at the heart of “The End of Plenty,” his big book on the global food system.

headline: ‘A Hand Reached Down to Guide Me,’ by David Gates
abstract: The characters in David Gates’s stories engage in festivals of bad decisions.
lead_paragraph: The world of the knowing and frank stories in David Gates’s new collection is located north of New York City, ranging roughly from Peekskill to Vermont. The bright, educated, sardonic people who inhabit this world call themselves refugees from New York, dismissing their new locale as Olde Quaintsburgh or the boonies. Full of rueful badinage, like the characters in his novels “Jernigan” and “Preston Falls,” they make for witty and cautionary company. “A Hand Reached Down to Guide Me” is a smart book about smart, articulate people who get in their own way again and again, engaging in episodic festivals of bad decisions and then talking about their plight with arresting candor, in language rife with humor and allusion.

headline: ‘The Hand That Feeds You,’ by A.J. Rich
abstract: A heroine learns her dead fiancé was an impostor.
lead_paragraph: As “The Hand That Feeds You” opens, Morgan, a 30-year-old graduate student, returns home to her 68-step Williamsburg walk-up to find that her fiancé has been mauled to death by her dogs. It’s a terrifying scene, relayed with gripping frankness.

headline: Christian Kracht’s ‘Imperium’
abstract: In this Swiss novel, a German vegetarian in the early 1900s tries to found a colony in the South Seas.
lead_paragraph: If, while sprawled in a deck chair or on the beach this summer, you crave a book whose tone and emotional landscape mirror your own state of torpor and cosseted relaxation, such a book would not be “Imperium.” Although this very amusing and bracingly oddball novel by the Swiss writer Christian Kracht does feature several palm-covered islands — not to mention many gallons of coconut oil and copious amounts of undress — calling it a beach read is like calling “Psycho” maternal.

headline: ‘The Loved Ones,’ by Mary-Beth Hughes
abstract: After an inescapable loss, a cosmetics executive moves his family to London.
lead_paragraph: “Only a flurry. A thin blanket of white, something to take the gray mounds of snow and make them new.” So begins Mary-Beth Hughes’s third book, “The Loved Ones.” It is 1969, and Jean Devlin is leaving her house on the Jersey Shore in “the Valiant wagon she used for errands.” The departure is fraught, partly because the fraughtness of departure is one of the book’s themes, and partly because of the nature of the driveway. “Jean made the reverse up the steep curve, then backed into the roadside pull-off where most delivery drivers chickened out and parked. They’d rather hand carry a refrigerator than make the plunge, but Jean could do it blindfolded.”

Sometimes when I see someone heading to the neighborhood mosque, I cross to the other side of the street. There is a popular belief among the pious that if they come in contact with a dog, they become unclean. You have to take a ritual bath before you can offer your prayers.

headline: First Draft Archive: Rendezvous at the Border
abstract: President William Howard Taft met with President Porfirio Díaz of Mexico in October 1909, when both leaders traveled to the United States-Mexico border.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, the real estate mogul-turned-Republican presidential candidate, traveled to the United States-Mexico border on Thursday, a crowd of gawking reporters in tow, to draw attention to his campaign’s focus on immigration. Border visits have become a fixture in modern American politics, from tours by sitting presidents to campaign stops by candidates like Mr. Trump. But they were not always so common. In October 1909, President William Howard Taft became the first sitting U.S. president to visit and then cross the border, when he met with the Mexican president, Porfirio Díaz. The trip, which included meetings in El Paso, Tex., and Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, was the first meeting between sitting presidents of the two nations and was only the second international trip by a sitting U.S. president. At some point during their daylong back-and-forth, the two men posed for their formal portrait.

headline: Review: In ‘The Art of Abhinaya,’ Bragha Bessell Dances With Masterly Range
abstract: Ms. Bessell presented five pieces, dancing and acting in a classical Indian tradition.
lead_paragraph: In many classical Indian dance traditions, the dancer is also an actor. A dance can be a kind of dramatic monologue in which the dancer presents a character, or several, and wordlessly tells a story, both narrating and re-enacting a poem. This kind of acting is called abhinaya, and it was the focus of a performance on Wednesday at the theater of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis High School in Manhattan. Titled “The Art of Abhinaya,” this was the first solo recital in New York of the Bharatanatyam dancer Bragha Bessell, who revealed herself to be a master of the art.

headline: Uber Makes Its Pain New Yorkers’ Problem
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The ride-hailing company uses a populist campaign that riles up customers to fight regulation.
lead_paragraph: In the immediate aftermath of the stock market crash in 1929, amid the suicides, collapsed fortunes and other pervasive miseries, the number of men looking for jobs in New York expanded the ranks of the city’s cabdrivers to 30,000. Chaos reigned. There were too many drivers going after too few passengers — fares were slashed, tensions between fleets escalated, violence erupted. Some drivers working 20-hour days could not make enough money to support themselves. As a result, in 1937, the city devised the medallion system to limit the number of vehicle licenses. In the late 1930s, there were just under 12,000 medallions in circulation; more than 75 years later, in a city larger by one million people and benefiting from far greater prosperity, there are only 13,000.

headline: How Natalie Collette Wood, Program Director of the Bronx Children’s Museum, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: What others consider a good day for downtime is prime time for Ms. Wood, as she and other members of the museum staff take the bus that holds their peripatetic exhibits on the road.
lead_paragraph: Even after the new Bronx Children’s Museum opens on the Harlem River in 2017, Natalie Collette Wood, 33, the program director, will continue to share her peripatetic exhibits and mural-making aboard the organization’s traveling bus. “This is the way we think a 21st-century museum should run,” she said. “The Bronx is extremely hard to get across from east to west. We are out in the community building relationships.” Sunday, then, is prime time to take the museum on the road. But Ms. Wood also schedules time for her own artwork and to relax with her boyfriend, Victor Vildósola, 37, a musician, with whom she lives in the Morrisania section of the borough, along with a new puppy, a Chihuahua mix named Oliver.

headline: Chicory Is the Cheshire Cat of Herbs
abstract: The nonnative plant is known to open for a single day, and its flowers are bluest for only a few short morning hours, fading rapidly after sunset.
lead_paragraph: Chicory’s flowers are as blue as the summer sky, their casual, untrained beauty heightened by the meager settings in which they grow. One of the best ways to see chicory in New York City is to simply take a drive. The plant seems happiest growing from road medians, cracks in curbs and mangy, un-mowed fields. It grows alongside other beautiful but outcast plants like Queen Anne’s lace, dandelion and soapwort, and it takes only a wet week or two in July to produce a burst of color that can challenge autumn’s leaves.

In April, about 300 American troops arrived in Ukraine to train Ukrainian national guard troops, who fall under the Interior Ministry. As that mission winds down, the new trainers will arrive to work with Defense Ministry troops near Ukraine’s border with Poland. The additional training brings the amount of American military assistance to Ukraine to $244 million, Mr. Toner said.

headline: 1940: Hungary Expects to Get Only Part of Transylvania
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Hungary’s aspirations to get Transylvania back are challenged in 1940.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — The impression that Soviet aspirations as yet unknown are the reason for this week-end’s Salzburg conversations is generally gaining ground here, as well as the feeling that Hungary will not receive the whole of Transylvania in the axis solution of the Danubian question, because of the important problem of erecting an anti-Russian bloc in this area. It is difficult to say how a partial cession of Transylvania would be received here, in view of the propaganda which has been waged for the return of the whole district. An indication of how this might be done gracefully, however, was given this morning in the ‘‘Pester Lloyd,’’ organ of the Foreign Office. The paper’s leading editorial resurrected the Hungarian claims for damages caused by the Rumanian Army during its partial occupation of the country in 1919. — New York Herald Tribune, July 27, 1940

headline: Assad, in Rare Admission, Says Syria’s Army Lacks Manpower

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a striking admission, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria said on Sunday that the country’s army faced a manpower shortage and had ceded some areas to insurgents in order to hold onto other regions deemed more important.

headline: 1965: U.S. Cars to Provide More Safety Features

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The nation’s leading auto makers now seem ready to install a number of safety items as mandatory equipment on their 1967 models. The decision to do so has not been taken lightly. Many of the auto makers, including Frederic G. Donner, chairman of General Motors, are known to feel that ‘‘if we were to force on people things they are not prepared to buy we would face a consumer revolt.’’

For most of her customers, it was just another afternoon at a Wendy’s restaurant in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Not for Ms. Cornick. She was celebrating.

headline: A Note on Medicare Costs
abstract: Oh, and happy 50th birthday.
lead_paragraph: Medicare is about to turn 50, and while it has brought immense benefits, it has also cost a lot of money. Why? Is it the general rise in health care spending, or some specific government-related inability to limit outlays?

headline: Thorstein Veblen in Brooklyn (Trivial)
abstract: The purpose of topknots.
lead_paragraph: I went to another Celebrate Brooklyn concert in Prospect Park last night, and had a very good time — although the usual close-up seating where you can really see the performers was given over to a throng of standing dancers, and while I may be a wannabe hipster I’m not going that far. But anyway, music aside, one thing I enjoy about these events is crowd-watching, which varies a lot by performer. Lucius was a real all-ages, all-subcultures crowd, ranging from enthusiastic teenagers to fairly sedate but equally enthusiastic senior citizens. Sylvan Esso was very hipster — which is fine; de gustibus non whatever.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (E!) I AM CAIT “Why did I decide to do a series?” Caitlyn Jenner, above, ponders in a trailer for her latest endeavor. “I’m telling my story. People don’t understand looking into the mirror and nothing seems right. Putting on clothes that you just really don’t identify with. This is about getting to be who you really are.” This new reality series aims to moves beyond the paparazzi photos (Ms. Jenner in Versace! In Diane von Furstenberg!) and public speculation to find out how Ms. Jenner came to be a role model for transgender pride. And while the show, at least initially, seems to focus on her looks — Ms. Jenner quipping about sports bras as she plays tennis; plucking a dress from her closet, only to be told by her stepdaughter Kim Kardashian that her mother, Ms. Jenner’s ex, has one just like it; and fixing a chip in her baby-blue manicure — “We’re going to do some good,” she promises. “Caitlyn Jenner, on screen, maintains the public personality of Bruce Jenner,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “She has the qualities of an excellent decathlete, spokeswoman and even leader, but as a reality star she could take a few lessons in openness and spontaneity from the Kardashians.”

headline: A Manhattan Project Veteran Had a Unique View of Atomic Bomb Work
abstract: Benjamin Bederson was assigned at key moments to the research project that produced the atomic bombs that were dropped on Japan nearly 70 years ago.

headline: The Disappearing Entitlements Crisis

lead_paragraph: A few years back elite policy discourse in the United States was totally dominated by the supposed entitlements crisis. Serious people all assured each other that history’s greatest menace was the threat posed by the unstoppable growth of Medicaremedicaidandsocialsecurity, which could only be tamed by dismantling the legacy of the New Deal and the Great Society, while of course cutting top marginal tax rates.

headline: Review: In ‘Butcher Holler Here We Come,’ Tensions Down in the Hole
abstract: In Casey Wimpee’s play, five West Virginia miners trapped during a cave-in share their histories and anxieties.
lead_paragraph: Darkness can be thoroughly disorienting, a fact that the performance collective Aztec Economy uses to advantage in “Butcher Holler Here We Come,” at the Tank in Midtown. The play, about a fictional mining disaster in West Virginia, is lighted entirely with headlamps worn by the actors, and sometimes it isn’t lighted at all.

headline: Review: Jane Urquhart’s ‘The Night Stages,’ a Novel of Melancholy and Missed Chances
abstract: The latest novel by this Canadian writer consists of three narratives, linked by a single night that an Englishwoman named Tamara spends in a Canadian airport around 1960.
lead_paragraph: The acclaimed Canadian writer Jane Urquhart often works within a particular wistful mood — her stories, whether contemporary or historical, are full of dormant hurts, quietly endured; long separations; sorrows. “The Night Stages,” her tender, meditative eighth novel, again has this tenor, suggestive of John Banville and Alice McDermott, and again demonstrates both its virtues and its flaws. The book’s language is often lovely. Its story could be described with equal fairness as stately or static, depending on your sense of how fast a narrative should move. It’s coercively melancholy. I suspect that not many people will like it, and also that some will love it.

headline: Senate Resurrection of Export-Import Bank Goes to Divided House

abstract: House Republicans are split over the agency, whose authorization expired June 30 and which had stopped assistance to customers of American exports.

headline: 11 Arrested in Nepal in Possible Ritual Killing of Boy
abstract: The boy had been missing since a neighbor hosted a gathering in which he said that his own son was possessed, and would need a human sacrifice.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU — The police found the boy’s body on the banks of a river in Kudiya, a farming village near the Indian border. His throat had been slit.

headline: ‘Chasing Shadows’ Offers Another Sleuth With Problems
abstract: The British mystery series, which begins on Acorn.tv on Monday, is a missing-persons procedural with echoes of shows like “Without a Trace” and “Cold Case.”
lead_paragraph: Sometimes British mysteries take us to places we haven’t been before. “Chasing Shadows” takes us straight to familiar places, and I’m not talking about the seedier parts of England.

headline: The New York Musical Theater Festival Features Joy and Purpose
abstract: Among the offerings at the festival includes final performances of “Songs for the Fallen,” “Manuel vs. the Statue of Liberty” and “Foolerie.”
lead_paragraph: The Statue of Liberty should always be played by a transgender woman in a sea-foam-green cape and boxing trunks. Shakespeare should always be a lovesick character in his own plays. All dying Parisian courtesans should declare “the greatest thing you’ll ever learn” — and repeatedly change their minds about what that is.

headline: Snoop Dogg Arrested in Sweden, Then Freed
abstract: The rapper was arrested in Sweden on Saturday night on suspected drug charges.
lead_paragraph: The rapper Snoop Dogg was arrested in Sweden on Saturday night on suspected drug charges. After playing a concert in Uppsala, Snoop Dogg’s vehicle was pulled over and he was taken to the police station for a urine test, The Guardian reported. After completing the test he was released without charges. Snoop Dogg profiled the events on his Instagram, posting videos from the back of the police car and inside the station. “Sorry about that to all the fans in Sweden, I’ll never be in this country,” he says in one video.

headline: Review: Dancenoise Brings Biting Commentary (and Fake Blood) to the Whitney
abstract: The duo performed at the Whitney as part of a Dancenoise exhibition that included a retrospective installation and a variety show invoking their 1980s East Village roots.
lead_paragraph: If only you could stuff the world into a box — a big cardboard box labeled “The World” — and just carry on around it, dancing naked and painting your nails. That’s one thing that happened on Friday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, in a wickedly funny new concoction from Dancenoise, the inimitable duo Anne Iobst and Lucy Sexton.

headline: Cooper Hewitt to Host Pixar Exhibition
abstract: “Pixar: The Design Story” opens on Oct. 8.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when Buzz Lightyear was just two-dimensional. That “Toy Story” character’s prehistory, as a conceptual sketch on a page, will be on display with other gems from Pixar Animation Studios at the exhibition “Pixar: The Design of Story,” opening on Oct. 8 at Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum. Conceptual drawings from Pixar’s films — including “Wall-E,” “Brave” and more — will be one aspect of the show, which will also feature paintings and sculpture to demonstrate the studio’s development process. The show will be a blend of blockbuster brand recognition and education. Caroline Baumann, the Cooper Hewitt’s director, said the exhibition is “completely parallel with the museum’s mission, which is focusing on process and inspiring and educating people with design.” Pixar’s most recent film, “Inside Out,” was released on June 19. The Cooper Hewitt show opens about a month before the studio’s next venture, “The Good Dinosaur,” due on Nov. 25.

headline: Tanglewood’s Contemporary Music Fest Milks Many Sources

lead_paragraph: TANGLEWOOD, Mass. — Gunther Schuller, a composer, conductor, jazz historian and horn player, had hoped to conduct the premiere of his “Magical Trumpets” last Thursday at Tanglewood. But the concert, part of the annual Festival of Contemporary Music, instead became a memorial to Mr. Schuller, who died in June at 89.

headline: Calling Obama ‘Our Son,’ Kenyans Nod Knowingly at His Critique
abstract: In a Nairobi slum, people paid 10 shillings each to see President Obama’s speech on television, including his “cancer of corruption” message.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Shaking off the morning chill, they walked down dirt pathways and past burning piles of trash. It would cost 10 shillings — about a dime — to see the speech, but they wanted to see the man.

headline: Kitty Genovese Killing Is Retold in the Film ‘37’

headline: Lil Buck and Michelle Dorrance Dance Enliven Lincoln Center Out of Doors
abstract: Lil Buck’s limber display and the equality among performers in Ms. Dorrance’s show were memorable at this dance festival.
lead_paragraph: Friday and Saturday nights offered, at Damrosch Park as part of the Lincoln Center Out of Doors series, performances by Dorrance Dance (tap) and Lil Buck (the style called Memphis jookin) that were, in their different ways, phenomenal. But Dorrance Dance left an impression of marvelously developed plenitude, with a program that ideally celebrated and renewed the resources of its genre, whereas Lil Buck looked like an artistically under-realized genius, a dazzling prodigy whose gifts are in danger of turning into point-scoring stunts.

lead_paragraph: After a game in which they had scored the most runs, tallied the most hits and presumably left the most mouths agape in Citi Field’s seven-year history, the Mets returned to the ballpark Sunday morning with a revised and sobered outlook. One run would do, thanks very much.

headline: A Little of This, A Little of That
abstract: The return of Zhouqin Burnikel and D. Scott Nichols.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s funny how your senses come into play even when solving a crossword. You have to pay close attention, but sometimes an entry can trigger a Proustian memory of things past and, for me, it’s also a reminder that a crossword puzzle is much more than just a square of interconnected words.

headline: Lynch Says Death in Police Custody Highlights Fears Among Blacks

headline: Yankees’ Nathan Eovaldi Lends Stability to a Rickety Rotation
