headline: Problems of Housing Mentally Ill People Spill Into the Street
keywords: ['Group Homes and Supportive Housing', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: There is widespread agreement that shelters like the one housing a man who fought a Washington Heights restaurant owner are wrong for mentally ill people, but there are now more shelters and less supportive housing.
lead_paragraph: One evening last week, a restaurant owner in Washington Heights and two customers stood chatting on the sidewalk about the changes in the area over the last 25 years. The restaurateur, Peter Walsh, was telling the people, who were coming from a hospital on 168th Street, how much safer the neighborhood had become as he stood in front of his restaurant, Coogan’s, on Broadway between 168th and 169th Streets.

headline: Liberia: Ebola Stalls Birth Registrations
abstract: The births of more than 70,000 children in Liberia during the Ebola crisis were never recorded, leaving them vulnerable to marginalization.
lead_paragraph: The births of more than 70,000 children in Liberia during the Ebola crisis were never recorded, leaving them vulnerable to marginalization as noncitizens, denial of government services, trafficking and illegal adoption, Unicef reported Thursday. The agency said birth registrations in 2014 and so far this year had dropped sharply compared with levels before the Ebola epidemic. Quoting Ministry of Health data, Unicef said the births of only 700 children had been registered between January and May of this year, when many health facilities were overwhelmed or closed. Sheldon Yett, the Unicef representative in Liberia, said the agency was helping the government to register the others. Registration is required to obtain basic health and social services and identity documents. “Children who have not been registered at birth officially don’t exist,” he said in a statement. More than 4,800 people have died in Liberia because of the Ebola crisis, according to the World Health Organization.

headline: Review: ‘Two Step’ Scuffles Around With Petty Criminals
abstract: Alex R. Johnson’s feature-length debut is a nasty, well-acted little gem that goes deep inside its characters’ psyches.
lead_paragraph: A recurrent image of grackles lined up on a wire as if on the lookout haunts “Two Step,” a creepy indie thriller set in the seedier environs of Austin, Tex. That image reinforces the movie’s acrid portrait of a scuffling working-class milieu where the lines between legitimate employment and petty crime blur. Several of the characters run scams in addition to holding jobs.

headline: A Fight Outside an Uptown Restaurant
abstract: A surveillance video shows an altercation between Peter Walsh, the co-owner of Coogan’s restaurant, and a man who approached him outside his restaurant.
lead_paragraph: A surveillance video shows an altercation between Peter Walsh, the co-owner of Coogan’s restaurant, and a man who approached him outside his restaurant.

headline: MSNBC Reshuffles Its Daytime Lineup Ahead of Brian Williams’s Debut
abstract: Three daytime shows are being canceled in advance of Brian Williams’s joining the cable network, possibly in September. MSNBC’s prime-time lineup is so far untouched.
lead_paragraph: The cable network MSNBC is getting a long-awaited shake-up to its daytime lineup.

headline: Review: In ‘Dark Awakening,’ a Haunted House and Surfeit of Gore
abstract: Dean C. Jones’s film depicts a small-town prosecutor who moves with his family into his deceased mother’s house, only to be pestered by its spectral residents.
lead_paragraph: The district attorney of a Southern town, James Thomas (Jason Cook), has a lot on his docket. First he has to put up with an angry court spectator who shoots a leering defendant just declared innocent. Then James’s mother dies, and he and his wife, Jennifer (Valerie Azlynn), and 7-year-old son, Danny (William Pifer), move into Mom’s country home, where spectral residents befriend Danny and terrify Jennifer. The local priest (Lance Henriksen) clearly isn’t sharing all he knows, and before long James just isn’t acting like his old self.

headline: Construction Plans for La Guardia Airport Don’t Faze Its Neighbors
abstract: Residents of East Elmhurst, Queens, seem willing to deal patiently with inconveniences out of an abiding loyalty to the airport.
lead_paragraph: One cannot live any closer to the terminals of La Guardia Airport than the residents of East Elmhurst, Queens. Some homes sit only a few hundred yards away from the control tower, on the opposite side of the Grand Central Parkway. The new $4 billion airport hub envisioned for the site, announced this week by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Vice President Joseph R. Biden, would be even closer.

headline: Review: Burgers (and Seafood) at Shad Row in Rocky Hill
abstract: With outdoor-only seating, Shad Row offers a funky ambience and a beachfront vibe in a serene setting.
lead_paragraph: I have waxed enthusiastic over Spicy Green Bean in Glastonbury, whose funky-cozy-colorful ambience reflects the eclectic flair of its chef-owner, Kathy Denisiewicz. Now the Bean has sprouted a new branch, Shad Row, just across the Connecticut River, that is ably tended by Kathy D, as Ms. Denisiewicz is often called, and her niece, Jenna Cavalieri.

headline: Restaurant Review: Tony Cuban Cucina & Cocktails in Freeport Has a Rollicking Setting
abstract: A Cuban-Italian fusion restaurant with a menu that ties the distinct ethnic backgrounds of its married owners together.
lead_paragraph: A Cuban-Italian fusion restaurant seemed like a natural project for married restaurateurs Frank and Elizabeth Minier (he is of Cuban descent; she, of Italian and Colombian heritage) who opened Tony Cuban Cucina & Cocktails in Freeport in May.

headline: Mullah Muhammad Omar’s Life Ends With Little Clarity
abstract: Mullah Muhammad Omar, the secretive leader of the Taliban, spent the final years of his life in remarkable obscurity, and his death was confirmed only by chatter among Taliban officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the winter of 2014, an Afghan with links to top Taliban leaders approached Afghanistan’s intelligence service with a startling tip: Mullah Muhammad Omar, the secretive leader of the Taliban, had died in a hospital in Karachi, Pakistan.

headline: Review: ‘I Am Chris Farley,’ a Brief Life, Lived for Laughs
abstract: In this documentary about the comedian, colleagues recall Mr. Farley’s exuberantly physical humor and invented characters, including the motivational speaker who lived “in a van down by the river.”
lead_paragraph: “I Am Chris Farley” paints an effusive portrait of its title subject, a man the “Saturday Night Live” creator Lorne Michaels is shown calling an “infuriatingly talented” comedian.

headline: Banking for Pot Industry Hits a Roadblock
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Unions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: After its application to serve the marijuana business was denied, a credit union filed a lawsuit demanding “equal access” to the financial system.
lead_paragraph: Banking regulators just said no to a financial institution that aims to be the first to serve the expanding marijuana industry in Colorado.

headline: Spike in Donor Numbers for Clinton Foundation
abstract: Clinton Foundation officials said Thursday that there were 10,516 donors so far this year, compared to 8,801 during the same six-month period last year.
lead_paragraph: The Clinton Foundation accelerated its fund-raising in the first six months of the year, officials said Thursday, as Hillary Rodham Clinton was gearing up for her presidential run amid a crush of news reports scrutinizing the charity’s solicitation of foreign donors.

headline: Review: ‘Jenny’s Wedding,’ a Lecture on Tolerance
abstract: This movie, directed by Mary Agnes Donoghue and starring Katherine Heigl as a closeted lesbian, is about secrets, lies and bigotry.
lead_paragraph: “Jenny’s Wedding” begins with a christening and ends with a conga line — a finale signaled so clearly that even those in the cheap seats can’t miss it. And that’s one of the many irritants in this trite, well-intentioned lecture on tolerance: The audience is always several moves ahead of the script.

headline: Taking Aim at Planned Parenthood, Conservatives Use Familiar Tactic
abstract: The vow by some Republicans to reject a spending bill that includes funds for Planned Parenthood is their latest attempt to affect policy by threatening to shut the government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The vow by ardently conservative Republicans to reject any spending bill that does not cut off federal funds for Planned Parenthood is their latest attempt to force through policies by threatening to shut down the government.

headline: Review: Emanuel Ax, at the Mostly Mozart Festival, Gives a 19th-Century Lesson
abstract: Mr. Ax, along with fellow pianists Orion Weiss and Anna Polonsky, played a program that centered on Brahms and ended with Schumann.
lead_paragraph: In the 19th century, when many homes had a piano and before recorded music was available, composers often disseminated their orchestral works to a wider public via piano transcriptions. Composers also transcribed their predecessor’s music; Liszt created solo piano arrangements of all the Beethoven symphonies as well as numerous virtuosic opera transcriptions. Many musicians, like Schumann, created duo works and arrangements for the amateur market.

headline: Review: In ‘A Lego Brickumentary,’ Master Builders Working and Playing
abstract: A movie explores the uses, from artistic to therapeutic, of a ubiquitous toy.
lead_paragraph: You’d expect “A Lego Brickumentary” to be an extended plug for Lego products, and it is certainly that — to an extent. (Lego did not finance the film.) And this nimble, expertly paced family-friendly film by Daniel Junge and Kief Davidson dutifully covers the origins of the Lego company in Billund, Denmark, and its growth into a global toy brand rivaling Mattel and Hasbro. But it delves into other things: how engineers and psychologists have employed the pieces as tools, and the ways in which people have adopted Legos as a medium to realize their creative visions.

headline: Maryland’s Governor Orders Immediate Shuttering of Long-Troubled Baltimore Jail
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: A state-run institution is cited for an extraordinary history of corruption and deplorable living conditions.
lead_paragraph: The man who until recently ran the huge, fortresslike city jail in Baltimore impregnated four corrections officers, bought fancy cars and demanded unchallenged loyalty, investigators would later say.

headline: Ivan Moravec, Pianist, Dies at 84; His Music Penetrated Iron Curtain
abstract: Mr. Moravec was a renowned interpreter of Chopin, heard largely through recordings.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Moravec, a Czech pianist who earned a reputation as one of the greatest interpreters of Chopin largely through recordings that had penetrated the Iron Curtain, died on Monday in Prague. He was 84.

headline: Review: ‘Paulo Coelho’s Best Story’ Hopscotches Through an Author’s Career
abstract: This Brazilian film depicts Mr. Coelho’s rebellious youth, setbacks, grand adventures and literary success.
lead_paragraph: Before the Brazilian author Paulo Coelho published his mythic quest of a fable, “The Alchemist,” he had already written plays, put out a magazine, made hit records with the Brazilian rock star Raul Seixas and became a music executive. So the title of this biopic, “Paulo Coelho’s Best Story,” is apt: His own life might well be his greatest work.

headline: Richard D. Bass, Ski Resort Developer Who Climbed Tallest Peaks, Dies at 85
abstract: A book about the Texas rancher’s climbs and its attendant publicity were often given credit, and blame, for a flood of amateur attempts on Mount Everest.
lead_paragraph: Richard D. Bass, an oil and gas scion and Texas rancher who preferred mountain altitudes to oil field flats, building the Snowbird ski resort in the Utah Rockies and scaling the highest peaks all over the world, finally reaching the summit of Mount Everest after three failed attempts, died on Sunday at his home in Dallas. He was 85.

headline: Undone Deal Is Astros’ Gain
abstract: A day after the Mets’ trade for Carlos Gomez fell through, Houston acquired Gomez, pitcher Mike Fiers and a 2016 draft pick from the Milwaukee Brewers for four prospects.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Sitting in the dugout at Minute Maid Park in Houston this week, the Astros’ general manager, Jeff Luhnow, reflected on the way his job had changed. The Astros are making a playoff push, a bit ahead of schedule, after six losing seasons in a row. The team expects to contend for a long time, but that did not lessen Luhnow’s urgency.

headline: Glare of Video Is Shifting Public’s View of Police
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The recording of encounters between the police and the public has begun to alter public views of the use of force and race relations, experts and police officials say.
lead_paragraph: They began as workaday interactions between the police and the public, often involving minor traffic stops in places like Cincinnati; North Charleston, S.C.; and Waller County, Tex. But they swiftly escalated into violent encounters. And all were captured on video.

headline: Mike Pyle, Captain of 9-0 Yale Team and Champion Bears in ’63, Dies at 76
abstract: Pyle was among the many former N.F.L. players who brought suit against the league for disregarding cognitive dangers resulting from football collisions.
lead_paragraph: Mike Pyle, the captain of Yale’s last unbeaten and untied football team and of the 1963 N.F.L. champion Chicago Bears, died at 76 on Wednesday in Highland Park, Ill., after a decade-long battle with dementia, which his family believes may have resulted from the battering he took as an offensive lineman.

headline: Attack on Gay Pride Parade Shakes Israel’s Self-Image as Bastion of Tolerance
abstract: An Israeli’s violent rampage at the event in Jerusalem was quickly politicized by critics of Israel.
lead_paragraph: As the news spread online that an ultra-Orthodox Jewish man had stabbed six people at Jerusalem’s annual Gay Pride Parade on Thursday, accompanied by terrifying images of the attack, critics of Israel were quick to argue that the rampage undermined the country’s self-image as a bastion of tolerance in the region.

headline: Koch Brothers Brave Spotlight to Try to Alter Their Image
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'Philanthropy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: After two elections in which liberals sought to cast them as the secretive face of the G.O.P., the billionaire brothers want to change perceptions of their family.
lead_paragraph: Once known for grim letters to fellow wealthy Americans warning of socialist apocalypse, Charles G. Koch now promotes research on the link between freedom and everyday happiness. Turn on “The Big Bang Theory” or “Morning Joe,” and you are likely to see soft-focus television spots introducing some of the many employees of Koch Industries.

headline: Review: In ‘That Sugar Film,’ a Bitter Truth
abstract: For this documentary, the director and actor Damon Gameau subjects himself to a high sugar diet, by way of juice, yogurt and cereal.
lead_paragraph: In “That Sugar Film,” Damon Gameau, an engaging Australian actor-director who has been off refined sugars for years, shifts his consumption for two months to include 40 teaspoons of sugar a day, the average Aussie’s intake. And he isn’t scarfing candy and soda: Instead, to highlight the hidden sugars in so-called healthy alternatives, he consumes products like low-fat yogurt, juice and cereal.

headline: Review: ‘Wild City’ Follows Two (Very) Good Samaritans in Hong Kong
abstract: This movie, directed by Ringo Lam, features a former cop and his cab-driving stepbrother who take extravagant risks in protecting a woman from triad gangsters.
lead_paragraph: Much has changed in Hong Kong since Ringo Lam’s classic 1987 undercover thriller, “City on Fire,” starring Chow Yun-fat, but one scourge of urban life apparently persists: sidewalks and shops plagued by careening car chases. “Wild City,” Mr. Lam’s respectable but average return to directing feature films after a recent hiatus, follows an accidental hero, T-Man (Louis Koo), who often laments the evils of cash. But it’s mayhem, not moralizing, that perks up the story.

headline: Texas Trooper’s Behavior Called ‘Catalyst’ in Sandra Bland’s Death
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Trooper Brian T. Encinia behaved rudely and failed to de-escalate a confrontation with Ms. Bland, the head of the state police told lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The head of the Texas state police department faced fierce grilling by lawmakers here Thursday over the confrontational behavior of a trooper in the arrest of Sandra Bland, who was found hanged in her Waller County jail cell this month, three days after she was taken into custody after a routine traffic stop.

headline: Turn Awkward
abstract: Friday fun with James Mulhern and Ashton Anderson.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — You definitely can’t say that this one by James Mulhern and Ashton Anderson wasn’t exciting. If you are going to start your weekend with a crossword puzzle, it might as well have SEXY BEAST, GET WEIRD and RUN AMOK in it.

headline: Family of Man Killed by Rogue Detectives Settles Suit for $5 Million
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: Israel Greenwald was killed in 1986 by two New York Police detectives known as the “mafia cops,” Stephen Caracappa and Louis Eppolito. His body was not found until 2005.
lead_paragraph: The last that Israel Greenwald’s daughters saw of him was in February 1986. Yael, then 7, had the flu, and her father stayed up all night with her; the next morning, he hugged Michal, 9, when he left her at her bus stop. They never saw him again. The married father of two girls, a diamond dealer and a religious man with no criminal record, simply seemed to disappear.

headline: Review: Skepta Returns to the Rugged at Palisades and MoMA PS1
abstract: In two New York gigs, the British rapper demonstrated his creative rebirth, which stems from his rediscovery of grime’s rugged origins.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the British grime rapper Skepta released “That’s Not Me,” a punchy, skittish, electrifying song that went on to become one of his biggest hits. It was also a song that announced a creative rebirth by way of de-accessioning — Skepta had been releasing music for more than a decade, and was a star for years, but to rediscover himself, he had to return to grime’s rugged origins.

headline: 4 N.J. Transit Conductors Sold Stolen Tickets, Prosecutors Say
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Commuting', 'Transit Systems', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The suspects are accused of turning the monotony of the commute on New Jersey Transit trains into a windfall.
lead_paragraph: The four New Jersey Transit conductors collected tickets from their usual passengers in their usual cars, making idle chatter day after day as riders flashed monthly rail passes that can run more than $400.

headline: Judge Hears Arguments on an Exxon Settlement
abstract: On Thursday, lawyers for New Jersey and environmental groups argued their case about an environmental contamination settlement between the state and Exxon.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J. — For months, environmental groups, state lawmakers and others have blasted a proposed $225 million deal to settle a longstanding environmental pollution case between New Jersey and Exxon Mobil Corporation.

headline: Stand-Up Comedy Beyond the Brick Wall
abstract: As stand-up spreads out of traditional comedy clubs in New York, new spaces include a biscuit shop, a pizzeria and Central Park.
lead_paragraph: “Everything that I’ve done in life that’s been remotely successful started out with a joke that I just blurted out,” said Brandon Scott Wolf, a stand-up comedian based in Brooklyn. “And then I was like, ‘You know what, I’m going to do that.’ ”

headline: Dancing for Geoffrey Holder’s Birthday and Legacy
abstract: Lincoln Center Out of Doors commemorates the work of Mr. Holder with a screening of “Carmen & Geoffrey” and a performance by that same Carmen de Lavallade, his widow.
lead_paragraph: Geoffrey Holder was, for starters, a dancer. He was also a choreographer, an actor, a painter — the list goes on. With a towering height (6-foot-6) and personality to match, he made his presence known all over New York for over 50 years.

headline: The Metropolitan Museum of Art: A Look Back
abstract: The current Metropolitan Museum of Art, which has had an overall record number of visitors during the last year, is hardly the Met that first opened to the public in 1872.
lead_paragraph: 143 YEARS AGO

headline: Bad Day for Dry Cleaning
abstract: A man tried to protect his clothes as he crossed 26th Street at Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Thursday. Forecasters say Friday will be sunny, with a high in the 90s.
lead_paragraph: A man tried to protect his clothes as he crossed 26th Street at Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Thursday. Forecasters say Friday will be sunny, with a high in the 90s.

headline: Facebook Taking Open-Source Software Ethos to Drones
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'Open-Source Software']
abstract: Autonomous aircraft firing lasers for three months at a time? Not bad. Open-sourcing the whole project? Maybe even better.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is developing advanced telecommunications, complete with autonomous laser-firing drones, and it is doing it as if it were a big software project.

headline: Families of 2008 Crane Collapse Victims Are Awarded $48 Million
keywords: ['Derricks and Cranes', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A jury found James F. Lomma, the owner of a crane company, responsible for the deaths of two people killed when a tower crane collapsed in Manhattan seven years ago.
lead_paragraph: One of the longest civil trials in New York City history ended on Thursday when a jury found the owner of a crane company responsible for the deaths of two people killed when a tower crane collapsed in Manhattan seven years ago.

headline: Report Reveals New York City Paid $138 Million in Settlements Related to Potholes on Roadways
abstract: The highest number of incidents caused by potholes happened in the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, the Grand Central Parkway and the Belt Parkway.
lead_paragraph: New York City should do a better job of fixing potholes to reduce the amount of money it pays to settle claims involving injuries and damage they cause, which have cost taxpayers $138 million in the past six years, Comptroller Scott M. Stringer said on Thursday.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The End of the Tour’
abstract: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “The End of Tour.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “The End of Tour.”

headline: U.S. Sets Goal for Faster Supercomputers. Much, Much Faster.
keywords: ['Supercomputers', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: President Obama announced an ambitious goal of creating an ultrafast machine that could enable breakthroughs in fields like medicine and astronomy.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has announced an ambitious plan to build the world’s fastest computer, a machine capable of speeds far beyond technology’s current reach, in a bid to enlarge the frontiers of fields including medicine, biology and astronomy.

headline: Facing Death With a Shrug in Two Versions of ‘The Killers’
abstract: A Criterion set offers Robert Siodmak’s 1946 noir take on a Hemingway short story and Don Siegel’s treatment of the same material in 1964.
lead_paragraph: To read Ernest Hemingway’s short story “The Killers,” first published in Scribner’s magazine in 1927, is to understand why this most mainstream of American writers was once considered a modernist.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Ta-Nehisi Coates
abstract: The author of “Between The World and Me” on the books he’d want on a desert island: Doctorow, Wharton, Fitzgerald and more.
lead_paragraph: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Ta-Nehisi Coates, national correspondent for the Atlantic and the author of “Between The World and Me” and “The Beautiful Struggle”, who shares his picks exclusively with T.

headline: Yankees Fall in Ninth Inning, Capping a Day of Frustration
abstract: The Yankees’ day started with Michael Pineda going on the disabled list and ended with a loss thanks to Josh Hamilton.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — On a day when the Yankees lost out on acquiring David Price and lost one of their best pitchers, Michael Pineda, to the disabled list, they also suffered a rare letdown from their two nearly infallible relievers.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) FOXCATCHER (2014) Bennett Miller recounts the based-in-truth story of the chemical company heir John E. du Pont (Steve Carell) and his dream of Olympic glory, which leads him to build a training center on his Foxcatcher Farm in Newtown Square, Pa., and lure the gold-medal wrestler Mark Schultz (Channing Tatum, far left, with Mr. Carell) to live and train there. Mark Ruffalo plays Mark’s brother, Dave, himself a gifted wrestler, who is disinclined to join the crusade. Vanessa Redgrave is John’s disapproving mother, who finds the sport beneath the family’s station. “Beautifully acted and impeccably mounted, it is light on historical details and heavy on atmosphere, character and chintz,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this drama, which earned Oscar nominations for Mr. Carell, Mr. Ruffalo and Mr. Miller; its screenwriters, E. Max Frye and Dan Futterman; and Bill Corso and Dennis Liddiard, the men behind Mr. Carell’s large prosthetic nose. “Some of the best scenes in the movie are of the brothers, including an early one in which they train in their old gym, hitting and grasping in a pantomime of aggression and affection, the crowns of their heads touching like the antlers of young stags testing each other,” Mr. Scott added. “It’s rare to see such physical male intimacy on screen, especially among men not bonded by war. And it’s in the depictions of this intimacy, in its tangle of bodies and desires — the images of John squirming on top of and below other men say more than any of his pitiful speeches — that ‘Foxcatcher’ rises to the occasion of real tragedy.”

headline: Corrections: July 31, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, July 31, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 31, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “Jails were never meant to be mental health hospitals.”

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: July 31
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include “water-gazers” at the Battery, high temperature scenes across the city and more summer love.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include “water-gazers” at the Battery, high temperature scenes across the city and more summer love.

headline: Jewish Arsonists Suspected in West Bank Attack That Killed Palestinian Toddler
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Israeli Settlements', 'ARSON', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The attack was branded as terrorism by Israeli and Palestinian politicians, and shocked consciences on both sides of the simmering conflict.
lead_paragraph: DUMA, West Bank — Residents of this Palestinian hamlet still awake on a hot summer night heard the screams and rushed to the Dawabsheh home. Outside, Saad, 32, lay writhing on the ground. Nearby, his wife, Riham, 27, was still on fire. Their 4-year-old son, Ahmad, could be heard crying inside the burning house, and his brother, 18-month-old Ali, was already dead.

headline: In Guatemala, Exhuming Children to Make Room for Death
abstract: Saul Martinez discovered that his homeland’s mind-numbing violence has led cemetery administrators to clear out the graves of forgotten children to make room for new burials.
lead_paragraph: There is palpable heartbreak in the photos of Saul Martinez. On one level, it is evoked by the subject itself: The bodies of Guatemalan children have been put into mass graves after being removed from burial niches because their parents could not — or forgot — to pay the upkeep fee. But just as sad is the underlying reason: Guatemala’s mind-numbingly high levels of violence have created an unceasing demand for new burial spaces.

headline: A Nighttime Police Visit in China
abstract: On the night of July 11, the police in Guangzhou came for the human rights lawyer Ge Wenxiu. They threatened to break down his door.
lead_paragraph: On the night of July 11, the police in Guangzhou came for the human rights lawyer Ge Wenxiu. They threatened to break down his door.

headline: Setting Big Goals, Hillary Clinton Joins the Climate Battle
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: A test of her commitment to fighting global warming will be how she addresses the need to sharply cut the use of fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton has promised a series of initiatives to address the challenge of climate change. The first installment, unveiled this week in Iowa, calls for an aggressive expansion of wind, solar and other carbon-free energy sources so that they provide one-third of America’s electricity by 2027 — enough, she says, to power every home in the country.

headline: A Port Authority Bill
abstract: AAA New York State says the legislation, endorsed by The Times, “offers only superficial solutions.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Obama Administration Ignores Malaysia’s Trafficking Record
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Human Trafficking', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Did Malaysia get a pass on its terrible record because the administration needed to meet political requirements of the trans-Pacific trade deal?
lead_paragraph: After one year on the State Department’s list of countries that are failing to combat modern-day slavery, Malaysia has been upgraded to a higher category. That judgment, part of an annual evaluation of how 188 countries deal with human trafficking, strains credulity, given how little Malaysia has done to address the problem.

headline: The Profusion of Airline Fees
abstract: A reader suggests a way to “correct this situation.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Guns and the Two Americas
abstract: One is safer. The other is an open-fire zone, backed by politicians who think it should be even more crowded with people parading around with lethal weapons.
lead_paragraph: The waves of mass shootings continue to roll over the United States like surf on the ship of state’s prow. Every few weeks now we get hit with a jolt of cold water. We shake and shudder, and then brace ourselves for the next one.

headline: Two Cheers for Capitalism
abstract: A big coming debate will be over how much say government should have over business and income equality.
lead_paragraph: We are clearly heading toward another great debate about the nature of capitalism. Contemporary capitalism’s critics are becoming both bolder and more intellectually rigorous. Protests and discussions are sprouting up all over the place.

headline: The Death of Cecil the Lion
abstract: Attention on one animal’s death should increase focus on the many species being threatened by markets demanding their tusks, horns and other parts.
lead_paragraph: The death of Cecil, the black-maned lion killed by an American big-game hunter in Zimbabwe, has unleashed a global storm of Internet indignation. The hunter, Dr. Walter Palmer, a dentist from Minnesota, has been forced into hiding.

headline: China’s Naked Emperors
abstract: The politicians in Beijing who have ruled during economic booms, not unlike many of their American counterparts, have no idea what they’re doing.
lead_paragraph: Politicians who preside over economic booms often develop delusions of competence. You can see this domestically: Jeb Bush imagines that he knows the secrets of economic growth because he happened to be governor when Florida was experiencing a giant housing bubble, and he had the good luck to leave office just before it burst. We’ve seen it in many countries: I still remember the omniscience and omnipotence ascribed to Japanese bureaucrats in the 1980s, before the long stagnation set in.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Crowded Stage
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Campaign Finance', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why the long and unforgiving slog to a presidential nomination is proving irresistible to so many — from senators to governors to Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: ANYBODY not running for president?

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The mouthy magnate is the carnival we summoned by letting our popular and political cultures bleed into one.

abstract: The Bright Lines Project and the Center for Competitive Politics disagree on the role of the Internal Revenue Service.

abstract: A column by David Brooks provokes arguments for and against an increase.

headline: Chinese Films Find Their Audience — and It’s Huge
abstract: China’s “domestic film protection period,” the summer weeks when foreign films are largely blocked from Chinese theaters, is helping at least one movie set box-office records.
lead_paragraph: This is turning out to be a very good season for domestic films in China.

headline: BNP Paribas’s Profit in 2nd Quarter Is Bolstered by Investment Bank Revenue
abstract: Results were dragged down at France’s biggest bank last year by a huge settlement for doing business with countries facing American sanctions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — BNP Paribas, France’s biggest bank, said on Friday that it swung to a profit in the second quarter because of higher revenue in its investment bank and international financial services business, less than a year after being hit by a huge settlement for doing business with countries that face United States sanctions.

headline: Liberty Global Increases Its Stake in British Broadcaster ITV

headline: How to Cure a Cat’s Anxiety
abstract: Install a fish tank. Acknowledge the animal’s enigmatic nature.
lead_paragraph: Impulse-control problems, phobias, anxiety, violent outbursts and compulsive disorders are not uncommon in pets. ‘‘Unfortunately, you cannot put a cat on a couch and say, ‘Tell me about your mother,’ ” says E’Lise Christensen, a veterinary behaviorist with practices in Manhattan and Denver. (‘‘Think of us as animal psychiatrists,’’ she says.) Still, you can treat the kind of underlying feline psychological distress that leads to biting, scratching, moping and urinating outside the litter box. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors like Prozac can help, but Christensen advises clients to examine a pet’s environment before turning to pharmacology. ‘‘Ask yourself, Are you coming close to meeting this animal’s natural needs? The answer is almost always no.’’

Far ahead my husband’s bike light glimmered through the dense pines. Suddenly he stopped and waited for me. “Cherie, can’t you go a bit faster?” Guy said rather anxiously. Later, I learned that a boar had just crashed through the woods in front of him.

headline: Exit Strategy
keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Smuggling', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Passports']
abstract: Trying to get out of Afghanistan, illegally and otherwise, for years.
lead_paragraph: It was nine years ago, when I was 23, that I first tried to leave Afghanistan. I had been working as an interpreter for coalition forces, and I started getting phone calls from the Taliban. They would say, ‘‘We will find you, and we will kill you.’’ They claimed to know my name and where I was living. I don’t know if it was true — when you worked with the Americans, you hid your face to protect yourself — but interpreters had been killed before. I felt I had to try to go to Europe and make a new life there. So I went to a kachakbar, a smuggler, to get me out of the country.

headline: ‘Circling the Sun,’ by Paula McLain
abstract: This novel is based on the life of Beryl Markham, horsewoman and aviator.
lead_paragraph: If you were half awake in 2011 (or 2012 or 2013), you couldn’t have avoided Paula McLain’s runaway best seller, “The Paris Wife.” That fictional autobiography of Ernest Hemingway’s beleaguered starter wife, Hadley Richardson, unfolds pretty much as the Hemingways’ marriage does, in Paris in the 1920s. Caught up in the mass hysteria, I too bought a copy. But when I came to this line, after just half a dozen pages, I couldn’t go on: “I don’t want to think and I don’t want to feel, either, unless it’s as simple as this beautiful boy’s knee inches from mine.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: William Finnegan, who has written several sober examinations of the world’s hot spots, has his first best seller with the surfing memoir “Barbarian Days,” No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction list.
lead_paragraph: The Waves: As a war reporter and international correspondent for The New Yorker, William Finnegan has long been celebrated for his sober examinations of the world’s hot spots — going back to 1986, all of his books have been “editors’ choice” picks in the Book Review, including dispatches from apartheid-era South Africa, civil-war-torn Mozambique and poverty-stricken America. None of those books became best sellers. But his latest, the surfing memoir “Barbarian Days,” ends Finnegan’s dry spell at last, landing on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 5. “I was kind of nervous about coming out of the closet as a surfer,” Finnegan told The National Post in Canada last month. “I mean, I was a political reporter and writing a lot of political opinion pieces for The New Yorker, and I had a kind of reluctance to expose this part of my life and have a bunch of people say, ‘What do you know? You’re just a dumb surfer.’ ” Once he started, though, he couldn’t stop. “It’s easy for me to write about the act of surfing. I find it endlessly interesting,” he said. “The trick is to make it interesting to readers who couldn’t care less.” This columnist might be the kind of reader he means — I’m not a surfer, dumb or otherwise, although friends in California once coaxed me onto a board for 20 seconds. But I do kayak, and I recognize the giddy obsession Finnegan brings to his sport. In that sense, “Barbarian Days” offers the same heedless pleasure as any addiction memoir before the reckoning; it is, as Alice Gregory writes in The New York Review of Books, “an utterly convincing study in the joy of treating seriously an unserious thing.”

headline: Flight or Fright
abstract: Sara Paretsky’s crusading private eye, V.I. (Vic) Warshawski, returns in “Brush Back.”
lead_paragraph: Don’t listen to Thomas Wolfe. You can always go home again — if you’re prepared to have your beating heart ripped from your chest and stomped on. Sara Paretsky’s crusading private eye, V.I. (Vic) Warshawski, finds that out in BRUSH BACK (Putnam, $27.95) when she lets a high school boyfriend talk her into returning to the ramshackle neighborhood on the South Side of Chicago where they grew up. Frank Guzzo, a truck driver for a haulage company, is worried about his unstable mother, Stella, a truculent old bat who just got out of prison after doing 25 years for beating her teenage daughter to death. (“She was getting those big ideas, way above herself.”) But when Vic pays an unannounced visit to Stella, who now claims to have been innocent, this harridan slanders Vic’s mother and blames the killing on the sleuth’s beloved cousin and Chicago hockey legend, Boom-Boom Warshawski (who was murdered far too early in this series).

headline: 1890: Bismarck Speaks His Mind
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Prince Bismarck says he cannot give up politics altogether in 1890.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Post has now published a detailed account of Prince Bismarck’s interview with the representative of the Russian journal the Novoe Vremya. It was on a personal subject that the ex-Chancellor expressed himself with the greatest bitterness, on the subject of the proposed monument in his honor. His friends were desirous, he said, of paying to him in his lifetime the honors due for the dead. The Prince declared that he was becoming reconciled to his lot. Everything had been carried out with such attention to legal form that he could not dream of protesting. He took a keen pleasure in his present life as a country nobleman. Harking back to the subject of Socialism, the Prince declared that in his opinion a bloody cataclysm was impending in Germany in the near future and that the later repressive measures were undertaken the bloodier would be its solution. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 1, 1890

headline: 1915: Submarine Sinks the Iberian
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Germany torpedoes the Leyland liner Iberian in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sixty-one survivors of the Leyland liner Iberian, which after being attacked by shellfire, was torpedoed and sunk by a German submarine yesterday afternoon, were landed at a British port to-day. It was then learned that seven of her crew, three of whom were Americans, and one American woman, Miss Mary Wily, of Boston, had been killed by the pirates’ shellfire. The crew got into the ship’s boats and rowed about for several hours before being rescued by a British steamer. Two of the crew died on board the rescuing steamer. The Iberian had a gross tonnage of 5,223, and was built at Sunderland in 1900. Only a month ago the Armenian of the same line was torpedoed and sunk off the Scillies. She, too, was shelled as a preliminary, and a number of men were killed, among them being sixteen Americans. Six more Lowestoft trawlers, the Coriander, Fitzgerald, Quest, Athena, Achieve and Strive were torpedoed and sunk by submarines to-day. Nearly all of the crew were saved. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 1, 1915

headline: Wall Street Now Hates Democrats
abstract: Very much including Hillary.
lead_paragraph: Over at Vox, Jonathan Allen notes that Hillary Clinton, sometimes derided on the left as doing Wall Street’s bidding, is actually getting a lot less Wall Street money than people think. Allen notes that during her husband’s administration Clinton was known for her relative antipathy toward financial types, which may be part of the story. But you should also put this in the context of finance’s hard turn against Democrats in general. In 2004, facing an election whose outcome was uncertain, finance and insurance split its donations almost equally between the parties; in 2012 it gave well over twice as much to Republicans as to Democrats.

headline: Liberal Arts, a Lost Cause?

Breneman published a controversial report lamenting a shift away from liberal arts toward practical courses like engineering and business. Now, more and more university students enroll in professional programs, and the small colleges that were the hallmark of a liberal education are increasingly adding market-oriented programs. Some are closing. Sweet Briar, the 114-year-old women’s college in Virginia horse country, is one of the latest to run into trouble. Dr. Breneman, who had just finished six years as president of Kalamazoo College when he wrote his paper, went on to be dean of the school of education and a director of the school of public policy at the University of Virginia. After 10 years on Sweet Briar’s board, he stepped down in June as a new crew took on a rescue mission.

headline: Coffee Connections at Peddler in SoHo
abstract: Peddler, a sidewalk stand in SoHo with mismatched teacups dangling from hooks above a proper espresso machine, has all the trappings of an up-and-coming cafe, without the laptops.
lead_paragraph: On a humid Monday in July, the corner of Houston and Lafayette was typically busy. Tourists and late-afternoon commuters rushed into the subway. Yellow cabs lurched in and out of the gas station, avoiding shoppers carrying bags from Uniqlo and Zara. In the commotion, you easily could have missed the coffee cart with a frayed, slightly cockeyed umbrella, around which the city’s motion pooled and slowed to an amble.

Think of Holst’s “The Planets,” too, and the strains of “Jupiter,” later set as the patriotic hymn “I vow to thee, my country,” wander through the ears.

headline: Review: ‘Dapline!’ Demonstrates Gesture as Communication and Dance
abstract: This dance by Renegade Performance Group had no accompanying music: The sound came from the contact of hands and feet.
lead_paragraph: “Dapping” could be defined as elaborate handshaking, but that would only begin to describe this kind of greeting, developed by and still largely associated with African-American men. Yes, hands clasp and shake, but they also slide and slap and snap. Something between a punch and an embrace, dapping is communication through touch, a dialect direct in its wordlessness but still rich in emotional nuance and gestural beauty — like dance. All of these facets are illuminated by “Dapline!,” a powerful dance that Renegade Performance Group debuted on Thursday in University Settlement’s Speyer Hall on the Lower East Side. Choreographed by André M. Zachery with the artist LaMont Hamilton, this work for six men has no sound accompaniment but is hardly silent. Skin hits skin. Feet and fists pound the floor.

headline: Sunday at Grey Gardens With Liz Lange, Fashion Designer
abstract: Ms. Lange is spending her weekends this summer at Grey Gardens, the famed East Hampton estate.
lead_paragraph: When Liz Lange’s real estate broker sent her the rental listing for Grey Gardens, the famed East Hampton estate, her eyes nearly popped out. Ms. Lange, a fashion designer who sold her maternity-wear business in 2007 but remains its creative director, had long been captivated by the decaying mansion and its eccentric former residents, Edith Bouvier Beale and her daughter, Edie, who were immortalized in a 1975 documentary and who are also the subjects of a  2006 Broadway musical being revived this month at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor. Ms. Lange was also obsessed with the house’s subsequent renovation by the journalists Sally Quinn and Ben Bradlee. “There’s history in that house,” she said. She rented it, and Ms. Lange, 48, who lives on the Upper East Side, is spending extended weekends at Grey Gardens this summer with her fiancé, a lawyer; her children, Gus, 16, and Alice, 14; and their Goldendoodle, Rosie.

headline: Review: Karen Oberlin’s ‘His Aim Is True,’ a Tribute to Elvis Costello
abstract: Ms. Oberlin’s show at Stage 72 at the Triad celebrates Mr. Costello’s work as a cryptic genre unto itself, a code to be cracked or not.
lead_paragraph: Karen Oberlin’s extensively researched, beautifully executed tribute to the music of Elvis Costello answers a question that has been gnawing at me for years: Why have so few of Mr. Costello’s songs achieved the status of modern standards? For all this time, I had assumed that his raw, unwelcoming voice, with its strangulated diction, was the reason. Surely, a better-equipped singer could untangle his knotty lyrics and sharpen the melodic profiles of songs that Mr. Costello presented as impassioned downbeat mystery stories.
